Despite its rich history dating back to 1760, the school was unable to find a suitable partner or merge with other schools, and its decline can be attributed to poor decisions by the local authority. The community rallied around the school, but ultimately, the lack of funding led to its closure. I blame Michael Gove's academies plan, which has undermined local accountability and led to the loss of schools like Burnt Yates, which would still thrive if not for his policies.

The department publishes data on sponsored academy primary schools, which have been forced out of local control, and these schools consistently underperform compared to average schools. This is not surprising, given the higher proportion of students from disadvantaged backgrounds. Despite having more time to improve, the results of these schools do not show significant improvement. As a former primary school governor, I can attest to the devastating consequences of the academies program, which included the dismissal of governors, the headteacher's departure, and the takeover by a neighboring institution. The ACE academy chain's performance has fallen even further below average, with last year's results at other ACE schools only marginally better. The lack of effective oversight has enabled ACE to expand its network by taking on more schools and opening a new free school, despite its modest academic achievements.

The earliest known case of dandruff has been unearthed in a small, feathered dinosaur that lived around 125 million years ago. Scientists discovered tiny fossilized skin flakes on a microraptor, a crow-sized, meat-eating dinosaur with wings on all four limbs. Similar flakes were also found on two other feathered dinosaurs, beipiaosaurus and sinornithosaurus, as well as a primitive bird called confuciusornis. The fossilized skin flakes are the only evidence of how dinosaurs shed their skin. Unlike modern reptiles, which typically shed their skin in large sheets, the feathered dinosaurs shed their skin in tiny flakes. According to Maria McNamara, a paleontologist, "This is the only fossil dandruff known. Until now, we had no evidence for how dinosaurs shed their skin." Images taken with an electron microscope reveal that the fossilized dandruff is extremely well-preserved and almost identical to that found on modern birds. The skin flakes are made up of tough cells called corneocytes rich in the protein keratin. The study suggests that dinosaurs with feathers evolved skin to cope with their plumage as far back as the Middle Jurassic period. "Even in the early stages of feather evolution, they had already adapted their skin to this more modern structure," McNamara said. The fossilized remains of the animals were discovered in rock formations in northeastern China. Beipiaosaurus and sinornithosaurus, which grew to over 2 meters in length, were significantly larger than the 1-meter-long microraptor. Unlike modern birds, the dinosaur dandruff cells lacked fat, suggesting that the animals did not generate as much heat, possibly because they were not capable of flying long distances or at all. Many dinosaurs with feathers were not skilled fliers. "Rather, their feathers had multiple functions, including keeping them warm, blending in with their surroundings for camouflage, and potentially showcasing their vibrant colors to attract mates with dazzling displays."

I was a victim of identity fraud last year, and a Santander account I didn't open was discovered on my credit report. The fraudster had taken out a £11,420 loan from Sainsbury's Bank and deposited the funds into the Santander account. Sainsbury's Bank informed Santander and raised an indemnity to recover the money, but told me my credit file wouldn't be corrected until the issue was resolved. Although the Santander account was closed, the bank loan still appears on my credit report, disregarding my right to have inaccurate information corrected.

The high cost of relying on large financial institutions to communicate is evident in this case. Sainsbury's claims it only learned about my complaint when the Observer contacted them, and subsequently restored my credit record, which typically takes 60 days. However, Santander insists it notified Sainsbury's immediately after I reported the fraud and agreed to arrange an indemnity and close the loan. Despite this, nothing happened until eight days after I contacted Sainsbury's. Sainsbury's initially told me it hadn't been informed of the fraud, but it had actually been chasing Santander for the indemnity. Santander claimed it had never received an indemnity request and would need 30 days to process one. Fortunately, modern technology was used to expedite the indemnity process. Sainsbury's has since admitted it was contacted by Santander when I discovered the fraud, but claims Santander failed to respond to its requests for an indemnity. As a result, Sainsbury's amended my credit file and paid me £100 in compensation.

It's unclear which bank's inaction caused the delay, but it's clear that if I had wanted to apply for credit during the weeks of waiting, I would have been refused. Even if action had been taken promptly, the 60-day timescale for amending a credit record is far too long.

A fatal accident involving a self-driving Uber SUV in March has sparked a federal investigation. The vehicle's emergency braking system was intentionally disabled, according to the investigation. The National Transportation Safety Board's preliminary report revealed that the vehicle's guidance system detected the pedestrian six seconds before impact. However, the emergency braking system did not activate due to concerns about erratic vehicle behavior. The system relied on the human backup driver to intervene, but it did not alert the driver to the impending danger. The vehicle was traveling at 43 miles per hour when it struck the pedestrian, who was pushing a bicycle across a boulevard. The report showed that the sensors detected the need to brake 1.3 seconds before impact, but the brakes were not applied until after the fatal collision. The backup driver claimed she was monitoring the self-driving interface at the time of the accident. In response to the incident, Uber suspended testing in Arizona and focused on more limited testing in Pittsburgh and California. The company is conducting an internal review of its self-driving vehicle program and has brought in a former NTSB chairman to advise on its safety culture. The NTSB's preliminary report aims to provide an initial analysis of the incident, rather than assign blame. An expert in liability law emphasized the need for greater regulatory oversight in the testing of self-driving vehicles. States must exercise extreme caution when establishing and regulating these programs to avoid a patchwork of 50 different systems. We can't afford to have multiple, uncoordinated approaches, which could lead to experimentation with the technology at the risk of injuries and fatalities. To protect the public, states need to develop a more systematic approach. The question is, how can we achieve this?

The UK's Competition and Markets Authority is cracking down on hotel booking websites accused of deceiving customers. The regulator has been investigating the industry since October and has identified several warning signs. Major players such as Expedia and Booking.com are under scrutiny. The CMA is investigating whether a hotel's ranking on a website is influenced by the commission it pays, potentially leading to hotels that pay more commission being prioritized. The regulator is concerned that booking sites' display of room availability information can create a false sense of availability, prompting customers to make impulsive decisions. According to the CMA, 70% of people who shop around for accommodations use hotel booking sites, but many have found that the final price paid was inflated by unexpected extra charges. The CMA's CEO emphasized the importance of transparency, stating, "Booking sites can simplify the holiday selection process, but only if people can trust them." The regulator is demanding that the sites review their practices and provide a response within the next few months. If necessary, the CMA is prepared to take legal action to ensure consumers receive a fair deal. A financial expert welcomed the CMA's move, saying, "Hotel prices on booking and comparison sites often mislead. We hope the CMA will strictly enforce sites that fail to show the true cost upfront and claim false discounts or pressure-sell by suggesting the hotel is almost sold out."

Fastjet, a low-cost African airline, is on the verge of bankruptcy and has informed its shareholders that its shares will cease trading on Friday unless it secures additional funding promptly. Founded in 2012 with backing from easyJet's founder Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the airline is currently in talks with major shareholders to secure funding, but has no guarantee of success. Fastjet's cash reserves have dwindled from $7.5 million to just $3.3 million in a month, and the company warned that it is at risk of being unable to continue trading as a going concern. Despite launching operations in Tanzania with the aim of becoming a pan-African low-cost carrier, Fastjet has struggled with issues including inadequate banking infrastructure, overambitious plane orders, and high office costs. The airline's shares plummeted 70% on Wednesday, leaving them at just £3.70, valuing the company at around £19 million. Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who previously owned the Fastjet brand, expressed disappointment at the news, citing concerns about the company's management. He plans to attend the airline's upcoming AGM to voice his objections and vote against the proposed resolutions. Fastjet has expanded its operations to South Africa, Zimbabwe, Zambia, and Mozambique, operating four small Embraer aircraft. Despite never transporting more than one million passengers annually, the airline incurred an average annual loss of $50 million until 2016. The airline has yet to release its 2017 financial results, which must be published by Friday to avoid delisting from London's Alternative Investment Market (AIM).

Carpetright has reported a substantial annual loss of £70.5 million, largely due to sluggish trading and the costs associated with a major restructuring effort involving the closure of 92 stores. The retailer described the past year as extremely challenging, citing a 3.6% decline in sales at its established UK stores for the year ending April 28. The company's trading has been severely impacted in the first eight weeks of the current financial year, particularly due to supplier withdrawals and hot weather, which has kept customers away. Carpetright's store closure plan, announced in April, put 300 jobs at risk, and the company is now seeking rent reductions of up to 50% on 113 additional stores through a company voluntary arrangement. This process aims to prevent administration and allow the company to recover from its struggles, largely attributed to weaker consumer spending and a slowdown in the housing market. The CEO emphasized the company's focus on implementing its recovery plan, stating that the CVA and recapitalization offer a chance to rebuild the business, which remains the market leader in floor coverings with strong brand recognition. By the end of September, Carpetright expects to have closed 81 of the 92 targeted stores. The company's revenue for the year to April 28 fell by 3% to £443.8 million. Carpetright's situation has deteriorated significantly in 2018, with multiple profit warnings and a corresponding impact on its share price. However, the CVA has provided the company with some much-needed breathing space. Following the announcement, Carpetright's shares fell by 2%.

Over the past century, human life expectancy has plateaued. Prior to 2010, life expectancy in Britain had been steadily increasing, with men born in the 1920s and 1930s enjoying unusually long and healthy lives. This growth in lifespan has had far-reaching consequences across various aspects of life. The trend of increasing longevity has come to a standstill, according to a recent analysis by the Office for National Statistics. The underlying causes of this sudden stagnation are unclear, but potential factors include austerity measures, reduced NHS spending, flu outbreaks, rising obesity and diabetes rates, and increasing multimorbidity. The study's findings are concerning, as they indicate that the trend towards improving life expectancy has slowed significantly. The slowdown began in the second quarter of 2009 for men and soon after for women. Between 2011 and 2013, and again between 2014 and 2016, only a small number of local authorities in England showed statistically significant increases in life expectancy. This is a stark contrast to the equivalent period 10 years earlier, when many more local authorities reported significant increases in life expectancy. Other disquieting data from the weekly register of deaths in England and Wales this year adds to the worrying trend. The statistics reveal that the number of deaths is significantly higher than the average over the past five years. Pension companies repeatedly advise savers to plan for a retirement lasting 25 years or more, but perhaps this assumption is flawed. Maybe we should now reconsider increasing the state pension age and instead focus on maintaining the current age.

On International Women in Engineering Day, we celebrate the outstanding achievements of female engineers globally. Although women in the UK comprise just 11% of the engineering profession, their contributions are vital. Engineering significantly impacts our daily lives, from infrastructure to innovations like AI and robotics. To inspire more women to pursue engineering, we must effectively showcase its diverse applications to young women. By doing so, we can empower a new generation of women to join a field that shapes the future. Once women are part of the profession, we must strive to support and empower them to reach their full potential. According to the Create the Future report, 92% of respondents believe engineering has a profound daily impact. A balanced engineering sector is crucial for building a better future for all.

Mike Ashley, the founder of Sports Direct, has initiated talks to provide an emergency funding package to House of Fraser, in which he already holds an 11% stake. Ashley was approached by bankers advising House of Fraser to consider a £50m loan. House of Fraser announced plans to close 31 of its 59 stores, putting 6,000 jobs at risk, in June. The retailer secured a temporary reprieve from its lenders, who agreed to extend loans while it undergoes restructuring under a company voluntary arrangement scheme. C.banner, the Chinese owner of Hamleys, had agreed to invest £70m in House of Fraser, conditional on the CVA being implemented. However, the CVA plans are now in doubt due to a legal challenge in Scotland. House of Fraser's CEO, Alex Williamson, has described the CVA as the "last viable" option for the business. After winning a legal challenge to obtain House of Fraser's business plans, Ashley gained valuable information that could aid an investment bid. Ashley acquired his 11% stake in House of Fraser in 2014, when 89% of the business was sold to Chinese conglomerate Sanpower in a deal worth £480m. He also has a 29.7% stake in Debenhams and strategic investments in businesses such as Goals Soccer Centres and French Connection. House of Fraser is one of several retailers to seek controversial CVAs as Britain's high streets struggle with rising costs, weak consumer confidence, and competition from online-only rivals like Amazon.

Samuel Smith Old Brewery, Britain's oldest brewery, and its chairman, Humphrey Smith, have been fined £30,000 for withholding crucial documents about their pension scheme. The Pension Regulator requested pension plan information in 2015 to ensure sufficient funding for 2,000 employees' final-salary pension schemes. Smith dismissed the request as "tiresome" and refused to comply, prompting court proceedings. The company and Smith pleaded guilty in May and were sentenced at Brighton magistrates court. The brewery was fined £26,750, Smith £8,000, and costs of £1,240 were ordered. Judge Teresa Szagun criticized the brewery's tone, calling it "deliberately inflammatory," and said the company's refusal put 2,000 employees' future and security at risk. The total fine, including a victim surcharge and costs, was £27,990. Nicola Parish said, "Issuing a court summons and receiving compliance won't halt criminal proceedings, as Mr. Smith has recently learned." Samuel Smith Old Brewery operates 300 UK pubs. In 2017, Smith implemented a no-swearing policy and banned music to avoid music copyright royalties.

"In my opinion, the Help-to-Buy scheme may not be the best option for my sons, who are 30 and 35, and have been renting for 15 years. I think they're wise to be cautious about the scheme. If they can afford to buy a property without using the scheme, it would make more sense. According to the Help to Buy Buyers' Guide, if you can already secure a 90% mortgage, you should carefully consider whether a Help-to-Buy equity loan is right for you. There may be better options available.

Help-to-Buy can be a good option if you're looking to buy a new-build property from a registered house builder and need the 20% equity loan to complete the purchase. However, it's not suitable if you don't want a new-build Help-to-Buy home or don't need government assistance. The Help-to-Buy equity loan is not free money - you'll need to pay a monthly management fee of £1 and interest will start to be charged after five years.

The primary concern with an equity loan is that if house values increase, so does the amount you'll need to repay. Furthermore, interest rates on Help-to-Buy mortgages are less competitive than those for standard mortgages. Considering my sons have mixed opinions about the Help-to-Buy scheme and are under 40, I recommend they opt for the free government funding that comes with saving in a Lifetime ISA for property purchase."

Over the past year, scientist Jess Wade has created over 270 Wikipedia entries about influential women in science who have been overlooked, including Susan Goldberg, the first female editor of National Geographic. Research indicates that only 16% of Wikipedia editors are female, and just 17% of entries about notable individuals are about women. A 2016 Oxford University study found that most content about African countries on Wikipedia was written by editors from Europe and North America, with only 16% of content about sub-Saharan Africa being written by local contributors. The language of a Wikipedia entry influences the sources used, leading to different versions of the truth. For instance, an English-language article about Russia's annexation of Crimea cited 24% of sources as Ukrainian and 20% as Russian, whereas the German version cited only 10% of sources as Russian and 3% as Ukrainian. A 2011 study analyzed nearly 30,000 Wikipedia entries about US politics and found a slight bias towards the Democrats. The study discovered that entries were more likely to use Democratic phrases than Republican phrases. Although later entries were less biased, the study concluded that the average old political article on Wikipedia leans Democratic. A 2011 paper reviewed thousands of Wikipedia articles and found that, although most articles were accurate, recent events received the most coverage. The author analyzed US gubernatorial elections since 1978 and found that coverage before 2001 was scarce, reflecting the limited expertise and interests of contributors.

The Daily Mail published a front-page correction and issued disciplinary notes to senior staff after falsely claiming an Iraqi man won compensation for being caught with a bomb. The original story, published on December 15, incorrectly stated Abd Ali Hameed al-Waheed was caught with a bomb and awarded £33,000 due to excessive detention. However, the judge's decision to award al-Waheed compensation was based on his unlawful imprisonment and mistreatment during the Iraq war. The newspaper ran the story despite the judge concluding the bomb claims were "pure fiction" and discredited shortly after detention. Ipso ordered the correction after finding the Daily Mail breached accuracy rules in its reporting. Ipso stated the newspaper's failure to clarify the bomb claims' disproof seriously misrepresented the judgment's basis. The judge found no evidence supported the claim al-Waheed was an insurgent, and he was detained without legal basis for 33 days in 2007. The compensation award was broken down into £3,300 for unlawful detention, £15,000 for beating after arrest, and £15,000 for ill treatment. The Daily Mail defended its reporting by citing a three-page summary of the 239-page judgment and previous reporting. Ipso rejected this explanation, arguing it was unreasonable to rely on previous press coverage without verifying accuracy. Following the decision, a major internal investigation was conducted, and seven senior staff members received strongly worded disciplinary notes. These notes made it clear that similar errors in the future would jeopardize employees' careers.

The James Webb Space Telescope, a highly ambitious project, is now scheduled to launch in March 2021, following a rescheduling from its initial October launch date. Initially, the project was estimated to cost $500 million and launch in 2007, but technical issues and delays have significantly increased the budget to approximately $9.6 billion. The mission's requirements proved unexpectedly complex, leading to prolonged delays and cost overruns, and in 2011, the US Congress considered terminating the project. However, the mission was ultimately capped at around $8 billion, and the latest delay will bring the total budget to $9.6 billion. The source of the additional funding remains unclear. NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine has suggested redirecting funds from the Wide-Field Infrared Survey Telescope to the James Webb Space Telescope. The European Space Agency, a partner in the project, will launch the telescope from Kourou, French Guiana, in South America, and provide two instruments for the mission.

BP has agreed to acquire US shale oil and gas fields from BHP for $10.5 billion, marking its largest acquisition in nearly two decades. The deal is transformational and will significantly enhance the company's US shale presence, according to CEO Bob Dudley. The acquisition will increase BP's US oil and gas production by nearly 20% and marks a new era of growth for the company. The deal covers 470,000 acres of assets, including fields in the Permian Basin, the Eagle Ford, and Haynesville. Analysts have praised the deal, with Eagle Ford being considered the most valuable due to its scale and economics. BHP purchased the fields in 2011 but struggled to make them profitable, leading to their sale last August. BP believes its approach will differ from BHP's, bringing $350 million in synergies from its other US operations. The acquisition gives the company access to some of the best acreage in the best basins, including the Permian Basin. Following the deal's completion, BP's US production is expected to increase to 885,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. The acquisition will be entirely financed through cash and is being partially funded by the company's decision to divest its interests in the Greater Kuparuk Area. BP's deal significantly surpasses its recent investments in Europe's largest solar company and the UK's largest electric car charging network. BHP will return the proceeds from the sale to its investors, and its shares closed the day up 2.3%. In contrast, BP's share price declined by 1.5%. The company's largest transaction in recent history was its acquisition of Atlantic Richfield in 1999.

A parliamentary committee has issued a scathing report, condemning local councils for exacerbating financial hardship by employing aggressive debt collection methods to recover council tax arrears. In 2016, a staggering 2.3 million debt cases were referred to bailiffs by local authorities, statistics show. The report lambasts the "overzealous" pursuit of debtors, arguing that the public sector should set an example for responsible debt collection. MPs are calling for a reform of debt collection practices to meet industry standards. A debt charity found that one-third of its clients had council tax arrears averaging £1,000, with many expressing concern over aggressive debt collection tactics. The case of Jerome Rogers, a 20-year-old courier who took his own life after being pursued by bailiffs for two parking fines, underscores the need for fundamental changes to the debt collection industry. Creditfix identified 55 councils that consistently reject payment plans, leaving individuals with no choice but to declare bankruptcy. The report's CEO welcomed the findings, criticizing the government and local authorities for poor debt collection practices. The report recommends caps on high-cost credit and reforms to tax relief on pension contributions. The inquiry highlighted weaknesses in household finances, including excessive debt, inadequate savings, and insufficient pension savings. The report presents recommendations for the government to consider, aimed at helping households build more resilient financial foundations.

Fever-Tree, a 13-year-old drinks company, has reached a record value of £4.5 billion after exceeding profit forecasts, driven by Britain's insatiable demand for gin. The company's value has nearly matched that of Royal Mail and surpassed the combined stock market value of WH Smith, Debenhams, the AA, and Saga. Fever-Tree's rapid growth can be attributed to the soaring popularity of premium gin, which has doubled UK sales to £1.2 billion in the past six years. Gin is the most beloved spirit in the UK, with 29% of drinkers voting it their favorite. Riding the wave of gin's popularity has transformed Fever-Tree into one of the UK's fastest-growing major companies, making co-founders Charles Rolls and Tim Warrilow multi-millionaires. The pair founded Fever-Tree in 2005 and since the company's stock market float in 2014, Rolls has sold shares worth over £150 million, while Warrilow has sold shares worth £41 million. They still own 14% of the company, a stake worth nearly £600 million. Fever-Tree's shares jumped by as much as 15% to an all-time high of £39.87, driven by profits rising by a third to £34 million in the first six months of the year. The company reported particularly strong performance in the UK over the Christmas period, with an "impressive rate of sales growth." Fever-Tree has announced two new distribution agreements: one in the US with Southern Glazer's Wine and Spirits, and another with Grupo Damm, a Spanish company that produces Estrella Damm.

A UK transport operator, Stagecoach, is planning a trial of a full-sized driverless bus for the first time in the country later this year. The trial will take place within the company's depots, where the bus will operate autonomously until necessary laws permit passenger transportation. The bus is being adapted with technology similar to that used in a recent trial of driverless pods in Greenwich, south-east London. According to Stagecoach, the bus will be able to park, refuel, and navigate to wash points without human intervention. The company believes that wider adoption of self-driving buses could lead to safer and more efficient operations, as well as increased space within its depots.

Even when the bus is on public roads, the sensor system could provide earlier warnings to other road users, such as cyclists or pedestrians, who may be in blind spots or approaching unexpectedly. Stagecoach's UK bus engineering director, Sam Greer, described the project as exciting and potentially transformative, stating that it could improve safety and efficiency within depots and, in the long term, revolutionize bus travel.

This move by a traditional bus operator using a full-size vehicle could mark a significant step towards the wider adoption of autonomous vehicles in the UK. In contrast, passenger services using small driverless vehicles have been trialed in France, while China has tested larger driverless buses on major city roads in Shenzhen. The trials in Greenwich suggested that passengers may be more receptive to larger autonomous vehicles for public transportation than smaller pods. While driverless trains have been in operation for some time, researchers found that users had concerns about sharing vehicles with strangers, with 85% of participants expressing comfort with autonomous technology but only 46% willing to ride-share. Many respondents indicated that they were not willing to pay a substantial amount above the standard bus fare to use autonomous driverless pods.

A rare total lunar eclipse will be visible from most of Europe, Asia, Australia, and South America on July 27, with North America excluded. During a total lunar eclipse, the moon traverses the Earth's shadow, adopting a deep reddish hue. This spectacular phenomenon arises because sunlight bends through the Earth's atmosphere, scattering blue light and refracting red light. Consequently, the sky appears blue to us, while the red light is directed behind the Earth and onto the Moon. In the UK, the eclipse will commence before the moon rises, with the Earth's shadow already covering the lunar surface at 8:50pm. Thirty minutes later, the moon will reach the midpoint of the eclipse, showcasing its characteristic red color. By 10:15pm, the moon will have exited the Earth's shadow, concluding the eclipse.

Craig Jones, a successful local politician, turned to Wonga for financial assistance in 2011, taking out a small loan to alleviate his financial struggles. However, his financial situation didn't improve, and he found himself taking out multiple loans from various sources, eventually borrowing several hundred pounds. Wonga's profits soared to £45.8m on revenues of £185m in 2011, and the company was valued at £15bn by 2015. But its fortunes took a downturn the following year after it was embroiled in a scandal over fake legal letters and ordered to pay millions in compensation. As a result of the scandal, Jones received compensation from Wonga in the region of £800. He praised Labour MP Stella Creasy, a leading campaigner against payday loans, in a tweet, acknowledging that he had fallen victim to the industry's tactics himself. Jones acknowledged that Wonga filled a market gap, noting that its instant decision loans made it an easy and overly accessible way to access credit when needed, almost too easy. However, he also pointed out that Wonga targeted individuals who might not have been able to access other forms of credit. Jones emphasized the need for a campaign to make credit unions more accessible.

Aston Martin, a luxury car manufacturer, was founded in 1913 by engineer Robert Bamford and car enthusiast Lionel Martin in a small London workshop. The company's name was inspired by their success at the Aston Hill Climb track in Buckinghamshire. Aston Martin made its international racing debut in the 1922 French Grand Prix, but faced financial difficulties and was rescued in 1926. The company developed a reputation for engineering and design, competing in the Le Mans 24 Hours for the first time in 1928. Production of its road cars increased in the 1930s, with a record 140 cars built in 1937. In 1947, English industrialist David Brown acquired the company, expanding operations and relocating production. The company relocated its production base again in 1955 to Newport Pagnell. The iconic Aston Martin DB5 was introduced in 1963, and its famous partnership with James Bond began a year later in the film Goldfinger. Bond has since driven an Aston Martin in several films. The company changed hands several times in the 1970s and 1980s, and in 1987, Ford Motor Company acquired a 75% stake. The DB moniker was revived with the introduction of the DB7 in 1993. Aston Martin opened its first purpose-built factory in Gaydon, Warwickshire, in 2003. The company returned to racing in 2005 with the DBR9. In 2007, Aston Martin was sold to a consortium of two Kuwaiti investment houses for nearly £1 billion. Today, Aston Martin is one of the world's leading sports car manufacturers. The company is poised to make its stock market debut in London later this year.

Toyota, a Japanese automaker, is poised to invest $500 million in Uber to fortify their collaboration on autonomous vehicles, aiming to bridge the gap with competitors in the autonomous vehicle market. The investment values Uber at $72 billion, despite the company's substantial losses in 2017. The partnership will harness technology from both companies to create bespoke Toyota vehicles for Uber's ride-sharing network, starting in 2021. Toyota's investment marks a significant milestone in the company's metamorphosis into a mobility company. The deal represents a major step towards Uber's revitalization of its self-driving business, which was suspended following a fatal crash in Tempe, Arizona. Under the agreement, Uber will combine its autonomous driving system with Toyota's Guardian technology, offering automated safety features. The companies plan to integrate the combined technology into Toyota's Sienna minivans for use on Uber's ride-hailing network, starting in 2021. The partnership will pit Uber and Toyota against major players in the autonomous vehicle market, including Waymo. Uber's CEO described the deal as the first of its kind for the company. Our goal is to deploy the world's safest self-driving cars on the Uber network, and this agreement is another significant step towards making that a reality. Uber's advanced technology and Toyota's commitment to safety and manufacturing prowess make this partnership a natural fit.

My son is taking a year off before starting university in 2019 and wants to earn money for future travel. Should he find work locally or abroad, such as in Australia? Share your gap year experiences and advice for making the most of this time. If you have a problem you'd like our readers to help solve, email money@theguardian.com or write to us at Money, The Guardian, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU."

If you're struggling with math or know someone preparing for a test, you might be interested in the format of a modern GCSE math exam. Take this chance to test your skills with 20 questions drawn from actual past papers. Please note that we can't fully replicate the exam environment, as students typically spend four and a half hours taking exams with no calculators allowed. Unlike an online quiz, not all questions are multiple-choice, and students must show their work to earn full marks. After completing this quiz, you'll gain insight into the types of math questions students are expected to answer. Good luck, and share your results in the comments. If you're more comfortable with words than numbers, try our arts and humanities essay questions instead.

Ticketmaster has been praised by Rob Davies for closing its resale platforms. We remember a time before Ticketmaster, when we could simply phone a theatre or concert hall's box office to reserve a ticket at face value. However, "ticket partners" soon took over box office duties, leaving us to foot the bill. Today, we're charged a booking fee for every ticket, which can be a flat rate or percentage, and on top of that, there's a transaction fee that significantly adds to the cost of a night out. I liken it to shopping at a supermarket, where you'd be charged a "shopping fee" for each item, followed by a "transaction fee" at checkout. I believe ticket companies are unnecessary intermediaries, and I'll only praise them when they cease to exist entirely.

Superdrug has alerted its online customers to update their passwords after hackers claimed to have stolen the personal details of thousands of people. The hackers, who contacted Superdrug on Monday evening, allegedly obtained the personal information of 20,000 customers, including names, addresses, dates of birth, and phone numbers. However, Superdrug has confirmed that only 386 accounts have been compromised so far. The hackers gained access to the accounts by using email addresses and passwords stolen from other websites. Superdrug assures customers that payment card information was not stolen. Customers are advised to change their passwords, and the company has notified the police and Action Fraud of the incident. Superdrug has apologized for any inconvenience caused by difficulties customers may be experiencing when trying to change their passwords. A customer reported trying and failing to change her password on four different devices. This is the latest in a series of high-profile data breaches to affect high street retailers. Last month, Dixons Carphone revealed that personal data belonging to 10 million customers may have been accessed illegally, nearly 10 times as many as initially thought.

Elite private schools are urging universities to reduce the use of unconditional offers for undergraduate places, citing concerns that students may become complacent and not strive for high A-level grades. According to Mike Buchanan, executive director of the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference, students tend to relax after accepting unconditional offers. Buchanan believes that students will carry their academic achievements throughout their careers and should be motivated to work hard. He is calling on universities to only offer unconditional places to students who have been interviewed or whose schools have provided additional information. Historically, only a small number of students received unconditional offers, but the government's removal of the cap on funded undergraduate numbers has allowed universities to expand and compete aggressively for students and tuition fees. While there is limited evidence on the impact of unconditional offers on students' final grades, private school heads have long been concerned about the potential impact on their school's results and league table rankings. Some employers place significant weight on A-level grades when recruiting for graduate trainee programs, which means that students who underperform may struggle in the job market. The HMC's call follows that of Education Minister Sam Gyimah, who in July criticized the rise in unconditional offers as "completely irresponsible to students" and urged universities to limit their use. Typically, universities make conditional offers, specifying the A-level grades required to secure a place. However, in a more competitive market, unconditional offers have become more common, even among research-intensive institutions in the Russell Group. According to Ucas, 7% of the 950,000 offers made this year were unconditional, with roughly one-fifth of the 250,000 applicants to English universities receiving at least one such offer. Ucas noted that unconditional offers were more prevalent for older students who already held qualifications, as well as for those applying to creative arts courses who submit portfolios or attend auditions, and for students with mental health difficulties. University vice-chancellors have defended unconditional offers, citing their benefits in allowing for earlier engagement between universities and students, and making it easier to plan courses and accommodation.

A recent phonics screening check reveals that white boys from disadvantaged backgrounds significantly underperform, even at the earliest stage of their education. The results, segmented by ethnic group, gender, and free school meal eligibility, show that white boys receiving free school meals are the lowest-achieving group, with only 62% meeting the required standard. Despite a two-percentage-point improvement from last year, disadvantaged white boys still lag behind their peers. Overall, 82% of pupils met the expected standard, a one-percentage-point increase from 2017. Chinese girls not receiving free school meals emerged as the highest-performing group. The phonics screening check involves pupils reading 40 words aloud, with a pass mark of 32. Pupils who fail to meet the standard will retake the check at the end of year 2, by which time 92% are expected to meet the required standard. Fewer than half (44%) of pupils with special educational needs reached the pass mark, compared to 89% of pupils with no identified SEN. Provisional results for key stage 1 teacher assessments showed a slight decline in the number of six- and seven-year-olds reaching the expected standard in reading and maths. The government reported that 163,000 more six-year-olds are on track to become fluent readers than in 2012. However, the test remains contentious, with 85% of heads believing it should not be compulsory and 65% of teachers wanting it scrapped. A representative of the More Than A Score campaign group argued that the phonics check is a waste of valuable teaching time and instead of fostering a love of reading, children are spending months drilling on nonsensical words solely to prepare for a test. School Standards Minister Nick Gibb hailed this as a significant achievement, citing its positive impact on the education and lives of hundreds of thousands of children, and reiterated the government's commitment to ensuring every child has the opportunity to reach their full potential.

Tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes and his wife Annie have acquired Australia's most expensive home, the historic Fairwater estate in Point Piper, for a reported $100 million. The estate, spanning 1.12 hectares, has been in the Fairfax family's hands for over a century, with its rich history and legacy. Cannon-Brookes, co-founder of software company Atlassian, expressed his delight with the purchase, stating that he and his family are eager to preserve the estate's beauty and heritage. The family is particularly excited to raise their four young children in this historic property, which offers a unique opportunity for their children to grow up in a piece of Australian history. Fairwater is the largest privately held property on Sydney Harbour and one of the most significant heritage homes in Australia, boasting a rich history dating back to 1882. The waterfront estate stretches from New South Head Road to Seven Shillings Beach and has been the residence of the Fairfax publishing family since 1900. The property was previously owned by Mary Fairfax, who passed away in September last year, leaving behind a priceless collection of artworks. According to the New South Wales heritage register, Fairwater is of rare historic, aesthetic, social, and scientific significance, featuring a 2-metre tall bronze nude Rodin sculpture and paintings by Chagall, Degas, and Arthur Boyd. The property was listed for sale this month, despite rumors that it would be bequeathed to the state of NSW, and reportedly took less than two weeks to sell. Atlassian, founded by Cannon-Brookes and Scott Farquhar in Sydney in 2002, was worth $29.9 billion at the beginning of September, making the pair among the 10 richest Australians. Interestingly, Farquhar, Cannon-Brookes' business partner, purchased the neighboring estate Elaine for over $70 million last year, which was previously owned by the Fairfax family.

Bentley has joined the list of carmakers warning that a no-deal Brexit would negatively impact its sales and ability to invest, potentially leading to a temporary shutdown of its Crewe, Cheshire factory. The company is proactively stockpiling components and shifting to a different port to import certain parts ahead of Brexit. If a Brexit deal is not reached by the end of the year, Bentley may further stockpile parts and close its factory for additional days. The majority of Bentley's key components, including engines and bodies, are sourced from the European Union, primarily Germany. We may work for four days or have extended Christmas and Easter breaks if a no-deal Brexit occurs, allowing us to manage the period between now and mid-next year. The company is concerned about the potential for tariffs and long delays in importing components. In the best-case scenario, a no-deal Brexit would be a minor disruption to our annual profitability, while in the worst-case scenario, it would be quite damaging. A full no-deal Brexit would significantly harm our company, limiting our ability to invest. Bentley is stockpiling engines in preparation for Brexit and is even considering airlifting components if motorway traffic to and from Dover becomes severely disrupted. The company is exploring all options, including relocating staff to a three-day workweek. This announcement comes as Bentley continues to struggle financially, with the company reporting a significant decline in sales. Between January 1 and September 30, Bentley sold 6,654 vehicles, a 12% decrease from the 7,498 vehicles sold during the same period the previous year. The company's sales revenue dropped to €1.1 billion from €1.3 billion, and its operating loss widened to €137 million from €31 million, largely due to exchange rate fluctuations and delays in the launch of the new Continental GT model.
