A local Thomas Cook representative worked late into the night and returned on Sunday morning to address guests' urgent queries. The company stated that any guests who had paid the hotel had been refunded. A Thomas Cook spokesperson said: "We are aware that a small number of customers were asked to pay for their hotel room before leaving Les Orangers in Tunisia. This has now been resolved and customers flew home as planned. We continue to support our customers in all our resorts." Lynn and Peter Taylor reported that guests leaving the hotel had been asked for extra payment. "Those who were due to leave today had letters slipped under their door," said Lynn Taylor. "The hotel was asking for 6,000 TD. I think one old lady paid it. We didn't." The hotel refused to comment on its communication with Thomas Cook, only confirming that guests are now free to enter and leave the premises. Tunisia's tourism industry is still recovering from the devastating impact of two terror attacks in 2015, which severely damaged the sector and resulted in the mass killing of predominantly British tourists. The UK was particularly affected, as a government travel warning was in place from June 2015 to July 2017, advising against travel to Tunisia. Thomas Cook was one of the first companies to resume flights to Tunisia, announcing its return in February 2018. The British consulate in Tunis is aware of the situation and is providing assistance as needed.

A public servant in the home affairs department has expressed concerns to Parliament that the department's whistleblowing scheme is ineffective, citing a failed investigation into a staffing incident involving a senior executive. The submission alleges that a public interest disclosure was made in 2017 regarding an issue with hiring practices involving a senior executive, which was instead of being investigated independently, sent back to the department for handling. The government emphasizes the importance of the public interest disclosure process, rather than leaking information to the media. The Home Affairs Secretary stated that the department will investigate and prosecute public servants who leak sensitive information. The submission reveals that the public servant initially contacted the ombudsman and the Australian Commission for Law Enforcement Integrity, but the matter was ultimately handled internally. The submission questions the independence of the investigation, suggesting that it would be unlikely for an executive-level investigator to make adverse findings against a senior executive. The submission concludes that the department's handling of the matter was flawed and lacked an independent investigation. A public servant with over 30 years of experience described the situation as "worthy of an episode of ABC's Utopia". The Guardian has reached out to the home affairs department for a response.

Marks & Spencer is set to launch a "buy now, pay later" service on its website next month, aiming to attract younger customers and boost sales ahead of the crucial Christmas period. The retailer has partnered with Clearpay to offer customers the option of paying for orders over £30 in interest-free instalments. Clearpay, an Australian fintech company, has gained popularity among millennials on tight budgets, alongside its rival Klarna. Many of M&S's competitors, including H&M and Asos, already offer delayed payment services, and the struggling business is eager to attract a younger generation of shoppers. M&S says its customers are increasingly seeking ways to spread the cost of larger purchases, and the Clearpay service enables them to do so by spreading the total over four instalments paid back across six weeks. The maximum spend is £800, and customers can manage their payments through a phone app without needing to apply for credit. Unlike traditional credit products, fintech firms like Clearpay and Klarna make money by earning commission on the sales transaction. Shoppers who use these plans tend to spend more frequently, making it an attractive proposition for retailers like M&S. Over 4,000 UK retailers, including Asos, JD Sports, and Boohoo, work with Klarna, which has more than 3 million British customers. Clearpay, which launched in the UK just three months ago, has already gained over 200,000 active customers. However, not everyone is a fan of this form of credit. Simon Wolfson, CEO of Next, has expressed concerns that it might be dangerous, saying that there is a difference between spreading the cost and just deferring it. Stepchange, a debt charity, has also expressed concern that these payment plans may inadvertently encourage individuals to spend money they don't have. These services are marketed to consumers as a convenient option to "try before you buy", but the unintended consequence is that people may take on debt they wouldn't have otherwise considered.

Two years ago, Thames Water unexpectedly declared our residential property a commercial property and transferred our account to Castle Water without warning or explanation. We didn't discover the change until I notified Castle Water of our move, when we found out they believed we were a commercial customer. As a family of two adults and a baby, we're still waiting for a refund from Castle Water, which would mean paying our water bill twice. I submitted a complaint to the Consumer Council for Water, but haven't received a response.

As one of many customers affected by the acquisition of Thames Water's business accounts by Castle Water, I wasn't informed of the reason for the transfer. However, after your intervention, Thames Water acknowledged that an administrative error led to our property being listed as non-household, resulting in the transfer. Thames Water apologized for the confusion and is working with Castle Water to ensure we're not left out of pocket.

Castle Water has since refunded us £818, but the bill from Thames Water was £874. Thames Water is currently offering us an installment plan. The Consumer Council for Water reports that Castle Water has consistently exceeded the industry average for complaints over the past 18 months. We appreciate your letters, but due to the volume, we're unable to respond to each one individually. If you'd like to share your thoughts, you can email us or write to us at the address below. Please include your daytime phone number. All submissions are subject to our terms and conditions.

The festive food industry is on the verge of collapse due to labor shortages in the meat industry caused by Brexit. According to the National Pig Association, specialized processing plants already struggling to meet orders require additional seasonal labor for hand-finished products. Meat processing plants are facing labor shortages equivalent to 15% of their required workforces, while seasonal specialists are experiencing shortages of up to 30%. The decline in the pound's value since the 2016 referendum, combined with uncertainty over residential status, has significantly exacerbated labor shortages.

Ed Barker, senior policy advisor for the NPA, reported that processors reliant on European semi-skilled laborers are struggling to fulfill orders ahead of Christmas. "It's been challenging for two years, but it seems particularly strained this year," Barker said. "Three years of uncertainty and the decline in the sterling to euro exchange rate has altered the mindset of many laborers who have decided to return home." The British Poultry Council stated that its members are 20% short of regular staff, and seasonal specialists, such as turkey and goose producers, are under pressure due to difficulties in hiring up to 2,000 extra workers usually required ahead of Christmas.

Concerns about meat production come after it was revealed that thousands of tonnes of fruit and vegetables are being left to rot in UK fields due to a shortage of pickers and packers caused by ongoing Brexit uncertainty. Last month, some fruit farmers reported having 30% fewer workers than required, highlighting the severity of the issue.

"We're seeking your input to answer a question from a Guardian Money reader. A selection of the best responses will be published in our Saturday edition. My partner is extremely cautious about turning off electronic devices at night due to safety concerns, including unplugging the TV, charging devices like iPads and phones, and not running the dishwasher. Is she overreacting? Is it safe to leave appliances running while asleep? Share your thoughts with us and we'll feature a selection of responses. Email your suggestions to money@theguardian.com or write to Money, The Guardian, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU."

Luxury department store Fortnum & Mason has experienced a year of robust sales and profits, despite the challenges posed by ongoing protests in Hong Kong. CEO Ewan Venters remains upbeat, citing strong bookings for the store's restaurant, which has received 4,000 reservations for December alone. The store, the company's first standalone location outside the UK, has seen sales fall short of expectations, but Venters is confident that business will recover. The retailer, founded in 1707, is renowned for its high-end products, including smoked salmon and caviar, with customers willing to spend up to HK$7,000 on these items. The company operates concessions in several Asian department stores, including Lane Crawford in Hong Kong, Isetan Mitsukoshi in Japan, and Shinsegae in South Korea. Fortnum & Mason's profits rose 26% to £12m in the year ending July 2019, with total sales increasing 12% to £138m. The group's flagship shop on Piccadilly saw a 6% increase in sales, while online sales grew by 13%. The company has benefited from a trend towards upscale tea consumption, with tea sales rising 11% due to the popularity of unusual flavors. New products like sparkling tea have also boosted tea sales, offering an alternative to alcohol.

In response to your article 'One in five pupils granted more time to sit key exams' (22 November), I argue that genuine prioritization of inclusion and accessibility requires reevaluating the excessive time spent testing children and young people to identify their 'abnormal' needs before written exams. It's natural for everyone to work at different speeds, and each individual should be given the time they need to complete the task.

A potential solution is setting a standard time limit for each exam, with the option for students to request an additional 30% time if necessary. This approach aligns with the principles of the Equality Act 2010, which requires educational institutions to promote equality of opportunity between individuals with and without protected characteristics.

I hope this suggestion sparks a productive debate. I look forward to reading the thoughts of other Guardian readers on this important topic. You can join the discussion by emailing guardian.letters@theguardian.com or sharing your photos with us for publication in our print edition.

Inter Ikea Group, the parent company of Ikea, plans to dedicate €200 million to green energy and forest planting to achieve carbon neutrality by 2030. The investment will be divided into two phases, with €100 million allocated to new renewable energy projects and the second phase focusing on carbon removal through reforestation and responsible forest management. Inter Ikea Group has already made substantial investments in sustainability, with a commitment to spend at least €3 billion. Since 2009, the company has invested in renewable energy, owning wind turbines and solar panels in 14 countries, and has also acquired forest land. Ingka Group, which operates 374 Ikea stores, has taken steps to reduce its environmental footprint, including investing in plastics recycling and textile recycling. According to Inter Ikea Group's chief sustainability officer, reducing greenhouse gas emissions is critical in limiting climate change, but removing existing carbon from the atmosphere is also essential. The company believes it can make a positive impact through its integrated supply chain, global presence, and expertise in forestry and climate issues.

A power outage hit the ABC's Ultimo headquarters, causing the ABC News website, app, and homepage to display stories from 2011. On Wednesday morning, ABC readers were met with a retro layout featuring Julia Gillard as prime minister, Lady Gaga performing in Sydney, and the Australian dollar near parity with the US dollar. The ABC Breakfast program broadcast a 15-second still image of a chicken, but it was unclear if this was due to the power outage. By 10am AEDT, the entire online news front page went dark, but those who visited earlier saw archived homepages. Some users were automatically redirected to a mobile version of the site, which showed up-to-date articles without images and 2011-era fonts. Others saw a version of the site from the early 2010s. The business front page featured the headline "Carbon, mining taxes won't stop investment," while the entertainment page reported that Lady Gaga had surprised Sydney fans with two shows and asked "Oprah to host Oscars?" At 10am AEDT, the front page was entirely down, with an error message stating "WEBSITE OUTAGE. We are currently experiencing a technical outage, which means we are unable to provide our usual service." The Ultimo building was plunged into darkness, and ABC News Mornings host Joe O'Brien and his colleagues prepared their morning briefings in an eerie half-light. ABC Radio National host Matt Bevan shared a video of the ABC's emergency generator in action. By 11am, the front page was back, but in a new format displaying as a giant live blog with stories as individual posts. An hour later, the website was back to normal. The ABC attributed the difficulties to power fluctuations from their supplier overnight, which affected some of their systems. The ABC's website and news app were impacted, and alternative programming was being broadcast on digital radio. Meanwhile, the ABC's TV broadcast, terrestrial radio, and online radio broadcasts continued uninterrupted. Although the front page of the ABC's website was inaccessible, up-to-date news articles remained available online through their URLs or Google search results, although they appeared in the 2011 format.

On Friday, approximately 200 Google employees gathered outside the company's San Francisco office, demanding the reinstatement of two suspended worker activists. By Monday, Rebecca Rivers, one of the suspended workers, had been terminated, with reports suggesting that three other Google employees had also been let go. Rivers, a software engineer, announced her termination on Twitter. According to an internal memo, three other Google employees were fired on Monday, with the company citing "clear and repeated violations of our data security policies" as the reason. The firings sparked immediate allegations of retaliation from current and former Google employees. Meredith Whittaker described Rivers' firing as "craven retaliation" on Twitter, while Stephanie Parker called the terminations "inhumane" and "illegal". Whittaker and another organizer, Claire Stapleton, had previously left Google after alleging they were retaliated against by management. Rivers expressed pride in her actions, stating that everyone has the right to know what their work is used for. The public protest and firings are the latest signs of growing labor unrest at Google, which has seen an increase in employee activism over the past two years. Many employees have been demanding a say in how their work is used and their rights as workers. Google employees have voiced discontent with several projects, including a contract to supply AI technology to the US Department of Defense's drone program, a censored search engine for China, and cloud services to the fossil fuel industry. A notable example of employee dissatisfaction was the walkout by approximately 20,000 employees over the company's handling of sexual harassment cases. Many employees have also spoken out about Google's extensive use of subcontracted workers, who often have fewer rights and benefits than regular employees. A group of worker-organizers published a strongly-worded Medium post on Monday night, expressing outrage at the company's actions. They accused Google of illegal retaliation against employees who are exercising their right to organize, describing it as "classic union busting" and vowing to resist it.

The Fearless Girl statue has transformed into a multifaceted symbol, resonating with many individuals. Commissioned by State Street Global, the 4-foot bronze sculpture was designed to promote a fund supporting companies with diverse gender representation. Overnight in March 2017, the original Fearless Girl materialized in downtown New York, standing opposite the Charging Bull statue near Wall Street. The sculpture rapidly gained popularity, attracting crowds of selfie-takers and becoming a symbol of feminist empowerment. Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren utilized the statue to promote her policies, capitalizing on its widespread appeal. Sculptor Kristen Visbal has since created multiple copies of Fearless Girl, which now stand in cities worldwide. However, State Street took legal action to prevent the Fearless Girl from spreading further, arguing that replicas infringe on its trademark and dilute its message. According to the New York Times, State Street's lawyer claimed that Maurice Blackburn exploited the Fearless Girl campaign to promote itself, sparking controversy. State Street has also sued Visbal for creating other copies, citing trademark violations and attempting to "rob her of making a living from her art." The statue has been a mixed blessing for State Street, elevating its profile but also highlighting its own record on gender equality. In October 2017, State Street paid $5 million to settle charges that it had underpaid approximately 300 women in its employ, further undermining its reputation. State Street had a history of rejecting gender equality proposals at several prominent companies, including Alphabet, American Express, and Bank of America.

Over 40,000 academic staff are set to participate in an eight-day strike starting Monday, protesting pension, pay, and working conditions. The strike will affect over a million students across 60 campuses. The University and College Union accuses universities of using coercive tactics to undermine the strike. Social media is flooded with outrage over universities' attempts to deter students from joining picket lines and reporting striking lecturers.

In February, the largest ever industrial action in UK universities took place, with 14 days of strike action. The strike caused significant disruptions for students, with some calling for compensation.

We want to hear from you about your experiences and opinions on the ongoing strikes. Academic staff, what are the key reasons behind your decision to strike? How do you feel about having to strike for the second time? We're also interested in hearing from international students about how they're being affected. Students, do you support your lecturers' actions? Are you planning to join them on the picket line? Do you think students should receive compensation?

You can share your responses anonymously by filling out the encrypted form below. Only the Guardian will see your responses. Please leave your contact details, as one of our journalists may be in touch to discuss further. If you're having trouble using the form, click here.

This week, 60 UK universities will participate in a strike led by the University and College Union, backed by the National Union of Students. The National Union of Students supports the strike, but not all students agree, with many criticizing the lecturers. Within hours, a petition was launched to demand reimbursement for lost contact hours, as students are concerned about the impact on end-of-term grades. However, frustration is mutual between staff and students, who both feel universities are becoming impersonal and poorly run. Instead of directing anger towards lecturers, we should focus on the institutions forcing them to strike.

Tuition fees aren't solely spent on tutors' salaries; academics' pay has fallen by 17% since 2009. More than half of academics are on temporary contracts, adding to their daily stress and contributing to poor mental health among higher education staff. The UCU reports a 15% gender pay gap and a decline in pensions due to USS changes. Under these conditions, it's unrealistic to expect students to receive the best education.

As NUS vice president Claire Sosienski-Smith noted, "Students won't be happy about missing lectures, but they're not happy about studying in institutions where staff are underpaid and overworked." Lecturers demonstrate a genuine concern for their students' academic well-being. It's a testament to their dedication that they undertake such a demanding role without adequate recognition.

The strike's success hinges on universities recognizing students stand firmly behind their lecturers and acknowledge the need for change. As students, we have a crucial role to play in sustaining these strikes, maintaining pressure for fairer working conditions. I intend to hold my vice-chancellor accountable by asking what measures they're taking to address the issue.

The Bank of England's summer party expenses have reached £96,188, a moderate increase from the £95,673 spent in 2018. The annual event, held at the Bank's sports club in Roehampton, hosted nearly 2,500 staff and their families in July. The costs totaled £84,200, comprising £52,200 on food and soft drinks, £30,000 on family entertainment, and £2,000 for equipment. Bank officials faced questioning from MPs over their expenses, including the summer party bill. Defending the party, Dorothy Thompson stated it was an annual event costing £40 per head, with no alcohol included. The Bank is reviewing its expenses and has already decided to shut its sports ground to cut costs. Incoming governor Andrew Bailey will need to find an alternative venue if the event continues in 2020. The Bank made significant changes to its employee benefits last year, including reducing meal and hotel allowances. The Bank released a statement defending its Governors' Day tradition, aiming to recognize employees' hard work and dedication.

I joined the BBC film directors' training course in 1974, where I met Diarmuid Lawrence, whose influence on me was profound. We collaborated on a scene based on my script, and I was impressed by his remarkable acting abilities. A course instructor made thoughtless remarks about lighting men and women, sparking a heated debate among some male participants, who grew agitated and exclaimed, "Can't we just move forward?" Diarmuid intervened, speaking in a calming and conciliatory tone that dissipated the tension and restored harmony. His exceptional interpersonal skills, evident that day, enabled him to elicit outstanding performances from a diverse range of actors throughout his career, earning their respect and admiration.

Astronomers are puzzled by a series of mysterious radio wave bursts originating from distant parts of the universe. For years, scientists have been fascinated by these sudden, low-frequency radiation events, which release more energy than the sun in a day and disappear instantly. Known as Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs), these enigmatic signals appear randomly and without warning, leaving astronomers uncertain about when or where they will occur next. Over 60 FRBs have been detected, with the only consensus being that they are unlikely to be extraterrestrial greetings. A year ago, scientists identified a repeating radio signal and traced it to a dwarf galaxy 3 billion light-years from Earth. Further observations suggested that the burst was generated by extremely powerful magnetic fields, effectively ruling out the possibility of alien laser signals. A team of astronomers from several Canadian universities has announced the discovery of a second repeating radio signal. The team's breakthrough came after activating the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME) telescope in British Columbia. The findings were published in two papers in Nature and presented at a news conference at the American Astronomical Society meeting in Seattle.

The power struggle at NBCUniversal has commenced. CEO Stephen B. Burke has reshuffled the leadership, appointing Jeff Shell to oversee Hollywood operations and Mark Lazarus to lead the broadcast network, news division, cable networks, and sports group. Bonnie Hammer, 68, will head a new ad-supported streaming service, set to debut next year, which will compete with Disney's and WarnerMedia's upcoming streaming offerings. Insiders speculate that Burke's moves aim to pit Lazarus and Shell against each other for the top role. By doing so, Burke has essentially created an East Coast-West Coast divide, with Lazarus controlling the East Coast offices and Shell overseeing West Coast assets.

Facebook has repeatedly maintained its commitment to transparency and privacy in the face of increasing scrutiny over its handling of consumer data. A recent Pew Research Center study found that nearly three-fourths of Facebook users are unaware that the company collects and shares their personal traits and interests with advertisers. When users discovered this information on their "Ad Preferences" page, half expressed discomfort with the company's data collection. The study, which surveyed 963 American adults with Facebook accounts, suggests that many consumers remain unaware of how their online behavior is tracked and where the data is compiled. The Pew Research Center focused on Facebook due to its significant role in the global media ecosystem. According to Lee Rainie, Americans prioritize privacy as a fundamental value, but their online behavior suggests a disconnect. Rainie hypothesizes that this inconsistency may stem from a lack of understanding about how personal information is harvested and analyzed. The finding that 74% of Facebook users were unaware of the company's data collection practices highlights the need to educate Americans about these systems.

The Federal Trade Commission is nearing the conclusion of its probe into Facebook's compliance with privacy regulations, with insiders predicting substantial penalties will be imposed. The five FTC commissioners convened in mid-December to discuss the investigation, a rare occurrence in the early stages of an inquiry, signifying the investigation's advanced stage. The inquiry, initiated in late March, remains ongoing, with evidence of alleged privacy breaches presented by consumer-protection and enforcement staff. Ultimately, the FTC commissioners will determine the staff's recommendations, including the amount of fines or penalties, although they don't always concur with staff suggestions.

As the sun rose on Monday, a rare and awe-inspiring sight materialized in the night sky: a total lunar eclipse. For those with unimpeded views, the moon transformed into a radiant coppery red hue. This was the sole lunar eclipse of 2019, occurring just before midnight Eastern time. Despite the freezing temperatures in parts of New York City, which might have kept some individuals indoors, the clouds had cleared, offering a faultless view of the eclipse after earlier cloudy obstructions. The eclipse unfolded as Earth intervened between the sun and the moon, casting a shadow over our planet's moon. In contrast, a solar eclipse occurs when the moon blocks the sun's light, precipitating a transition from day to night in certain regions. The lunar eclipse coincided with a supermoon, a rare occurrence when the full moon is at its closest proximity to Earth, known as perigee. Although the supermoon might be barely perceptible to the naked eye, it added an extra layer of exhilaration to the celestial display. The event was dubbed the "super blood wolf moon," a moniker that encapsulated the moon's striking appearance during the eclipse.

Viacom, the former cable giant behind popular shows like "Jersey Shore" and children's programming like "Dora the Explorer," is acquiring PlutoTV, a streaming service, for $340 million. This marks Viacom's most significant foray into streaming, a strategy increasingly popular among media companies as viewers opt out of traditional cable subscriptions. The rise of streaming services like Netflix and Hulu has accelerated the decline of the pay TV industry and upended the media landscape. Time Warner, once the largest media company in the US, was sold to AT&T for $85.4 billion, while Rupert Murdoch's entertainment empire was sold to Disney for $71.3 billion after a bidding war with Comcast. Both deals aimed to create entities capable of competing with Netflix and other tech companies by offering their own streaming services. AT&T and Disney plan to launch their services by the end of the year. Viacom's acquisition of PlutoTV, while smaller in scale, shares a similar motivation. Founded in 2013, PlutoTV is a free, advertising-supported service with around 12 million active viewers per month. NBCUniversal also recently announced plans to launch a streaming service largely reliant on advertising.

Before the rise of Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, people relied on platforms like Open Diary, Blogger, and LiveJournal to share their thoughts. As social media grew in popularity, it became the go-to place for people to share articles, post photos, and express themselves. Despite the emergence of new platforms, Medium has continued to flourish, attracting 90 million unique monthly visitors who engage with open letters, petitions, and personal essays. However, Medium's content rarely sparks intense reactions or controversy. But that changed when Jeff Bezos, Amazon's CEO, accused American Media Inc. of "extortion and blackmail" on the platform, posting a headline that read "No thank you, Mr. Pecker," a reference to David J. Pecker, American Media's chairman.

San Francisco - Technology companies usually don't turn a profit until they go public, but notable exceptions like Twitter, Snap, Spotify, and SurveyMonkey have listed on the stock market despite being unprofitable. As Uber prepares for its initial public offering, the question is whether it can buck the trend and achieve profitability. This is significant because Uber, the most prominent tech startup of its generation, will set the standard for other well-known tech companies like Slack and Lyft. Unfortunately, Uber's profit prospects are concerning, given its recent net loss of $842 million in the fourth quarter of 2018, an 88% increase from the previous year. The losses are attributed to Uber's increased spending as it attempts to outcompete rivals, with the company responding by offering bigger incentives and promotions to fend off competitors like DoorDash, Lyft, and other ride-hailing and food-delivery services.

Pittsburgh's The Post-Gazette has sparked controversy with the appointment of Keith C. Burris as executive editor, following his involvement in the contentious editorial "Reason as Racism" on Martin Luther King's Birthday. Burris assumes the role at a precarious time, as the publication navigates the conflict between its workers' union and owner. On February 9, publisher John R. Block launched into a tirade in the newsroom, threatening employees' jobs while his daughter wept and pleaded with him to stop. Block Communications disputes the journalists' account. As executive editor, Burris will oversee the editorial pages of both The Post-Gazette and The Toledo Blade. In a message to employees, Burris sought support and vowed to work together to uphold the newspaper's legacy and navigate industry challenges. "I ask you to recognize my commitment and implore you to work with me to preserve the Post-Gazette's proud heritage and move forward into a bright future," he wrote. "It won't be easy, as we face uncertain times for journalism, but we owe the Block family a great debt for their support and trust in our mission."

The moment has arrived to add a small, new moon to Neptune's collection of icy satellites, increasing the total count to 14. Astronomers utilizing the Hubble Space Telescope have uncovered a previously unknown satellite orbiting Neptune, a finding published in Nature. This discovery serves as a poignant reminder that there remains much to be uncovered in our own celestial backyard, with far-reaching implications for our understanding of exoplanetary systems. According to Anne Verbiscer, a planetary scientist, "many assume we have a comprehensive understanding of the moons of major planets, but this is not the case. We still have a considerable amount to discover." The ice giants, Uranus and Neptune, remain largely unexplored, unlike every other planet in our solar system. Voyager 2 flew by Neptune 30 years ago, capturing images that revealed rings, six new moons, and its striking blue color, although its visit was limited by the technological constraints of the 1970s.

"Each week, our team of technology experts from The New York Times examines the latest news, offering in-depth analysis and a dash of humor on the most significant tech industry developments. Interested in receiving this newsletter? Simply sign up here. Hello, readers! I'm Nicole Perlroth, a cybersecurity reporter at The Times. Unfortunately, this week's news is marked by a concerning trend. It's no surprise that President Trump's diplomatic approach has reignited state-sponsored hacking in Iran and China. These countries are now targeting US companies and government agencies with renewed intensity, following a multi-year hiatus. This resurgence coincides with the ongoing threat from Russian hackers, who have already begun targeting European civil society groups ahead of May's elections. This is a glimpse into what's to come in 2020. With the US withdrawal from the nuclear deal with Iran, Iranian hackers are launching cyberattacks against American banks, businesses, and federal agencies. Notably, their tactics have become more sophisticated and effective, making them increasingly challenging to track."

The Federal Trade Commission has agreed to a $5.7 million settlement with TikTok over allegations it illegally collected children's personal information. This fine establishes a new benchmark for child privacy violations. The agency found that a significant number of users were under 13 and shared sensitive data, including email addresses, names, and schools. The FTC noted that TikTok failed to obtain parental consent before collecting user data, violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act. When parents requested data deletion, the site refused to comply. Under COPPA, online services must obtain parental permission before collecting data from users under 13. "This record penalty serves as a reminder to online services targeting children: the FTC takes COPPA enforcement seriously and will not tolerate disregard for the law," said Joseph J. Simons, the agency's chairman.

Ten years ago, Google was targeted by a groundbreaking cyberattack orchestrated by the Chinese military, a pivotal moment in US cybercrime history. Chronicle, a security startup owned by Alphabet, is introducing Backstory, a new product that utilizes its massive storage, indexing, and search capabilities to aid companies in investigating malicious attacks. Backstory's concept is simple: it will allow businesses to access and search extensive data archives spanning years to trace the origins of cyberattacks. Unlike other big data threat intelligence market players, many of whom charge excessive prices, making their services inaccessible to smaller businesses.

Slate, a prominent online publication, has appointed Jared Hohlt, a seasoned journalist with 18 years of experience, as its new editor-in-chief. He will take up the role on April 1, succeeding Julia Turner, who left Slate in October to join The Los Angeles Times as a deputy managing editor. Lowen Liu, Slate's former managing editor and deputy editor, has acted as editor-in-chief since Turner's departure. Hohlt held various positions at New York magazine, including editorial director and top editor of the print edition, and led the magazine to win the general excellence award at the National Magazine Awards in 2016. Prior to his departure, he worked under editor-in-chief Adam Moss, who resigned in January after 15 years. Interestingly, Hohlt began his career at Slate as an editorial assistant two decades ago, describing it as a "journalistic training ground" for him.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, there is no known cure for autism spectrum disorder, but medications can alleviate associated symptoms. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that up to a third of parents of children with autism have tried unproven treatments, and up to 10% may be using harmful methods. Two books on Amazon, published over five years ago, have received over 600 customer reviews. One book recommends autistic children ingest and bathe in chlorine dioxide, despite the Food and Drug Administration warning of severe health issues. Representative Adam Schiff criticized Amazon's algorithms for failing to distinguish between credible and misinformation, allowing harmful messages to spread. Schiff urged Amazon to take responsibility and prevent contributing to the growing public health crisis.

The unusual behavior of sun bears, making faces at each other, has profound implications for our comprehension of animal communication. Comparative psychologists have extensively studied primate facial expressions, which convey emotions such as joy and anger. However, the possibility of solitary-living creatures using facial expressions to communicate had not been considered. While researching orangutans in Malaysia, Marina Davila-Ross and her colleagues encountered sun bears in a nearby rehabilitation center. Fascinated by the possibility of widespread facial communication, they set up cameras to capture footage of the bears interacting. According to a study published in Scientific Reports, the bears indeed use facial expressions to communicate, suggesting this ability may be more widespread than thought. The study implies that social creatures are not the only ones capable of expressing themselves through facial expressions.

Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder and CEO, and his wife MacKenzie Bezos announced on Twitter that they have settled their divorce. Under the agreement, Jeff Bezos will retain 75% of their Amazon stock, as well as ownership of The Washington Post and Blue Origin. MacKenzie Bezos will own around 4% of Amazon, valued at approximately $36 billion. This means Jeff Bezos will likely remain the world's richest person, with a remaining stake worth almost $108 billion. For comparison, Bill Gates has a net worth of $102 billion. Experts predicted MacKenzie Bezos was entitled to roughly half of the couple's assets under Washington State law. The couple has investments and properties across the United States. The terms of their divorce settlement remain private, but it's possible the agreement includes other forms of compensation for MacKenzie Bezos.

As the Earth orbits the sun, it encounters cosmic debris throughout the year, resulting in breathtaking meteor showers that light up the night sky from dusk till dawn. One notable upcoming shower is the Lyrids, active from April 16 to 28, with its peak on Sunday night into Monday morning, although the moon may obstruct viewing this year. Chinese astronomers meticulously recorded their observations of these bursts of light, dating back over 2,700 years. Lyrid meteorites blaze across the sky at approximately 107,000 miles per hour, exploding about 55 miles up in the atmosphere. The Lyrids shower originates from Comet Thatcher, which takes 415 years to complete its orbit around the sun. Comet Thatcher's last visit was in 1861, and its next approach will be in 2276. Meteor showers often result from icy comets' remnants colliding with Earth's atmosphere, where small particles of debris pierce the sky at incredible speeds, creating a dazzling display of celestial fireworks. Comets are essentially dirty snowballs that leave behind a trail of rocks and ice as they traverse the solar system, and this dusty trail lingers in space, awaiting Earth's encounter.

Facebook is about to face an investigation by the New York State attorney general's office into its unauthorized collection of over 1.5 million users' email address books. The probe focuses on a practice discovered in April, where Facebook gathered the email contact lists of new users who signed up for the platform after 2016. These lists were used to improve Facebook's ad-targeting algorithms and other social connections across the network. The investigation was officially confirmed by the attorney general's office late Thursday afternoon. "Facebook has consistently disregarded consumers' privacy while profiting from exploiting their personal data," said New York Attorney General Letitia James in a statement. "It's time Facebook is held accountable for its handling of consumers' personal information."

While some parasites are infamous for their harmful effects, others play a crucial role in their ecosystems. For instance, the fungus Cordyceps controls ants to sacrifice themselves, whereas Toxoplasma gondii eliminates a mouse's fear of cats. In contrast, the Sacculina carcini barnacle adopts a drastic approach, rendering crabs infertile and transforming them into "zombie" slaves that care for its young.

In a surprising turn, some parasites can even benefit their hosts. In eastern North America, wood-eating beetles infected with a parasitic worm exhibit insides resembling a plate of moving spaghetti. Despite this, the infected beetles tend to be larger and consume more than their uninfected counterparts, according to a recent study published in Biology Letters. This increased consumption may actually facilitate the forest's nutrient cycle more efficiently, benefiting the entire ecosystem.

The study's lead researcher, Andy Davis, an ecologist at the University of Georgia, notes that everything is interconnected in the natural world. "Here's a case where a small insect in the forest is doing something important, and then there's another insect that lives inside that insect that's doing something important too," he says.

James Bennet, editorial page editor of The New York Times, has decided to recuse himself from covering the 2020 presidential election following his brother Michael Bennet's (D-Colo.) candidacy announcement. This move is anticipated, given James Bennet's likely succession to Dean Baquet as executive editor. With over a decade of experience in the Senate, Michael Bennet had previously expressed interest in a presidential bid. It's unusual for a newspaper's Opinion section head to disengage from a dominant topic. James Bennet's moratorium applies to all opinion pieces, including op-eds, columns, editorials, and articles on presidential candidates or campaign issues. The Times has appointed Kathleen Kingsbury and James Dao to share responsibilities for political coverage, which will remain in place as long as Michael Bennet remains a candidate.

Throughout the year, Earth's orbit around the sun brings it into contact with cosmic debris, resulting in spectacular meteor showers that illuminate the night sky from dusk to dawn. The next notable shower is the Eta Aquariids, active from April 19 to May 28, with a peak around May 5-6. As the moon approaches new, clear skies could provide optimal viewing conditions for the Eta Aquariids, one of two meteor showers linked to Halley's comet. With its exceptional speed of approximately 148,000 miles per hour, the Eta Aquariids are one of the fastest meteor showers, more prominent in the Southern Hemisphere. In contrast, the Northern Hemisphere tends to see about half as many meteors per hour during the peak. When you spot a meteor shower, you're witnessing the remnants of an icy comet colliding with Earth's atmosphere, leaving behind a trail of rocky and icy debris. Comets, often referred to as "dirty snowballs," leave behind a trail of debris as they travel through the solar system, and when Earth encounters these cascades, small particles enter the atmosphere at incredible speeds, producing a breathtaking celestial display.

A report warns that climate change and rising sea levels pose a significant threat to the world's last and largest tiger habitats. The study highlights that nearly 500,000 land species are at risk of extinction due to habitat destruction. The Sundarbans, a 4,000-square-mile region in Bangladesh and India, is home to the world's largest mangrove forest and a diverse ecosystem that supports hundreds of animal species, including the endangered Bengal tiger. However, 70% of the region is only a few feet above sea level, making it extremely vulnerable to climate change impacts. Researchers predict that the warming planet will decimate the few hundred Bengal tigers remaining in the region. By 2070, the study concludes that there will be no suitable tiger habitats remaining in the Bangladesh Sundarbans. Climate change has already had a devastating impact on endangered mammals, with a recent study finding that it has harmed almost half of them. The new report's lead author and colleagues examined the risks to the tiger population beyond sea level rise, which accounted for only 5.4-11.3% of the projected habitat loss in 2050 and 2070. They found that other climate-related factors were more significant threats to the Sundarbans' tigers. Habitat loss, hunting, and the illegal trade of animal parts have contributed to the global tiger population decline since the early 1900s. The Bangladesh Sundarbans will likely experience a decline in its population due to an increase in extreme weather events and changes in vegetation. As the Sundarbans flood, the likelihood of conflicts between humans and tigers will rise. The situation could worsen significantly if a cyclone hits, a disease outbreak occurs, or a food shortage develops. If greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise at their current rate, the Earth's atmosphere will warm by as much as 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit above preindustrial levels by 2040.

Imagine a creature with dinosaur-like features, and you might not picture a bat. But a team of Chinese paleontologists has made a stunning discovery that could change your perspective. They've unearthed a dinosaur, Ambopteryx longibrachium, with fleshy wings like a bat's, dating back around 163 million years. Initially, paleontologist Min Wang thought it was a bird due to its long forelimbs, a trait shared by modern birds. However, as his team excavated the fossil over a year, distinctly dinosaurian characteristics emerged, including long fingers that are unique to dinosaurs.

About 50 years ago, astronauts on the Apollo mission placed temporary seismometers on the lunar surface, uncovering a surprisingly dynamic moon with various quake types. Some quakes were likely caused by Earth's gravitational pull, while others were triggered by meteorite impacts or temperature-driven surface expansion and contraction every two weeks. Shallow moonquakes occurring just a few miles beneath the surface remained unexplained until a recent study in Nature Geoscience attributed them to a combination of internal heat escape and Earth's gravitational pull, triggering movements along numerous young faults. This discovery implies that the moon is still tectonically active, raising concerns about shallow moonquakes at future lunar bases and sparking questions about the moon's evolution, particularly given its small size and assumption of internal heat escape. Despite its small size, the moon's internal heat appears to still be driving geological activity, contradicting expectations.

Conde Nast has divested Golf Digest to Discovery Inc. in a move to streamline its portfolio amidst financial difficulties. The reported sale price is $35 million, but the terms of the deal remain confidential. Discovery plans to maintain Golf Digest's editorial team, including Editor-in-Chief Jerry Tarde, and will continue publishing the print magazine. Tarde will oversee the global strategy and content for Discovery Golf, encompassing GolfTV, a digital platform broadcasting live professional golf tournaments globally. Tarde expressed enthusiasm about the partnership, highlighting the benefits of Discovery's global reach and platform distribution, combined with the PGA Tour's brand, for golf enthusiasts worldwide.

If you've ever taken a large bite of wasabi, you're acquainted with the intense, spreading sensation that seeps into your scalp. You're not the only one who's distressed - many animals share your aversion to the spicy condiment. The culprit behind wasabi's sinus-clearing properties is a chemical compound called allyl isothiocyanate, which actively disrupts proteins within cells. Flies, flatworms, mice, and wolf spiders all shun this compound, and nearly every animal will do the same. However, there is one notable exception: the highveld mole rat, a rodent native to South Africa, is completely immune to the substance. A recent study published in Science showcased the rodent's remarkable resistance to allyl isothiocyanate. The findings highlight the significance of studying naturally occurring differences in pain sensitivity, and may ultimately lead to more effective pain treatment in humans.

The House has recently approved a retirement bill with a broad bipartisan consensus, encompassing a range of provisions that will affect various groups of American savers and retirees. The legislation introduces several key modifications, with one notable aspect permitting employers to offer intricate annuity products within their retirement plans. The bill's notable changes include:

* Allowing workers to contribute to individual retirement accounts without age limitations, rather than being restricted to age 70 1/2.
* Increasing the age at which individuals must initiate withdrawals from their Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs) to 72, up from 70 1/2.
* Permitting penalty-free withdrawals from retirement plans to cover expenses related to the birth or adoption of a child.

Jeffrey Goldberg, editor-in-chief of The Atlantic, faced backlash after admitting it's difficult to assign cover stories to writers outside of white males. In a Nieman Lab interview, Goldberg revealed that writing a 10,000-word cover story is a daunting task, and only a select group of white male journalists possess the necessary skills, perpetuating a narrow definition of excellence. Of The Atlantic's 15 most recent cover stories, 11 were written by men, further highlighting the issue. Goldberg proposed identifying and mentoring new writers, but acknowledged that this approach may not always yield successful results, potentially reinforcing existing biases. His comments sparked widespread criticism, with many accusing him of undervaluing underrepresented writers. The article's length sparked a lively Twitter discussion, with journalists chiming in. Margaret Sullivan humorously shared her own writing limitations, saying she aspires to write 1,200 words but tops out at 850. Andi Zeisler quipped, "Has anyone informed Jeffrey Goldberg about women who write books?"

Mitchel R. Levitas, a renowned journalist, died at his home in New Marlborough, Massachusetts, on Saturday at the age of 89, succumbing to Alzheimer's disease complicated by pneumonia, according to his son Daniel. Levitas held prominent roles at The New York Times for nearly four decades, overseeing metropolitan coverage and editing various sections. Born and raised in New York City, Levitas graduated from the city's public schools and colleges before joining The New York Times in 1965 as a writer and editor. He retired in 2002 after 37 years, having served as editorial director of book development. Levitas continued working as a consultant for the book development office until 2014. Known to colleagues as Mike, Levitas was a precise editor with a sharp eye for detail. As an assistant metropolitan editor, he played a crucial role in assigning a reporter to investigate the authenticity of "The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano."

CBS's "Late Show with Stephen Colbert" is a highly successful program on the network. Despite extended negotiations, CBS and AT&T failed to reach a contract agreement by the Saturday deadline. As a result, CBS went dark for over 6.5 million AT&T customers early Saturday morning, impacting its satellite service DirecTV, landline-delivered U-verse, and live streaming product DirecTV Now. The blackout affected customers in at least 14 major markets, including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, and San Francisco. The network, carried in approximately 119 million homes across the country, lost tens of millions of dollars in monthly revenue. CBS and AT&T have been at odds over pricing and streaming rights, with CBS refusing to agree to terms that would devalue its popular programming. AT&T accused CBS of being a repeat blackout offender and demanded a more reasonable fee structure. CBS seeks an increase in retransmission consent fees, last negotiated in 2012. While CBS is available for free over the air, it also sells its rights to pay-TV operators like AT&T. According to sources, CBS received $2 per AT&T subscriber monthly and now seeks a fee in the range of $3.

On July 21, 1969, at 2:56 a.m. Coordinated Universal Time, a historic milestone was reached as humans successfully landed on another planet for the first time. This extraordinary event captivated millions worldwide, who watched live on television and listened on the radio. As people gazed up at the moon and their own Earth, a shared perspective emerged. For most people alive today, the Apollo 11 mission is a nostalgic memory, predating their birth. Even for those who recall the event, it's easy to overlook that the Apollo program unfolded during a tumultuous period in American history, when many Americans prioritized other pressing issues over space exploration. Despite skepticism, the mission's success became synonymous with humanity's potential, inspiring the notion that if we could put a man on the moon, we could accomplish anything. To commemorate this complex history and The New York Times' coverage, the science desk has been publishing a series of articles, essays, photo galleries, and a poem throughout the month, reflecting on the legacy of Apollo 11 and the promise and challenges of a new era of space exploration.

San Francisco - Food delivery startup DoorDash announced its acquisition of Caviar, a rival service, for $410 million, escalating the competitive food delivery landscape. DoorDash is purchasing Caviar from Square, a payments company that has owned it since 2014. Caviar operates in 15 cities, primarily offering upscale restaurant food in urban areas. According to DoorDash CEO Tony Xu, Caviar's selection of higher-end restaurants in cities complements DoorDash's offerings, which focus on chain restaurants in suburban areas. Xu described his conversation with Square's CEO Jack Dorsey about the potential deal as brief. The food delivery market has become increasingly competitive, with DoorDash, Postmates, GrubHub, and Uber Eats vying for customers, drivers, and restaurant clients. The intense competition has been fueled by Uber's initial public offering in May and the potential IPO of Postmates, which filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission in February.

Sponges, categorized as poriferans, are characterized by their soft, sedentary nature and numerous pores. Comb jellies, also referred to as ctenophores, are gelatinous, feathery organisms with cilia resembling combs. Scientists have been engaged in a long-standing debate about the closest relative to the first animal to evolve. The most recent analysis suggests that sponges are the closest living relatives of the earliest animal, although this conclusion may be subject to dispute. All animals, from sponges and comb jellies to humans and other mammals, share fundamental characteristics such as multicellularity, nucleated cells, and the ability to consume food. All animals are descended from a common ocean-dwelling ancestor that lived at least 550 million years ago and shared these characteristics. The appearance and lifestyle of the first animal remain unclear. To comprehend the origins of the animal kingdom, researchers examine existing species to infer the common ancestor's characteristics. By comparing modern animals, we can reconstruct what the ancestor was like, including its complexity, genes, and traits.

"Stay up to date with space and astronomy events by setting calendar reminders. Witness a meteor shower by observing the remnants of a comet's icy trail as it enters Earth's atmosphere. Comets are composed of dirty snowballs that release rocks and ice as they travel through the solar system, leaving a lingering trail. When Earth encounters this trail, small particles burn up, creating a spectacular display. Note that you're seeing the remnants of the comet's previous passes, not its most recent orbit. For the best view, find a spot with a clear view of the night sky, ideally with dark skies, away from city lights and traffic. Look for a spot with a wide, unobstructed view to maximize your chances of spotting the show. Meteor showers are typically visible for a set period, peaking in visibility from dusk to dawn on specific days. Peak times vary, with some lasting only a few hours and others several nights. The showers tend to be most visible after midnight and before dawn. For the best viewing experience, use your naked eye. When using binoculars or telescopes, spend around 30 minutes in the dark to adjust your eyes. Be aware that moonlight and inclement weather can sometimes obscure celestial events. If this happens, consider alternative options like NASA and Slooh's meteor livestreams."

In 1995, WNYC, New York's public radio station, had a new boss, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in office, and a monthly audience of approximately one million listeners and an operating budget of $8 million. Since then, New York Public Radio, WNYC's parent organization, has grown to become a prominent public media entity, boasting a budget of $97 million, nationally syndicated radio programs, and popular podcasts. The organization claims its various broadcast and online platforms now attract 24 million people. After nearly a quarter-century, New York Public Radio has welcomed a new leader. The nonprofit group announced on Wednesday that Goli Sheikholeslami, who has led Chicago Public Media and WBEZ since 2014, and has held executive positions at The Washington Post and Conde Nast, will become the organization's new chief executive. She is set to start her new role in New York in October.

Google has settled a dispute with the National Labor Relations Board over allegations that it stifled employee dissent, including the alleged termination of a conservative worker who spoke out. As part of the agreement, Google will educate employees on their federal rights, including the freedom to discuss workplace conditions, and ensure they won't face retaliation for exercising those rights. The company will post a notice reminding employees of their National Labor Relations Act rights and clarifying that workplace policies do not prohibit discussing issues. The settlement is pending NLRB approval, with a regional director already expressing her approval.

Enhanced radar technology may create the illusion of increased insect populations, whether it's a ladybug swarm in California or a massive hoverfly gathering in England. On Monday, National Weather Service meteorologist Doug Kahn in Cleveland observed multiple blue masses moving and expanding on the radar over Ohio, which were not storm clouds or a weather system, but a massive dragonfly swarm. Kahn estimated there were millions of dragonflies, explaining why they were so prominent on the radar. The National Weather Service's dual-polarization radar generates a three-dimensional-like image of the atmosphere, scanning horizontally and vertically to measure dimensions and identify airborne entities before they become visible to the naked eye.

"Game of Thrones" has secured the most Emmy wins for a drama series in television history, a surprising outcome given its final season. The HBO fantasy epic dominated the Creative Arts Emmy Awards, claiming a record 10 awards, the most for any series at the Primetime Emmys' opening ceremonies. HBO's limited series "Chernobyl" also had a successful night, taking home seven Creative Arts Emmys. Amazon's "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel" won six awards, including honors for guest acting by Jane Lynch and Luke Kirby. In the drama guest acting categories, Cherry Jones and Bradley Whitford took home awards for their roles in Hulu's "The Handmaid's Tale". The 71st Primetime Emmy Awards honored winners in nearly 100 categories over two ceremonies, recognizing achievements in technical areas, guest acting, and other categories.

A lightning strike's typical impact is considerable, but superbolts are a unique phenomenon. Initially detected in the 1970s by satellites designed to monitor nuclear explosions, these extraordinary lightning events are thousands of times more energetic than regular lightning. Despite their extraordinary nature, the probability of being struck by a superbolt is extremely low. Scientists examined data from the World Wide Lightning Location Network's 80 sensors to gain a deeper understanding of where these powerful lightning strikes occur. Their findings, published in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, revealed that superbolts primarily occur over open water from November to February. Dr. Robert Holzworth and his team analyzed over 1.7 billion radio-frequency observations of lightning, focusing on the most robust detections from 2010 to 2018. They identified 8,171 superbolts with energies exceeding one million Joules, which accounts for only 0.0005 percent of the total lightning recorded by the network. Superbolts are so rare that even Dr. Holzworth, a renowned expert in the field, has never witnessed one firsthand.

Apple is venturing into the film industry with three movies set to debut this fall. The company's foray into film was made possible after acquiring the movies earlier this year. Apple aims to expand its film efforts in 2020, producing its own movies, including co-productions with independent studio A24, known for critically acclaimed films like "Moonlight" and "Lady Bird". The partnership between Apple and A24 was formed last year.

The first film to be released is "Elephant Queen", a documentary narrated by Chiwetel Ejiofor, showcasing a 50-year-old elephant. It will premiere in select cities on October 18 and become available on Apple TV+ on November 1. The second movie, "Hala", is a coming-of-age drama starring Geraldine Viswanathan as a Muslim teenager. It will be released in select theaters on November 22 and debut on Apple TV+ in December. Apple acquired "Hala" after its debut at the Sundance Film Festival in February.

A Manhattan federal judge dismissed the lawsuit on Monday. Judge J. Paul Oetken's ruling stated that the court acknowledged the SALT cap as a distinct provision, but the states failed to demonstrate that it exceeded Congress's authority to impose taxes. The lawsuit was joined by New Jersey, Connecticut, and Maryland. The 2017 tax law introduced a cap on state and local tax deductions to offset the cost of trillions of dollars in tax cuts. The cap and related provisions are expected to generate nearly $700 billion in revenue over the next decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. Independent analyses suggest that most residents in high-tax states received a modest tax cut under the 2017 law. Other provisions of the law, such as reduced marginal tax rates, offset the loss of the deduction for many families. The state and local tax issue poses a challenge for Democrats seeking to restore a tax break primarily benefiting high-income earners. Prior to the cap's implementation, households earning $200,000 or more accounted for roughly half of the nearly $600 billion in state and local tax payments deducted on federal tax returns. Democrats argue that the SALT cap unfairly penalizes states with progressive tax policies, making state and local taxes more expensive for residents. This could hinder states' ability to raise taxes, particularly on wealthy residents, and increase pressure to cut spending. The four states claimed that the SALT cap constitutes an impermissible attempt by the federal government to influence certain states' tax policies.

Julia Sigwart, an evolutionary biologist from Queen's University Belfast, connects the chiton's ball-rolling behavior to a desire to explore new territories. This behavior has its roots in the ancient trilobites, which went extinct around 500 million years ago. These ancient creatures curled up for protection, and the chiton, their modern equivalent, shares this ability. Despite its appearance, which resembles a flattened piece of shrimp nigiri, the chiton is a marine mollusk that clings to tidepool rocks. Like trilobites, several animals, including three-banded armadillos, pill bugs, and hedgehogs, can also roll into balls. Many scientists previously believed that conglobation was a defense mechanism against predators, but Dr. Sigwart disputes this assumption. In lab experiments, Dr. Sigwart found that chitons roll into balls to regain their footing after losing it. Her research suggests that chitons can make decisions and may be more intelligent than previously thought.

We usually acquire smartphone typing skills through experimentation, as there is no universally accepted method. Unlike typing on a typewriter or computer, where established techniques exist, smartphone typing lacks a standardized approach. A recent study involving 37,000 participants discovered that a specific technique - using two thumbs and relying on autocorrect while avoiding predictive text - yields faster typing. According to Per Ola Kristensson, this technique is crucial for quick typing. The study, presented at a human-computer interaction conference in Taipei, focused on the Qwerty keyboard, originally designed to prevent mechanical jams in typewriters. Despite questions about its relevance and the emergence of alternative layouts, the Qwerty layout remains widely used.

James Murdoch, former CEO of 21st Century Fox, has acquired a minority stake in Vice Media, targeting millennials through his holding company, Lupa Systems. The investment was made as part of Vice's Refinery29 acquisition, according to a source familiar with the matter. The Financial Times first reported the deal. After leaving 21st Century Fox, which his father Rupert Murdoch founded, James Murdoch established Lupa Systems. The Murdoch family sold Fox's majority assets to Disney for over $70 billion, with James receiving a $2 billion payout. Since then, he has invested in various media businesses, departing from his father's ventures. He has shown less enthusiasm for traditional news ventures, the source noted.

Uber has made a significant investment in Cornershop, a grocery delivery startup, to boost its food delivery capabilities. This acquisition marks a major departure for the company, which is seeking to expand its scope beyond its core ride-hailing service following a rocky IPO in May. Despite a slowdown in its core business, Uber is prioritizing the growth of its food and freight delivery services, as well as exploring new markets like bicycle and scooter rentals. Cornershop, operating in Chile, Mexico, Peru, and Canada, will be integrated into Uber's platform, with plans to expand into additional markets, including the United States. We're excited to partner with Cornershop and look forward to bringing grocery delivery to millions of consumers on the Uber platform, said Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber's CEO.

Lyft's CEO Logan Green announced significant progress towards achieving profitability, with the company on track to reach this goal by late 2021, excluding certain expenses. Executives reaffirmed their commitment to operating profitability during the latest earnings call. Lyft's shift towards profitability comes as its losses were primarily driven by stock-based compensation costs and payroll tax expenses. Excluding these costs, the company's operating loss was $121.6 million for the quarter, a less severe outcome than Wall Street estimates. Lyft's stock surged 1.5 percent in after-hours trading on Wednesday. CFO Brian Roberts attributed the company's strong revenue performance, stating, "We significantly exceeded revenue expectations." Roberts emphasized Lyft's dedication to achieving profitability by a specific date, a rare approach in the industry. Earlier this year, Lyft had predicted record losses as it prioritized growth, but the company has since adjusted its strategy in response to a shift in sentiment towards prominent tech startups.

The decision to leave the publication must have been a difficult one, given the challenging job market in the industry. Newspapers have been struggling for over a decade, particularly in small towns and midsize cities, and digital news outlets that emerged in their wake have also shown signs of strain. In a text message, Ms. McKinney stated, "I no longer believe this company supports its writers," citing the deletion of a post acknowledging reader complaints about auto-playing ads as evidence. Investigative reporter Diana Moskovitz announced on Twitter that she had given her two weeks' notice, stating, "The events of today and everything that led up to them are among the reasons I decided to move on." G/O Media maintains that Deadspin is free to cover topics that may seem unrelated to sports, as long as there is a sports-related angle. Following the mass exodus, the company released a statement, saying, "They resigned and we're sorry they couldn't work within our broad coverage mandate. We're excited about Deadspin's future and will have important updates in the coming days." Deadspin has been without a full-time top editor since August, when Editor-in-Chief Megan Greenwell resigned due to undue interference from management. Greenwell is now a columnist at The New York Times. One of Deadspin's notable investigative reports was a 2013 story revealing that the feel-good story about Notre Dame star linebacker Manti Te'o was fabricated, including the claim that his long-distance girlfriend had died in a car accident. Deadspin was sold to Univision in 2016 after being acquired by Gawker Media, which was subsequently sold following a $140 million judgment against Gawker in an invasion-of-privacy lawsuit backed by Peter Thiel, a Silicon Valley billionaire.

Recent hurricanes, including Katrina, Harvey, Maria, and Dorian, have resulted in thousands of fatalities and billions of dollars in devastation. Despite the limited historical record spanning just over a century, researchers have compiled a 1,500-year history of hurricanes in the Bahamas, revealing significant variations in activity over time. Compared to historical peaks, recent activity in the Bahamas is relatively subdued, except in other parts of the Atlantic. Scientists attribute these fluctuations to changes in atmospheric and oceanic circulation, as well as volcanic activity. The destruction caused by Hurricane Dorian has served as a "wake-up call" for researchers, emphasizing the need for a deeper understanding of hurricane patterns and processes within the context of long-term history. Blue holes, formed when carbonate rock erodes and collapses, are renowned for their deep, crystal-clear waters and serve as valuable depositories of scientific data. Hurricanes deposit coarse materials such as sand, gravel, shells, and coral fragments into these holes, making them crucial keepers of the historical record.

Xerox's reputation as a photocopying and printing leader has been mirrored by HP, which is now a potential partner in a merger. The proposed deal follows informal discussions about a potential business combination. HP will carefully weigh its options, taking a deliberate and disciplined approach to ensure the best interests of all shareholders are served. A merger would unite two former industry leaders that have navigated significant challenges in recent years, including declining demand for printed documents and ink.

Facebook is launching a data portability tool in Ireland, allowing users to export photos and videos from Facebook to Google Photos. This move is a response to European data protection regulations and criticism of Facebook's control over user data. Critics contend that the initiative falls short, citing Facebook's continued dominance and the competitive disadvantage it creates for rivals. Facebook's historical stranglehold has made it difficult for users to switch platforms due to the complexity of data transfer. Authorities are weighing the potential benefits of enabling companies to let users take their content and data to other services, fostering greater competition.

During the Cretaceous period, the tooth fairy would have been overwhelmed with dinosaur teeth. Unlike humans, who lose only one set of teeth, dinosaurs frequently shed tens or hundreds of sets due to their unique dental habits. Herbivorous dinosaurs, which needed to chew through tough plant material, often replaced their teeth frequently. However, researchers were surprised to discover that a carnivorous dinosaur replaced its teeth even more frequently than some herbivores. The dinosaur's habit of chewing on its prey's bones may have contributed to its rapid tooth replacement rate, scientists hypothesized. The findings were published in the journal PLoS One and focused on several meat-eating dinosaurs, with Majungasaurus crenatissimus emerging as the star of the study. This 20-foot-long apex predator, which lived on Madagascar around 70 million years ago, left behind a remarkable fossil record, including several complete skeletons, hundreds of fragmentary skeletons, and tens of thousands of shed teeth. "This is quite unusual," said Michael D. D'Emic, a vertebrate paleontologist at Adelphi University, who led the study.

For centuries, scientists have puzzled over the mystery: despite the scarcity of nutrients, tropical waters remain remarkably transparent. However, coral reefs flourish, supporting a staggering quarter of all known species on Earth. The key to this paradox lies partly with sugar. We often assume the ocean is salty, but it also contains microscopic particles of sugars and carbohydrates, known as dissolved organic matter. This dissolved substance accounts for most of the ocean's organic material and is particularly abundant near coral reefs. "Consider all these sugars dissolved in the ocean," said Michelle Achlatis, a researcher at the California Academy of Sciences. "If no one can utilize them, they might as well not exist." This filter-feeding sponge, found on coral reefs in the Indian and Pacific Oceans, extracts tiny plankton as it floats in the water, using its filtering cells to draw sugars from the seawater.

Initially, it's apparent that this new job is not the panacea people had envisioned. Rather than offering a safer alternative to the mine, it presents a fundamentally distinct type of employment. Although the mine was hazardous, it provided secure employment with benefits. In contrast, the warehouse job is precarious, lacking benefits, a full-time contract, and guarantees of a pension, sick pay, or holiday pay. Furthermore, workers are compensated at or below the minimum wage. A government inquiry into the warehouse's practices several years ago uncovered alarming instances of employees being penalized for taking breaks, including a woman who was so fearful of job loss that she gave birth in the warehouse and left her newborn in a bathroom.

Uber is nearing a deal to sell its Indian food delivery arm, Uber Eats, to Zomato for $400 million. The proposed sale aims to reduce losses and is part of the company's efforts to streamline operations and demonstrate profitability to investors. CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has been working to divest money-losing ventures, including Uber Eats' Indian business, to clean up the company's balance sheet and appease investors.

A new California state law, aimed at improving working conditions for contractors at companies like Uber and Lyft, has inadvertently led to the loss of regular writing assignments for over 200 bloggers in the state. As a result, Vox Media has announced the immediate elimination of 200 freelance positions at its sports outlet, SB Nation. The affected writers are regular contributors to 25 SB Nation blogs focused on California teams, including Golden State of Mind, Conquest Chronicles, and True Blue LA. Many of these writers have been producing dozens of posts annually for minimal compensation, according to a related lawsuit. The law, set to take effect on January 1, poses a significant challenge for SB Nation, as it restricts contractors from submitting more than 35 written content pieces per year.

To share a specific album with a family group, begin by selecting and organizing the desired photos into that album. If automatic backups are enabled on your device, the photos are already stored in your Google Account's online storage. Alternatively, manually upload the selected photos you want to share online. To add photos from a computer folder, log in to the website, either drag the images into the browser window or click the Upload button and navigate to the folder.

The fate of ABC's "Roseanne" reboot remains uncertain, stirring controversy before its revival. At a press event in Pasadena, California, Roseanne Barr faced repeated questions about her stance on President Trump and that of her character, just two months ahead of the show's revival. While Barr clarified she wasn't a Trump supporter, she argued her character's stance in the reboot reflected the nation's deep divisions. "I've always strived to portray a genuine representation of our society," Barr said. "Half the country voted for him, half didn't. This is a realistic portrayal of our nation's deep divisions."

Actress and activist Rose McGowan is set to star in a documentary series called "Citizen Rose", which premieres on E! later this month, offering an unfiltered look into her life. The series will debut with a two-hour episode on January 30 and continue with four more installments in the spring. McGowan became involved in September after a New York Times story revealed her settlement agreement with Harvey Weinstein, whom she accused of sexual assault. Executive producer Andrea Metz was convinced by McGowan's pitch, which she recalled as "It'll be worth it, I promise." Filming began in September and will incorporate footage recorded by McGowan over the past three years. As the #MeToo movement gained momentum, McGowan became a prominent voice advocating for women who have been victims of sexual harassment and abuse. She has publicly condemned men accused of sexual misconduct and criticized those who have not been outspoken enough. McGowan's online following, known as the #RoseArmy, has grown significantly since the Weinstein scandal broke. In a recent Twitter rant, McGowan criticized what she saw as "Hollywood fakery" during the Golden Globes ceremony.
