Asian companies such as Alibaba and SoftBank have committed to creating thousands of new US jobs. In February, Intel, the world's leading computer chip manufacturer, announced a $7 billion investment to complete a factory in Arizona, which is expected to generate 3,000 new jobs.

As Tom Price, Secretary of Health and Human Services, entered the West Virginia State Capitol in Charleston on Tuesday, Dan Heyman, a reporter from the Public News Service, trailed behind him in the hallway, eager to ask about the healthcare legislation passed by the House last week. Heyman reached past staff and security members to ask his questions, recording audio with his Android smartphone. He asked if domestic violence would be considered a pre-existing condition under the new legislation, saying "Do you think that's right, or not?" twice, and then "You refuse to answer? Tell me no comment." As Heyman persisted, a man's voice is heard saying, "Do not get close to her. Back up." After nearly a minute, Heyman was pulled aside by West Virginia Capitol Police, handcuffed, and charged with a misdemeanor count of willful disruption of governmental processes. He spent eight hours in a local jail before being released after the news service posted a $5,000 bail. The arrest sparked suspicions that officers were trying to silence Heyman's efforts to ask questions. Heyman's lawyer described the case as "highly unusual" and said, "I've never had a client get arrested for talking too loud or anything similar to that." The American Civil Liberties Union of West Virginia condemned the arrest, calling it a "blatant attempt to suppress an independent and free press." The organization demanded that the charges against him be dropped immediately, describing them as "outrageous." In a separate statement, Heyman expressed his doubts about whether the security officials intentionally tried to block him, but noted that their actions were consistent with a broader pattern of hostility towards the press.

San Francisco - Waymo, the autonomous driving unit of Alphabet, has partnered with ride-hailing company Lyft to accelerate the development of self-driving vehicles. The partnership aims to bring autonomous vehicle technology to the mainstream through pilot projects and product development efforts. Lyft confirmed the deal, stating that collaborating with Waymo will accelerate their shared vision of improving lives through transportation. The partnership highlights the dynamic nature of relationships in the self-driving car sector, where numerous companies are forming alliances to gain an edge in the market. The deal has significant implications for Uber, the world's largest ride-hailing company, which has faced recent challenges. Lyft, the second-largest ride-hailing service in the US, and Waymo are bitter rivals, competing in the development of autonomous car technology. Waymo is involved in a lawsuit over alleged trade secret theft with Uber. Details about the deal between Waymo and Lyft remain scarce, with the companies declining to comment on specific products or timelines. The partnership offers Lyft a new entry point into the market, as the company has previously stated it will not develop its own self-driving car technology. General Motors acquired Cruise Automation, a self-driving technology startup, for over $1 billion in cash and stock last year, and Cruise has since started testing GM vehicles on public roads in California.

MSNBC's "Morning Joe" hosts Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski claimed on Monday that White House counselor Kellyanne Conway had privately disparaged President Trump before his election. Brzezinski alleged that Conway would criticize Trump in private after publicly endorsing him on TV. Scarborough echoed Brzezinski's statements, saying Conway told them she only accepted the job for the paycheck and would soon be done defending Trump. Brzezinski mockingly quoted Conway as saying, "But first, I have to take a shower, because it feels so dirty to be saying what I'm saying." Conway denied the claims, calling them "absurd" and "not true." Conway initially worked for a super PAC supporting Ted Cruz's presidential campaign, but joined the Trump campaign after Cruz dropped out. She became Trump's campaign manager in August and frequently appeared on TV in support of him. Brzezinski stopped booking Conway on the show in February, citing concerns she would spread misinformation. Last week, Brzezinski renewed her criticism, calling Conway "not credible" and criticizing CNN for featuring her. Conway has faced intense media criticism since she defended the White House's claims about President Trump's inauguration crowd. A recent clip of Anderson Cooper reacting with disdain to her comments drew widespread attention, prompting Conway to label the reaction "possibly sexist" and attribute it to an anti-Trump bias in the media. Despite having a cordial relationship with President Trump in the past, the "Morning Joe" hosts have increasingly criticized him in recent months. President Trump has stated that he no longer watches the network in response.

Fox News has filed a court motion seeking discipline for lawyer Judd Burstein, who allegedly failed to verify basic facts in a lawsuit accusing the network of using fake Twitter accounts to harass a former host. Lawyers for Fox News and its top executives accused Burstein of making "outrageously and flagrantly" false claims on behalf of his client, former Fox News host Andrea Tantaros. Tantaros claims that Twitter posts from fake accounts, known as "sock-puppet" accounts, were part of a concerted effort to silence her after she reported sexual harassment by Roger E. Ailes, a network founder who resigned as chairman and CEO last summer. Ailes passed away this month. Fox News argues in the court filing that Burstein failed to conduct basic research into one of the accounts he cited, which was posted under the name Daniel Wayne Block. According to the filing, a simple phone call would have revealed that Mr. Block is alive and well and has no connection to Fox News, other than as a fan.

When linking smart devices to your Wi-Fi network, exercise utmost care. Internet-connected devices, such as smart light bulbs, have been found to have vulnerabilities, making it essential to be vigilant. The Internet of Things, comprising wirelessly linked gadgets like security cameras, thermostats, and baby monitors, has been a prime target for cybercriminals seeking to infiltrate or disrupt networks. A recent major cyberattack, facilitated by compromised devices, brought online traffic to a standstill. To comprehend how hackers exploit smart devices, refer to a detailed post on the Heimdal Security blog. Weak security on both the network and devices has created vulnerabilities for hackers to exploit. However, there are measures to fortify your home network's defenses. Begin by ensuring your home network router uses a robust, unique password that differs from the default one. Your router's manufacturer should provide guidance for changing the password. Alter default passwords on your smart devices and use distinct passwords for each one. Install available firmware updates or security patches to maintain protection.

We rely heavily on our cellphones, which require battery power to function. To ensure they remain charged, I sought advice from Nick Guy, a senior staff writer at The Wirecutter. With 32,819 Amazon results for "wall charger," I needed guidance navigating the multitude of options. The sheer number of choices can be overwhelming, but once you know what to look for, it's manageable. Our top-recommended wall charger is Anker's PowerPort 4, featuring four USB ports capable of delivering up to 2.4 amps per port. Most devices cannot draw more power than that, so this charger will charge most devices at their maximum speed. The exceptions are newer devices supporting USB-C PD and Qualcomm Quick Charge, which are still relatively rare. I often carry my charger, wondering if it would fit in my pocket or weigh down my bag. While the PowerPort 4 would fit in a bag, it might be too large for a pocket. If portability is a priority, I recommend iClever's Dual USB Travel Wall Charger, which is compact and lightweight. Recently, I read a warning that public charging stations can be risky to use, as they might compromise your data, raising concerns about legitimacy.

The Galapagos Islands' avifauna remains a crucial aspect of our comprehension of evolutionary theory. Charles Darwin's visit to the islands was marked by the striking diversity of finch beaks, which facilitated his understanding of how a single species could transform into multiple forms. The Galapagos cormorants, the sole species to lose the ability to fly, have enabled scientists to pinpoint the genes responsible for this species' divergence from all other cormorants approximately two million years ago. These genes, present in birds, mammals, and most animals, including the commonly studied nematode C. elegans, are also found in some algae. Their effects differ, with influences on bone growth in humans and cormorants, while mutations in humans can lead to severe diseases and in birds result in smaller wings and a weaker breastbone, reducing flight effectiveness. Alejandro Burga, a researcher in Leonid Kruglyak's laboratory, analyzed the DNA of these and other cormorants with his colleagues. Burga noted that he and Dr. Kruglyak were discussing how to harness modern genetics' increasing power to investigate the process of speciation. "We have very little understanding of how these events occur in nature," he said.

Sinclair Broadcast Group, poised to acquire Tribune Media and establish a massive local television network with 223 stations, is in talks with seasoned television executive Steve Mosko to expand its programming offerings. According to sources familiar with the discussions, Mosko, former chairman of Sony Pictures Television, is in preliminary negotiations with Sinclair for a senior management position. The talks were initially reported by The Financial Times. Mosko's television career began in the late 1970s at a Baltimore station owned by Julian Smith, Sinclair's founder, and he has maintained close ties with the Smith family, who continue to control the company. Mosko is perhaps best known for revitalizing Sony's television division, which was struggling after a major downsizing in 2001. By the time he left the company last year, television was generating more revenue for Sony than its film division. During his tenure, Sony produced popular broadcast network shows such as "Kevin Can Wait," critically acclaimed series like "Better Call Saul," and syndicated game shows like "Jeopardy."

The Round Health iOS app offers a complimentary version that tracks medication schedules, sends reminders, and enables users to record pill intake and calculate next doses. The Medisafe app is available for both Android and iOS, providing a complimentary version with optional in-app purchases for enhanced features. MyTherapy Pill Reminder & Medication Tracker is available for both Android and iOS, featuring a journal function and PDF report generation capabilities. Prior to using a health app, review its privacy policy and understand data storage, especially if it synchronizes across devices. Enable phone security features, such as a passcode, to safeguard your personal data.

In southwestern Canada, it's likely that an elderly elk you encounter is a female. Male elk, or bulls, typically don't live beyond five years due to hunting, whereas female elk, or cows, can live up to 20 years. Notably, cows over the age of 10 appear to be nearly invulnerable to hunters. A team of scientists aimed to understand why senior cows are so skilled at survival. Is it because these elk are naturally more cautious, thereby allowing them to evade hunters more effectively? Or can cows learn to avoid hunters over their lifetime, even if they initially exhibit more daring behavior? Research published in PLOS One suggests that both factors are involved. By tracking dozens of female elk over several years, the authors found that, overall, cautious cows were more likely to survive. However, they also discovered that individual cows could adapt their behavior and adopt stealthier strategies as they aged. As cows aged, they tended to move shorter distances and seek safer terrain if they sensed a higher risk of encountering hunters.

Prior to President Trump's travel ban and withdrawal from the Paris climate accord, the atmosphere was more conducive to cooperation. White House officials reported no hesitation from executives or investors to attend the Monday meeting, which focused on upgrading government technology. Tech executives and investors faced a dilemma, as they didn't want to be used as window dressing for photo opportunities, but also saw this as the most business-friendly administration since Eisenhower, which was more open to on-the-spot influence than any other administration.

Three high-profile CNN journalists resigned on Monday following the network's retraction and apology for a story linking a Trump ally to a Russian investment fund. The article was deemed unreliable and CNN was unable to fully stand by its reporting, causing a significant blow to its reputation. The resignations come amid intense criticism from Trump and his supporters, who label CNN's reporting as "fake news". Trump's advisors have also accused CNN of harboring a bias against the president. CNN's president, Jeffrey A. Zucker, was deeply disturbed by the reporting errors and led an internal investigation. The three resigning journalists played a crucial role in the story's publication. This is the latest in a series of embarrassing episodes for CNN, which has previously fired Kathy Griffin and severed ties with host Reza Aslan. Critics seized on the news, with Breitbart News publishing a headline that read "Fake News Blues". Despite the controversy, CNN's investigative reporting has received widespread acclaim, with the network highlighting the hiring of prominent journalists as evidence of its dedication to in-depth reporting. CNN's reporting has consistently clashed with the Trump administration, with President Trump publicly criticizing CNN's CEO at a White House press conference. Recently, CNN reporter Jim Acosta sharply criticized Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, for restricting television coverage of press briefings. In response, CNN dispatched a courtroom sketch artist to document Spicer's appearance at a briefing, emphasizing its commitment to transparency and accountability.

Waymo, Google's autonomous vehicle subsidiary, has significantly reduced its patent claims against Uber in a high-stakes lawsuit over driverless technology. A recent federal court filing reveals the dismissal of three out of four patent claims related to lidar sensor technology, a crucial component in self-driving car technology. The lawsuit highlights the intense competition for autonomous vehicle talent and technology. The case has significant implications for Google, which has invested years in developing driverless car technology and is now struggling to capitalize on it. Many of Waymo's top engineers have defected to rival companies, taking valuable knowledge of its technology with them. The dispute between Waymo and Uber began in February when Waymo filed a lawsuit alleging that Uber was using stolen intellectual property from a former Google project leader in its driverless vehicles. The case has been marked by months of contentious wrangling, culminating in Uber firing the former Google project leader, Anthony Levandowski. The trial is scheduled for October, with the central issue being whether Uber misappropriated Waymo's trade secrets.

NASA's Juno spacecraft has been orbiting Jupiter above its cloud tops, capturing breathtaking views of the planet. During its latest flyby, the spacecraft approached the Great Red Spot, a massive storm that has persisted for at least 350 years, within 5,600 miles. The mission's latest images were released on Wednesday, offering a rare glimpse into the storm's internal clouds. According to NASA scientist Amy A. Simon, the Great Red Spot's appearance may have changed since the Galileo orbiter mission concluded over a decade ago. "The internal clouds appear less fragmented in some areas compared to Galileo," Simon said. "We expected this based on recent Hubble imaging, but these new images provide a higher-resolution view of the clouds and reveal exactly how they've changed over the past decades." The released images may appear distorted due to the spacecraft's close proximity to the storm, which causes the horizon to appear foreshortened. According to NASA's lead investigator for the JunoCam instrument, Candice Hansen-Koharcheck, the hourglass shape is a result of this unique perspective.

The Yukon-Charley Rivers National Preserve in central Alaska spans 2.5 million acres, supporting a habitat for majestic animals such as wolves. Despite human-defined boundaries, wolves roam freely across the region, unaffected by human efforts to restrict their movement. A recent study in Wildlife Monographs suggests that controlling wolf populations outside the preserve has had adverse effects on wolves within it. The study reveals that when Alaskan authorities culled wolf populations outside the preserve, survival rates within the preserve were lower than usual. This highlights the importance of communication and cooperation between wildlife managers within and outside preserve boundaries, with potential implications for global wildlife management programs. The Alaska Department of Fish and Game has invested millions in an intensive predator management program since the 1990s, initially using sterilization and later shooting and killing hundreds of wolves from helicopters. Despite decades of effort, the program has failed to significantly increase the Fortymile caribou herd population, which remains at around 50,000 to 60,000. Research suggests that these efforts may not be effective in increasing caribou numbers. Over 22 years of monitoring wolves using radio collars, researchers found that wolf survival rates decreased during lethal management outside the preserve. Every single wolf pack left the preserve, as the state only targeted wolves outside the preserve, while many wolves that ventured out were shot and killed.

As summer arrives, a new generation of black-legged ticks that transmit Lyme and other diseases emerges, seeking their first blood meal. These ticks, widespread on forest floors, suburban estates, and urban parks across North America and Europe, are attracted to white-footed mice and other small mammals that harbor pathogens. Typically, they feed on these mice, but a recent study suggests that the surge in tick-borne disease may be linked to a decline in traditional mouse predators. If mice were less abundant, larval ticks might feed on other mammals and birds that don't carry diseases, or they might struggle to find their first meal. Ticks require three meals to reproduce, and humans are only at risk of contracting diseases from ticks that have previously fed on infected hosts.

To test this theory, lead researcher Tim R. Hofmeester set up cameras in 20 plots across the Dutch countryside to monitor fox and stone marten activity. The plots were situated in both protected areas and areas where foxes are heavily hunted. Over two years, Hofmeester captured hundreds of mice and voles, counted the number of ticks on them, and tested the ticks for Lyme and other disease-causing bacteria. He also used a blanket to capture more ticks by dragging it across the ground.

Obesity is a widespread problem in the United States, boasting one of the highest rates of overweight individuals globally. A recent study published in Psychological Science suggests that this phenomenon may have an unforeseen influence on how people perceive American identity. The research discovered that heavier Asian-Americans are more likely to be perceived as "American" than those of average weight, and overweight Asian-American men are less likely to be viewed as illegal immigrants. The study uncovered a paradoxical social advantage for Asian-Americans, where excess weight can lead to being seen as more American and less susceptible to prejudice against those assumed to be foreign. According to Sapna Cheryan, an associate professor of psychology at the University of Washington and a study author, this finding implies that there is a social benefit for Asian-Americans in being overweight, as it enables them to be perceived as more American and less prone to prejudice.

Several professors who have publicly shared their opinions on race and politics have become targets of both liberal and conservative groups, with even the most obscure or academic statements sparking attack campaigns fueled by online monitoring of social media for controversial remarks. The Professor Watch List, created by Turning Point USA, has amplified scrutiny towards professors accused of discriminating against conservative students and promoting left-wing ideologies in the classroom. Some websites even send alerts to subscribers. The latest targets of these attacks include Sarah E. Bond, a classics professor at the University of Iowa, who faced threats and calls for dismissal after writing an academic paper challenging the use of marble antiquities by white supremacist groups. Another victim is Tommy Curry, a philosophy professor at Texas A & M, who received death threats after a column drew attention to a 2012 podcast discussing violence against blacks by whites versus violence against whites by blacks. Johnny Eric Williams, a professor at Trinity College in Hartford, was placed on leave after sharing a provocative post arguing that bigots in danger should be left to die, and his family had to flee the state due to severe threats.

A wave of controversy has swept across campuses over the past year, focusing on racist historical figures. Statues have been toppled and buildings rebranded nationwide. Following student protests and internal reviews, at least five universities have renamed buildings previously honoring Ku Klux Klan members. However, not all universities have taken similar action. For instance, students at the University of Alabama petitioned the president to rename Morgan Hall, honoring John Tyler Morgan, the KKK's grand dragon and a senator, in honor of alumna Harper Lee. Buildings named for David Bibb Graves, a former governor of Alabama and grand cyclops of the KKK's Montgomery chapter, can be found at Auburn, the University of Alabama, and at least nine other universities, including two historically black schools, Alabama A&M and Alabama State University. Meanwhile, Middle Tennessee State University's board of regents voted to remove Nathan Bedford Forrest's name from Forrest Hall, believed to be the KKK's first grand wizard, after years of student protests.

Immediately stop all activity and move away from the microwave. The soft cleaning tool is a tiny world teeming with millions of microorganisms. While some may assume that microwaving a sponge kills its tiny inhabitants, this is only partially true. The weaker bacteria may be eliminated, but the most resilient, potent, and potentially harmful bacteria will survive and thrive. They'll multiply and occupy the vacant space left behind by the dead, ultimately making your sponge even more pungent and unpleasant, prompting you to regret not simply discarding it. According to a recent study published in Scientific Reports, microorganisms are ubiquitous, so it's no surprise that a kitchen sponge would serve as a breeding ground for them. However, previous research had underestimated the quantity and diversity of bacteria found in sponges. By analyzing DNA and RNA samples from 14 used sponges, microbiologist Markus Egert and his team identified 362 distinct species of bacteria inhabiting them. The researchers were astonished to discover that the microbes coexisted in such close proximity with remarkable density: approximately 82 billion bacteria per cubic inch. "This density is comparable to what you'd find in human stool samples," Dr. Egert noted. "There may be no other places on earth with such high bacterial densities."

A prominent corporation's social media account was compromised in a hacking incident on Wednesday evening. The breach is part of a larger scheme orchestrated by a single hacker, identified as "Mr. Smith," who has been targeting HBO since the start of the month. Mr. Smith has been releasing confidential information, including an HBO executive's emails and unaired episodes of shows like "Curb Your Enthusiasm," "Ballers," and "Insecure." The extent to which these episodes have been shared online remains unclear. This is not the only instance of leaked content, as two unaired "Game of Thrones" episodes were leaked online earlier this month, unrelated to the wider breach. The Twitter hacking on Wednesday night does not appear to be connected to the Mr. Smith attack. OurMine, a group known for hacking major companies like YouTube, Marvel, and Netflix, is also under investigation for the hacking incident.

The capacity for impulsive behavior can be a significant asset. Picture a mouse dodging a cat by moving erratically and unpredictably, thereby increasing its chances of survival. Similarly, in humans, this type of behavior is linked to creativity and cognitive complexity. However, understanding the human mind's capacity for randomness is a complex task. A team of European researchers recently conducted a series of experiments to measure human random decision-making abilities. They found that, on average, individuals are most skilled at producing random results around the age of 25. The team designed five tasks to test randomness, including simulating random coin flips, guessing the next card in a shuffled deck, and arranging a grid of black and white boxes to appear random. Over 3,400 participants from 4 to 91 years old took part in the experiment. The researchers used software to analyze participants' responses and identified the sequences that were most challenging for the computer to predict as the most random. By analyzing participants' performance against various factors, including age, sex, and educational background, the researchers found a strong correlation with age. Performance improved from childhood to the mid-20s and remained relatively high until the 60s, after which it began to decline. However, Dr. Zenil noted that even in older adults, there may be trade-offs that compensate for decreased randomness, such as increased experience and knowledge.

Syd Silverman, the owner of Variety for three decades, died on August 27 in Boca Raton, Florida, at the age of 85. His son Michael confirmed the news. As president of Daily Variety and publisher of its New York edition, Silverman had a profound impact on shaping the entertainment industry's vocabulary. Founded by his grandfather Sime, both publications were pillars of the industry, with Daily Variety's reporters covering the business from a Manhattan brownstone, where traditional typewriters and manual typesetting were the standard. Throughout his tenure, Variety's editorial content spanned the 20th century, from silent films to digital devices, as the industry underwent significant transformations driven by technological advancements and shifting business models.

Figuring out why humans cry can be a challenging task. We cry in response to a wide range of emotions, including the loss of loved ones, violence, heartbreak, and even joy. Sometimes we struggle to cry when we should, and other times we cry without apparent reason. Amidst this emotional complexity, it's refreshing to consider the straightforward explanation behind why onions make us tear up. Onions release a chemical called lachrymatory factor, which irritates our eyes when it reacts with other substances. Simply peeling an onion won't cause our eyes to water, but chopping, cutting, crushing, or smashing one will. This is because the onion's cells break open, allowing two previously separate substances to combine and form a potent chemical irritant. According to Josie Silvaroli, this chemical reaction is analogous to tear gas, as it releases a gas that hits the eyes and sensory nerves, causing them to tear up. The lachrymatory factor evolved as a defense mechanism to protect onions from microbes and animals, including humans. When an onion is damaged, it triggers this defense mechanism, releasing the chemical reaction as its cells break down.

In 2015, BMI reached a record-breaking $1 billion in revenue for the first time. At the time, CEO Michael O'Neill forecasted it would take three more years for the agency to generate $1 billion in royalties to its songwriters and music publishers after expenses. BMI has achieved a notable milestone: it generated $1.13 billion in revenue and distributed $1.02 billion in royalties to its members during its most recent fiscal year, which concluded in June. With hundreds of thousands of members, including prominent artists like Taylor Swift, Ed Sheeran, and Sting, BMI collects royalties whenever songs are played on the radio, streamed online, or piped into a restaurant. According to O'Neill, "Revenue is a significant number, but distributions are what ultimately benefit a songwriter's pocket." BMI and its rival Ascap have experienced steady revenue growth over the past decade, driven by changes in technology and music consumption patterns. Ascap had previously reached $1 billion in revenue in 2015, beating BMI to the mark.

Fox News's prime-time lineup, a familiar presence in the Oval Office, is on the verge of a significant overhaul. Conservative radio host and commentator Laura Ingraham, an early supporter of President Trump, is in talks with the network to claim the 10 p.m. time slot. If the deal comes to fruition, Sean Hannity, the network's outspoken host and informal presidential advisor, is likely to move to the 9 p.m. slot, where he'll face off against MSNBC's top-rated Rachel Maddow. This shake-up would mark the latest in a series of adjustments to Fox News's prime-time schedule, which has been in flux since the departures of Megyn Kelly and Bill O'Reilly earlier this year. The network is also struggling with unprecedented competition from MSNBC, whose hosts have seen a surge in popularity among liberal viewers since the presidential election.

AMC has appointed David Madden, a former Fox executive, as its new head of original programming. Madden, who departed Fox in late August, will oversee popular shows including "The Walking Dead" and "Better Call Saul", which is up for several Emmy Awards on Sunday. He will also play a key role in AMC's in-house studio and be responsible for programming at Sundance TV. Madden's experience in developing shows like "The Shield" and "The Americans" during his time at Fox makes him a strong fit for cable networks like AMC.

"Microsoft's Outlook for Android app, introduced in 2015, focuses on streamlining inbox management and scheduling. Upon receiving emails, formatting is visible, but composing messages on your device is restricted to plain text, excluding capabilities such as bold, italic, and underline. When crafting a message, you can access fundamental functions like copying by long-pressing on the text. To request further features, you can submit a suggestion directly within the Outlook app."

Just days after announcing its sale, Rolling Stone faces a new challenge: ongoing litigation over a retracted article about a gang rape at the University of Virginia. The US Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has overturned a lower court's decision to dismiss a defamation lawsuit filed by three former members of the fraternity featured in the 2014 article. The original ruling had dismissed the lawsuit, stating that the three men had not shown that the article was about them personally, aside from their affiliation with the fraternity. However, the appellate judges disagreed, ruling that the article could be seen as referring to Elias and Fowler, and sent the case back to the district court for further proceedings. While none of the men were named in the article, details like the setting of the alleged rape and descriptions of the men's interests could have led a reader familiar with the fraternity, Phi Kappa Psi, to identify Elias and Fowler, according to the lawsuit. The judges upheld the original dismissal in the case of Hadford, whose only identifying feature was his fondness for riding his bike around campus.

China's iconic giant pandas are a treasured national emblem, and the only place outside captivity where they can be found. Years of conservation efforts by the Chinese government have led to a remarkable rebound in the panda population. In September 2016, the pandas were officially removed from the endangered species list, with an estimated population of 1,864, excluding cubs. This represents a significant increase from the low of around 1,200 in the 1980s. However, climate change and other factors could still devastate the pandas' habitat in the long term, rendering any population surge a temporary triumph. The fragmentation of the panda population, now confined to just six mountain ranges and 30 isolated groups, is a major concern. According to Dr. Ouyang and her colleagues, Chinese conservation efforts have had a positive impact on panda habitats in recent years, and planned changes are expected to reduce pressures on the pandas and their habitat in the short term. However, infrastructure development, tourism, and other human activities could undermine these improvements. The researchers recommend several steps to prevent the pandas from becoming endangered again, including improving connectivity between isolated panda populations, reducing habitat fragmentation, establishing ecological red lines, expanding panda preserves, and restricting tourism in national parks containing pandas.

Disney has been renovating its Northridge Fashion Center mall store in Los Angeles since late July. The revamped store now features a massive movie theater-sized screen, a simplified floor plan, and white walls, replacing iconic Pixie Path aisles, ornate displays, green walls, and color-changing fiberglass trees. The store now offers a broader range of fashion-forward items for adults. This prototype is being tested, with sales and customer feedback monitored as the company prepares to revamp its 340-store chain. The goal is to learn from the experience, particularly during the holiday season. The redesign aims to bring a more immersive theme-park-like experience to Disney's stores, featuring daily live streams of Disneyland and Walt Disney World parades on colossal video screens. During these parades, store staff will set up seating areas and carts stocked with treats like cotton candy and light-up Mickey Mouse ears for shoppers to enjoy.

In the spotlight of Los Angeles, every Hollywood star has a Playboy Mansion story, but one tale stands out as a testament to the mansion's notorious reputation. Sharan Magnuson, a former Warner Bros. executive, has a story that resonates with many women. Magnuson arrived in Hollywood in 1980 to pursue an acting career and soon discovered a dark side of the Playboy Mansion that few people dared to discuss. Initially, the mansion was captivating, with glamorous events, impeccable maintenance, and exquisite banquet spreads. The atmosphere was further enhanced by the presence of flamingos and monkeys. However, not all of Hef's male guests shared his charming demeanor. In the mid-1980s, Magnuson and her girlfriend were invited to the mansion for a Sunday movie night, but the evening took a disturbing turn when a man who had seemed friendly earlier cornered her outside. "He suddenly had nine hands," Magnuson recalled, recounting the incident. "He tried to get me into the cave, and when I refused, he physically restrained me. I felt violated."

"I'm getting warnings that my iCloud storage is full, and Apple suggests upgrading to a larger plan. Are there more affordable and user-friendly options available? I only need to back up a few random files, not my entire computer. Apple offers 5GB of free storage for documents, photos, videos, and device backups. I can access these files from iOS devices, Macs, and PCs with iCloud software installed. My iCloud email messages and older accounts are also stored here. If I receive warning messages, Apple recommends purchasing more storage or deleting old files, messages, and backups to free up space. Buying more storage from Apple is easy, as no download or installation is required. If I've purchased media or apps from iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store, Apple may already have my credit card on file. Prices start at 99 cents for 50GB, $2.99 for 200GB, and $9.99 for 2TB."

The news of Tom Petty's passing spread rapidly across the internet on Monday afternoon, with CBS News breaking the story. The announcement triggered a wave of tributes and condolences from notable singers like John Mayer, Shania Twain, and Jon Bon Jovi, who paid their respects on Twitter. However, it soon became clear that the news was premature, and Petty's manager confirmed his death just before midnight, revealing it had occurred at 11:30pm. Initially, CBS News reported Petty's death on Twitter with a bold "BREAKING" banner, citing the Los Angeles Police Department. In an online article, the network only stated "CBS News has confirmed" without mentioning the LAPD. CBS later deleted the tweet.

Anthony Scaramucci, the former White House communications director, reminisced about his eventful career path while seated in his Midtown Manhattan steakhouse, which he co-owns, as he shared outlandish claims about the moon landing, Tang, and Velcro with journalists. Just nine weeks earlier, Scaramucci was still shaping the president's public relations strategy from Air Force One. After being fired by President Trump, served with divorce papers, and mocked on late-night TV, Scaramucci is attempting a comeback with a new media venture called The Scaramucci Post. The project's specifics remain unclear, but Scaramucci described it as an "experiential online venture" during a launch party at the Hunt & Fish Club.

I'm considering purchasing a new iMac desktop computer and would like to know if it's similar to previous models. I currently use an old MacBook with AppleWorks, a word-processing program. Will a new Mac be able to convert my old files to a current word-processing program?

The new iMac boasts advanced technology, featuring a faster processor, sharper screen, and updated software. However, you may need to adjust to the new hardware and operating system if you haven't upgraded recently. The Migration Assistant program can assist in transferring your files from your old machine to the new one. Unfortunately, older software may not be compatible with modern Macs.

AppleWorks, a collection of office and art programs, was discontinued over 10 years ago and replaced by iWork, a suite of free programs including Pages, Numbers, and Keynote. These programs are compatible with Macs, iOS devices, and web browsers. When you purchase a new Mac, you'll receive the latest version of these programs. However, you may encounter issues opening older files with the new software. If you used AppleWorks 6 and saved your files in that version, you can try opening them with the current iWork programs. Files created in AppleWorks 5 or earlier may not be compatible. To open an older AppleWorks file, open the Pages program, select File > Open, and choose the AppleWorks file. If it opens, you can save it in the newer Pages format by selecting File > Save As.

"I'm closing my Yahoo and Flickr accounts. I still have most of my original photos on my computer, but I need to retrieve a few that I can't find on my hard drive. Can I download the Flickr copies in their original resolution, or will they be lower in quality? You can download a copy of each photo in its original resolution, just like it was uploaded. To do this, log into your Flickr account, select a photo from your collection, and click the Download arrow icon in the lower-right corner of the viewer window. From the menu that pops up, choose Original to download the image in its highest resolution. Flickr automatically creates multiple resolutions of uploaded images for sharing purposes. You can see the range of sizes available for a picture by clicking the Download arrow and choosing View All Sizes from the menu. I'll download the original resolution photos."

Beneath Yellowstone National Park lies a supervolcano, a colossal force capable of releasing over 1,000 cubic kilometers of rock and ash in a single event, dwarfing ordinary volcanoes. This would be a staggering 2,500 times more material than the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens, which claimed 57 lives. Such an event could blanket most of the United States in a thick layer of ash, potentially plunging the Earth into a prolonged period of volcanic winter. Yellowstone's most recent supereruption occurred 631,000 years ago, but it's not the only buried supervolcano on the planet. Scientists believe a supereruption occurs every 100,000 years, prompting questions about when the next such event will occur. To better understand this phenomenon, scientists are studying Yellowstone's past to uncover the secrets behind these rare and violent events. The early findings have revealed a surprising discovery: the forces driving these events can move much faster than previously thought. Initial evidence suggests that Yellowstone's most recent supereruption was triggered by new magma entering the system just decades before the eruption, contradicting previous estimates that assumed a geological process unfolding over thousands of years.

A Weinstein Company employee described a chaotic work environment on Friday, with unanswered phones and some staff members openly defying authority. Former chief spokesperson Nicole Quenqua announced she would no longer provide statements to the press. The Weinstein Company has been at the center of a growing scandal surrounding Harvey Weinstein and his brother. Investigations by The New York Times and The New Yorker uncovered decades-old allegations of sexual misconduct and rape against Harvey Weinstein. Harvey Weinstein, who has denied allegations of non-consensual sex, was fired by the Weinstein Company's board of directors, which includes his brother, on Sunday. Several other male board members have resigned, including billionaire investor Dirk Ziff, Milwaukee Bucks owner and Avenue Capital Group CEO Marc Lasry, Technicolor president and deputy CEO Tim Sarnoff, and accountant Richard Koenigsberg, who departed on Thursday. The Weinstein Company boasts significant assets, including a TV unit with popular shows and a theatrical division with seven completed films, potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Benedict Cumberbatch released a statement on Tuesday condemning Harvey Weinstein's actions. As the entertainment industry distances itself from the company, questions are mounting about whether the studio can continue to operate. Speculation about bankruptcy surfaced in Variety on Thursday, and on Friday, The Wall Street Journal reported that the Weinstein Company is exploring a sale or shutdown.

"Can I upgrade my three-year-old MacBook Air running OS X 10.9.5 to the latest operating system? Yes, you can upgrade directly to macOS High Sierra, skipping intermediate updates, if your MacBook Air meets the necessary hardware requirements. Apple recommends upgrading Macs running OS X 10.8 or later, without installing in-between updates. Specifically, MacBook Air laptops from late 2010, MacBook Pro laptops, Mac Mini, Mac Pro desktops from mid-2010 or later, and iMacs and MacBooks from late 2009 are eligible for the High Sierra upgrade."

The fly agaric mushroom is a beloved symbol in fairy tales, its striking, large fruiting bodies sprawling across mossy forests in North America and Europe. Initially, they emerge from the soil as white, egg-like structures, as if left behind by a mysterious woodland creature. Reaching up to a foot tall, the mushroom's cap develops warts, gradually shifting to a deep crimson hue. Eventually, the mushroom opens and flattens into a distinctive, polka-dot disc, resembling a plate fit for a whimsical gnome. Recently, enthusiasts and nature lovers have been sharing their fly agaric discoveries on social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. A striking post from Hungary featured a video and photo of a massive mushroom, nearly as large as a child. For many Eastern Europeans, mushroom hunting is a treasured tradition, while for others, it provides an additional source of income. For Csaba Reisz, a fertilizer salesman and soil nutrition consultant in southern Hungary, mushroom hunting serves as a welcome respite from the stresses of work. He finds solace in combining mushroom hunting and photography, which helps him rediscover his peace.

For nearly a decade, Netflix has released original series, including critically acclaimed shows like "House of Cards" and "Master of None", leaving unanswered the question of how many people are actually watching. The company, alongside Amazon and Hulu, has kept its viewership numbers secret, leaving industry experts puzzled about the popularity of these shows. However, Nielsen, a 94-year-old company that has long dominated US television ratings, has recently announced a groundbreaking method for measuring Netflix viewership. The details of Nielsen's data and measurement methods remain unclear, but this development marks a significant step towards establishing a reliable third-party ratings system for streaming services.

"When I visit Amazon on my computer, I'm shown a list of products I previously viewed. I'd like to prevent Amazon from tracking every product I click on. Amazon saves the products you browse on the site and displays them on your account's homepage. If this feature bothers you, you can turn it off. To do so, go to Amazon.com, log in to your account, click on 'Browsing History', then 'Manage History' to customize your settings."

The chief legal officers of Facebook, Google, and Twitter will testify before congressional hearings on November 1, discussing their companies' roles in Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential elections. The CEOs of the internet companies, Mark Zuckerberg, Jack Dorsey, and Sundar Pichai, will not attend, instead choosing to send their top lawyers to avoid scrutiny and potential public relations backlash.

Colin Stretch, Facebook's 48-year-old chief legal officer, has been with the company since 2010 and has led several high-profile legal battles, including an internal review on foreign interference on the platform. He holds a Dartmouth undergraduate degree and a Harvard law degree, and clerked for Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer.

Richard Walker, Google's 56-year-old chief legal officer, joined the company in 2006 after serving as deputy general counsel at eBay. During his time at Google, the company has been involved in several high-profile legal battles, including a landmark copyright case with Viacom and a lawsuit with Oracle over software copyrights. Walker is currently leading Google's efforts to challenge a $2.7 billion fine from the European Commission for antitrust violations.

Acting Chief Legal Officer Edgett, 39, is currently filling the role while Vijaya Gadde, Twitter's General Counsel, is on maternity leave. With over a decade of experience at Twitter, Edgett has been part of a legal team that has faced numerous challenges, including navigating complex policy and legal issues related to site security, hate speech, foreign government demands for information, and the use of the platform by terrorist groups. Prior to joining Twitter, Edgett worked at prominent law firms Latham & Watkins and Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld. He holds a law degree from Pepperdine University and a Bachelor's degree from the University of California, San Diego.

"When a Windows 10 update is a system upgrade versus just a patch, how can I tell? I receive frequent patch notifications, so I'm unclear when this one differs. Can I already see if it has installed itself? The Windows 10 Fall Creators Update is available for compatible devices through Windows Update. To check if it's available for your system, visit the Windows Update page and look for 'Feature update to Windows 10, version 1709'. If unsure, you can manually check for updates. To do this, click Start, select Settings, navigate to Update & Security > Windows Update, and click 'Check for updates'."

Amazon received 238 proposals from cities and regions across North America for its second headquarters, with bids coming from all but seven US states and several Canadian provinces and territories.

A color-coded map on the company's website shows that proposals came from 54 states, provinces, districts, and territories, including Puerto Rico.

The majority of applicants were from the United States, with only North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, Montana, Vermont, Arkansas, and Hawaii declining to participate.

In Canada, the Yukon Territory, Saskatchewan, and New Brunswick did not submit a bid, while in Mexico, only three states - Chihuahua, Hidalgo, and Queretaro - applied.

Amazon will announce its decision sometime next year.

The bidding process has been marked by a frenzy of publicity stunts and incentives offered by cities and regions eager to lure the 50,000 high-paying jobs promised by the company.

Some cities have gone to great lengths to woo Amazon, including a mayor who made a viral video featuring a faux conversation with Alexa.

Other cities have offered more unusual incentives, such as a 21-foot-tall saguaro cactus and a promise to fight a bear to win Amazon's new headquarters.

While the bidding process has generated significant free publicity for Amazon, it has also sparked criticism of the company's request for tax breaks and other incentives.

New Jersey has proposed providing $7 billion in state and city tax incentives to bring Amazon to Newark.

Some job seekers deliberately focused on showcasing their decision not to apply for Amazon's second headquarters.

A business organization in Little Rock, Arkansas, recently published a newspaper ad and created an online video to inform Amazon that they didn't want the traffic congestion its new headquarters would bring to their town.

Arkansas is the home state of Amazon's main competitor, Walmart.

You can determine if the cable TV service is down without calling without making a phone call. If you have a working internet connection or mobile access and an online account with your cable provider, you can check your equipment's status online. Log in to your account on your TV provider's website and navigate to the technical support section. The information will vary depending on your cable company, but many providers offer online tools to troubleshoot issues and reduce phone calls. Spectrum allows you to select the affected service and view its status, as well as check for area outage notices.

Twitter's headquarters in San Francisco is under investigation for its alleged role in the 2016 presidential election, with the company facing inquiries about deception and dishonesty. The company has admitted to inflating its monthly user numbers since 2014, following a mistake in counting data from third-party apps. The revelation came as Twitter reported a narrower net loss in the third quarter and a 14% increase in daily active users. However, the disclosure may further damage Twitter's reputation, which is already under scrutiny for its handling of Russia's election meddling, abuse, and harassment on the platform, and concerns about slowing user growth worldwide. Twitter's measure of monthly active users had incorrectly included figures from third-party apps using Digits, a software-development program. As a result, the company reduced its monthly active user count by 2 million for the first and second quarters of this year and by 1 million for the fourth quarter of 2016. Twitter was unable to reconcile the figures for periods before last year's fourth quarter due to its data-retention policies. The company reported a 4% increase in monthly active users from the same period last year, with 330 million users, up from 326 million in the second quarter. Twitter reported a net loss of $21.1 million for the quarter, compared to a $102.9 million loss for the same period last year. Revenue declined 4% to $590 million.

My iPhone's screen automatically activates when I pick it up or move it, eliminating the need to press the power button. This functionality is a standard feature on iPhone 6s and later models, attributed to the Raise to Wake function. Initially, this feature may seem unusual to those unfamiliar with it. When lifting the phone, the screen springs to life, presenting the lock screen with any received notifications, without requiring device unlocking. Some users may opt to disable this feature for privacy concerns.

This week, lawmakers issued a stern warning to Facebook regarding Russian agents' exploitation of the social network to spread division during the 2016 election, but Facebook's top executives, including CEO Mark Zuckerberg and COO Sheryl Sandberg, delivered a conflicting message prioritizing profits. Facebook released its third-quarter financial results after concluding its attendance at Capitol Hill hearings on Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election, revealing a 47% revenue surge to $10.3 billion and a 79% profit increase to $4.7 billion, exceeding Wall Street expectations. The results solidified Facebook's dominance in online advertising, an area the company has faced criticism for in Washington this week. Lawmakers grilled Facebook, Google, and Twitter on how Russians may have misused their platforms, including online ads, to fuel discord and polarization in the American electorate. Some lawmakers expressed discontent over the absence of top executives from Facebook, Google, and Twitter at the hearings, as well as the lack of attendance by their top lawyers. Facebook's general counsel, Colin Stretch, answered questions on behalf of the company, while Google and Twitter sent their top lawyers to participate.

A Canadian filmmaker, Barry Avrich, has revived his documentary about Harvey Weinstein, initially released online in 2011. Avrich claims the original film, "Unauthorized: The Harvey Weinstein Project," was watered down and now feels a moral obligation to rework it due to sexual harassment and rape allegations against Weinstein. From Ottawa, Avrich stated he wants to expand the documentary beyond its initial 11-minute conclusion, which focused on Weinstein's behavior as a sexual predator. However, Avrich must first resolve the issue with IFC Films, which acquired the documentary's distribution rights in 2010. Avrich has long alleged that IFC requested edits to the film and ultimately decided against a theatrical release to appease Weinstein. IFC has denied these claims, stating that the film was made available on various platforms and that they asked the filmmaker to remove 30 seconds of non-essential footage.

I've been frustrated with my iPhone since the software update. It insists on thinking I'm driving whenever I'm in a taxi, requiring me to repeatedly tap 'I'm not driving.' I'm tired of constantly telling my phone I don't drive.

The latest iOS 11 update introduces a new safety feature within the 'Do Not Disturb' function, which silences notifications while driving. When enabled, this feature kicks in when my iPhone connects to a car's dashboard via Bluetooth or detects movement and acceleration. It can even mistake the movement of a train or bus for driving. And, as I've learned, taxi passengers may find their phones temporarily disabled unless they switch off the Do Not Disturb control.

Thousands of years ago, a microscopic fungus began to grow at an astonishing rate of up to three feet per year, eventually covering an area the size of three Central Parks beneath the Oregon soil, potentially weighing as much as 5,000 African elephants. This enormous organism, known scientifically as Armillaria ostoyae, is affectionately referred to as The Humongous Fungus and is officially recognized as the largest known terrestrial organism on the planet by the United States Forest Service. However, its impressive size comes with a deadly drawback: it's a highly destructive forest pathogen. Other Armillaria species are also prevalent in North America, Europe, and Asia, causing root rot disease in forests, parks, orchards, and vineyards. What sets these fungi apart is their ability to send out stringy rhizomorphs that target weak trees, colonize their roots, and ultimately kill and consume them. A team of international scientists has made a breakthrough in the fight against these fungal giants, uncovering the genetic secrets behind Armillaria's remarkable ability to develop its unique rhizomorphs, grow to enormous sizes, and excel at killing host plants.

"My new iPhone features a dedicated emoji key on the keyboard, replacing the globe key, which allows for easy access to multiple keyboard layouts for various languages. This includes emojis and other pictographs. When I add a new international keyboard, the emoji key transforms into a globe key, enabling me to insert emojis into text. To access alternative keyboard options, I press and hold the globe key. I can also add a keyboard designed for another language by going to Settings, General, Keyboard, and Add New Keyboard. Alternatively, if I'm using the keyboard within an app, I can access settings by pressing and holding the emoji key for a few seconds."

When someone advises you to "wake up and smell the roses," it may be misguided. Research indicates that our sense of smell is more acute at specific times of day, peaking before sleep. A study published in Chemical Senses linked this fluctuation to our internal body rhythms. The study, led by sensory researcher Rachel Herz at Brown University, examined how taste and smell senses in teenagers influence obesity. To conduct the experiment, 37 teenagers aged 12 to 15 spent nine days in a lab, adhering to a strict schedule to regulate their sleep and wake cycles. This allowed the researchers to isolate the impact of the body's internal clock on metabolic processes. While more research is needed to determine if these findings apply to adults, Dr. Herz notes that the types of smell receptors in our noses remain consistent across age, yet there's evidence that internal clocks may evolve.

Apple has acquired the rights to a highly anticipated drama series starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston, a significant milestone in the TV industry. The show, centered around a morning TV show, marks a major coup for Apple, which outbid Netflix and Showtime for the two-season, 20-episode project. This is Apple's second major TV acquisition, following its deal to revive Steven Spielberg's "Amazing Stories" anthology series. The Witherspoon-Aniston project is significant, given the star power and success of its leads. Witherspoon is coming off the critically acclaimed HBO limited series "Big Little Lies," where she starred and served as an executive producer. The new project marks Aniston's return to television after her iconic role on "Friends."

A prominent figure has sounded the alarm, cautioning that Google's vast collection of consumer data demands scrutiny. The statement resonates with the public's growing unease towards tech giants, who are accused of wielding too much power and necessitating regulatory oversight as they expand into new markets and reap massive profits.

A preliminary investigation by the state suggests that Google may be collecting more user data than it has publicly disclosed, leaving users without a genuine choice to opt out. Google maintains that it provides users with control over privacy settings and never shares personally identifiable information with third parties.

When asked about the subpoena, a company spokesperson declined to comment, citing the fact that the company had not yet received it. However, he emphasized that Google has robust privacy protections and operates in a competitive environment.

In 2012, the Federal Trade Commission concluded an investigation into Google's business practices without filing charges. As part of the settlement, Google agreed to stop using photos or user reviews from third-party sites that had requested their content not be scraped by Google's computers.

With the macOS High Sierra update, Apple has introduced features in Safari that enable you to silence videos that unexpectedly play on certain websites. You can also tailor your preferences for specific websites that play videos you're eager to watch immediately. To manage autoplay videos, you have two options. If a site starts playing a video, you can right-click and select "Website Settings" or find the option under the Safari menu.

Time Inc., publisher of renowned magazines such as Time, People, and Sports Illustrated, is on the cusp of a major transformation. The company has agreed to be acquired by Meredith, a Midwestern publisher, for approximately $3 billion, equivalent to its annual revenue. Like its peers, Time Inc. has struggled to adapt to the industry's shift from print to digital media. A decade ago, management disagreements and cost-cutting measures led to key talent departures and a lack of succession planning. Now, after nearly a century, Time Inc. must look to Meredith to chart its future, which may not rely on its iconic photography, swimsuit models, and ambitious journalism that made its titles household names.

"To experience the most extraordinary Christmas trees, you'll need to trade in your boots for scuba gear. These remarkable 'trees' aren't plants, but rather intricate homes built by Christmas tree worms on coral reefs worldwide. Constructed from calcium carbonate secretions, these tubes serve as homes for the worms, who emerge to feed, reproduce, and breathe using their branchial crowns. As you snorkel through the waters, look out for these vibrant, spiral-shaped cones that resemble miniature decorated firs. According to marine biologist Orly Perry, these 'trees' are "really pretty, very colorful, very festive, and Christmassy." Despite their small size, these worm 'trees' make up for it with dazzling displays that rival the work of a skilled candymaker. In the Gulf of Aqaba, near Eilat, Israel, Perry has observed many of these 'trees' displaying a kaleidoscope of colors, including purples, greens, and whites. Unlike other creatures, Christmas tree worms don't burrow into the coral; instead, they latch onto dead spots or wounds and construct their tubes. By synchronizing their tube growth with the coral's growth, the worms ensure their homes remain stable and accessible. Once settled, these worms stay put for up to 30 or 40 years, unable to relocate. The locations where these larvae settle are not arbitrary; they appear to have a specific preference for certain coral species, often opting for less aggressive ones. In optimal environments, the worms are able to grow to their full size. According to Mrs. Perry, this phenomenon is reminiscent of human behavior: "If you're comfortable in a place, everything is happy, and that's true for these worms too. Their size is directly impacted by their habitat choice." Some species within the Spirobranchus genus have a fondness for artificial surfaces, while others thrive on specific types of coral. Mrs. Perry discovered a potentially new species in the Gulf of Eilat that has a peculiar affinity for plastic buoys and metal surfaces on piers and staircases. It's possible that the larvae are drawn to these preferred habitats by signals emitted by older worms that have successfully colonized similar locations in the past."

As the streaming wars escalate, Apple has acquired its third TV show in just two months. The latest addition is a space drama produced by Ronald D. Moore, creator of successful shows like "Battlestar Galactica" and "Outlander". Last month, Apple secured the highly sought-after rights to a project starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston, set in the world of morning TV news. In October, Apple revived Steven Spielberg's 1980s anthology series, "Amazing Stories", for its inaugural acquisition. It's likely to be at least a year before any of these shows are available to viewers, with the distribution plan still unclear. Apple's haste to add shows to its growing slate is a testament to the cutthroat competition for content in the industry. On Thursday, Disney announced plans to acquire 21st Century Fox, a move aimed at bolstering its own ambitious streaming ambitions. Meanwhile, Netflix has pledged to spend up to $8 billion on content next year. Apple, on the other hand, has a budget of around $1 billion for original programming.

Mercury Lounge and the Bowery Ballroom, two iconic indie venues, have collaborated with Live Nation to launch Mercury East Presents, a new booking and promotion company. This partnership unites the Bowery and Mercury with Live Nation's Irving Plaza, Gramercy Theater, and Warsaw clubs, as well as its Ford Amphitheater at Coney Island Boardwalk. By pooling expertise and marketing strategies, the partnership mirrors the rapid consolidation of the local market. Live Nation has bolstered its presence in the city by acquiring the Governors Ball festival and making strategic moves, including purchasing Bowery Presents and partnering to acquire and renovate Webster Hall.

Wearable devices have advanced to monitor vital signs, including heart rate and body temperature. A flexible sensor can identify multiple chemicals in sweat, providing real-time data on conditions such as dehydration and fatigue. According to Ali Javey, a University of California, Berkeley electrical engineer, this technology can send alerts to patients, prompting them to take action, such as drinking water or taking medication. The sensor was recently featured in a Nature publication. Dr. Javey emphasizes that the system's advantages include comfort and ease of wear.

Joe Earley, a seasoned executive with a background in senior leadership roles, is returning to his alma mater in a new capacity. As of Friday, Earley, 49, will lead the Jackal Group, a new company co-owned by Fox and Gail Berman, which produces television, film, and live theater content. Gail Berman praised Earley as "an exceptional leader with a keen eye for great content" in a statement announcing his appointment. Earley left Fox without being promoted or pushed out, a departure notable for its lack of drama. "I wanted to be closer to the creative side of the business again," Earley said. "It's a fortunate coincidence that working with Gail again was the perfect fit."

I'm not claustrophobic or fidgety, and music is my true passion, despite not being a musician. Although I've written about numerous neuroscience studies using functional magnetic resonance imaging, I'd never witnessed a scan firsthand. This was my chance to rectify that. I asked Professor Nancy Kanwisher, a renowned neuroscience expert at M.I.T., to participate in her recent Neuron journal experiment. I requested a tour of the process, focusing on the music-specific pathway in my brain. I assured her that the enclosed environment wouldn't trigger panic and that I'd remain still and focused, providing high-quality data. Dr. Kanwisher agreed, and I was escorted to the scanning room by Sam Norman-Haignere and Alex Kell. The scanning device uses radio waves and magnetic fields to track blood flow, an indirect measure of neural activity. Before the scan, I removed all metal objects, including boots, belt, earrings, and other potential interference. I expressed concern about my titanium dental implants, but was reassured they'd be safe.

Richard P. Von Herzen, a renowned explorer, uncovered that the deep sea's icy exterior masked vast regions of simmering heat. He passed away on January 28 in Portola Valley, California, at the age of 85. His daughter confirmed vascular disease as the cause of death. For over five decades, Dr. Von Herzen worked at prestigious ocean research institutions, including the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and the Scripps Institution of Oceanography. His early career coincided with Alfred Wegener's continental drift theory, which initially sparked ridicule but Dr. Von Herzen's research validated. As an inventor, Dr. Von Herzen developed modern instruments for measuring deep sea temperatures, enabling extensive readings of heat flow from the Earth's core. His 1960s expeditions revealed significant temperature flows at seabed mountain ranges and low flows at deep ocean trenches.

While your portfolio of American stocks may have recently encountered setbacks, your portfolio of foreign stocks has likely suffered an even more pronounced decline over a longer period. This disparity can be attributed to the US economy's faster growth rate and a stronger dollar, which devalues assets priced in other currencies. However, this trend may soon reverse, and many experts advise investors to prepare for a shift in leadership and a prolonged period of strength in foreign markets. "In the remainder of 2016, investors can expect numerous opportunities in foreign markets, surpassing those in the US," said Komal Sri-Kumar, president of Sri-Kumar Global Strategies. "Foreign markets have historically offered better valuations, and they're correcting more sharply now." Factors such as central banks' interest-rate policies could also boost the prospects for foreign stocks. The Federal Reserve recently raised interest rates for the first time since the financial crisis and signaled further hikes, but the market remains skeptical about the domestic economy's ability to support such aggressive tightening. In contrast, other central banks are adopting a more accommodative stance.

Naked mole rats, once believed to be immune to cancer, have been found to be susceptible to the disease. Researchers had previously reported no instances of cancer in these long-lived rodents, either in the wild or in zoos, and had even injected their cells with viruses that trigger tumors in mice without observing any adverse effects. However, a recent study published in Veterinary Pathology has identified two cases of cancer in naked mole rats housed in zoos. According to Martha Delaney, a veterinary pathologist at the University of Washington School of Medicine and lead author of the study, these cases do not preclude the possibility that naked mole rats may hold a clue to fighting cancer, but rather provide additional insights about what makes them less susceptible to cancer. The discovery of cancer in naked mole rats is significant, as researchers have been studying the rodents for over a decade to understand why they are less prone to cancer. The first case of cancer was identified in a 22-year-old male naked mole rat from the Brookfield Zoo in Chicago, which was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma, a type of cancer that develops from the body's mucus-secreting glands. Now that we have two cases of cancer in naked mole rats, we can study the colonies from which they came to understand why they are more prone to cancer compared to other zoo and research colonies.

David Litt, a former joke writer for President Obama, is joining Funny or Die to poke fun at American politics. As head writer and producer of Funny or Die's Washington operation, Litt will leverage his comedic prowess. Funny or Die's president of production, Mike Farah, describes Litt as "amusing, astoundingly intelligent, and uncannily resembling David Spade in 'Tommy Boy'." Litt, 29, previously served as a special assistant to President Obama and senior presidential speechwriter until his departure on January 23. He scripted a memorable moment at last year's White House Correspondents' Association dinner, where President Obama was joined by comedian Keegan-Michael Key's "anger translator." The video has been viewed over 35 million times on Facebook.

A remarkable cheetah named Chewbaaka has enabled scientists to explore the species' rich and complex history, uncovering clues about their evolution into the world's fastest land animals. Rescued as a 10-day-old orphan in Namibia, Chewbaaka became an ambassador for the Cheetah Conservation Fund, earning his name from a variation of the "Star Wars" character's moniker. Although he passed away five years ago at the remarkable age of 16, twice the average lifespan of a wild cheetah, his genetic legacy continues through his blood samples. Scientists combined his blood with samples from six other cheetahs from Namibia and East Africa to sequence the species' complete genome. Cheetahs, with their striking coats and distinctive "teardrop" markings, captivate tourists on photographic safaris with their remarkable speed, reaching nearly 60 miles per hour. Their unique physiology, featuring elongated legs, an aerodynamic skull, powerful adrenal glands and heart muscles, and claws that grip the earth like football cleats, enables them to achieve such remarkable speeds. Unfortunately, cheetahs are critically endangered, with only around 10,000 individuals remaining, mostly in southern and eastern Africa. A recent genomic analysis has revealed concerning findings: the cheetah has less than 5% of the genomic diversity of other wild cats, a level lower than even inbred domestic dogs and cats, and the lowest among the 30 mammals whose genomes have been sequenced. Genetic diversity in an animal is determined by variations in enzyme genes inherited from its parents and is crucial for its healthy reproduction and immunity to disease.

Sarah Kershaw, a former New York Times journalist, died at her home in Sosua, Dominican Republic, at 49. A plastic bag was found over her head, with pill bottles nearby. Officials await toxicology results to determine the cause of death. According to prosecutor Osvaldo Bonilla, Sarah had planned to take her own life due to illness. Contrary to initial reports, she was not strangled, Bonilla clarified. Her husband, William Paul Norton, was questioned but released without charge. Kershaw started at The Times in 1995 as a news clerk, writing about NYC schools and NJ on a freelance basis. She later covered local news, was promoted to Seattle bureau chief, and wrote for Styles and Real Estate sections.

For over a century, the notion that solving this problem was only a matter of time, yet to be overcome, had persisted. During this period, engineers, inventors, and tinkerers explored various forms of "telemotion," "televista," "photo-telegraph," and "tele-vision" using existing technologies and equipment. As early as 1907, The New York Times published an article on February 24, introducing the concept in its early stages. The article announced the successful transmission of photographs by wire, crediting Dr. Arthur Korn's "telephotograph" invention. According to the reporter, with a few adjustments to the apparatus, "television" or "seeing by telegraph" was just a year or two away. The article featured portraits of five elegantly mustachioed men, transmitted using the new technology, as well as a picture of Dr. Korn himself, sitting beside his "telephotographic apparatus," sporting a healthy mustache.

Fox News secured the highest ratings for a Republican debate since December, with 16.9 million viewers tuning in on Thursday night. The debate marked the first time Donald J. Trump and Megyn Kelly shared the stage since August. Thursday's ratings ranked as the fourth-highest viewership for a debate to date. The numbers significantly surpassed the 12.5 million viewers who watched the late January debate on Fox News, which Mr. Trump had declined to participate in due to Ms. Kelly's involvement. The viewership total also eclipsed the largest audience since CNN's debate in December, which drew over 18 million viewers. Fox News holds the record for the most-watched primary debate, which was its August event that attracted 24 million viewers. The Thursday debate set a new record for live streams, with 1.5 million concurrent streams.

The advertising industry's go-to phrase is "branded content," implying that marketing messages can be subtly delivered by disguising them as entertainment or journalism. Yet, this concept often falls flat, as readers can easily identify forced advertorials and corporate logos, even at high-profile events like South by Southwest. Red Bull Music Academy stands out as an exception. Despite being an energy drink company tied to extreme sports, it has built credibility over 18 years by hosting a respected music festival that attracts renowned musicians. This year, the academy will take place in Montreal, and for the fourth consecutive year, a Red Bull Music Academy festival of live events will be held in New York, featuring an impressive lineup from April 29 to May 22. The festival will include a night of avant-garde jazz with Kamasi Washington, Pharoah Sanders, and the Sun Ra Arkestra, as well as performances by Anohni, Diamanda Galas, Glenn Branca, Dizzee Rascal, and Eddie Palmieri, all of whom are giants in their respective genres.

Universal Studios Hollywood is preparing to launch a massive expansion centered on the popular Harry Potter franchise next month, aiming to attract families and rival nearby Disneyland. The park has unexpectedly announced a surprise addition to its teenage fan base: a permanent "The Walking Dead" attraction is coming to the park. A new haunted house, designed in collaboration with the creative team behind the AMC horror series, will be situated near the new Hogsmeade area and opens this summer. A promotional video showcases a building ablaze and zombies attacking visitors through a chain-link fence. According to Larry Kurzweil, president of Universal Studios Hollywood, the goal is to create a cross-generational experience appealing to a wide range of audiences. This will be a unique, immersive attraction propelling visitors on a thrilling adventure. Fans of "The Walking Dead" have had limited opportunities to participate in simulated invasions and experiences, including temporary mazes during Halloween festivals at Universal parks and a one-time experience at Comic-Con International in San Diego in 2012.

Lloyd S. Shapley, a distinguished mathematician and former UCLA professor, died at 92 in Tucson on Saturday. His son, Peter, verified the news, stating that Shapley had been hospitalized for several weeks after fracturing his hip. Shapley was a prominent figure in game theory, which examines strategic decisions made by competitors in various settings. He is credited with developing the Shapley value, a concept that enables fair benefit allocation among participants based on their relative contributions. Shapley was a close friend and mentor to John Forbes Nash Jr., a fellow mathematician and Nobel laureate who battled schizophrenia. The friendship between Shapley and Nash was documented in Sylvia Nasar's 1998 biography, "A Beautiful Mind," which was adapted into a film in 2001. Nasar, a former New York Times journalist, credited Shapley with proposing the book's title, inspired by his remark that Nash was "obnoxious" but redeemed by his "keen, beautiful, logical mind."
