Scientists forecasted that plants would enhance their respiration by nearly five times as much, grounded in short-term temperature response data from this study and others. Researchers at two Minnesota forest sites tracked the respiration rates of 10 tree species from boreal and temperate forests over three to five years. The trees were subjected to two conditions: ambient temperature and a 6-degree warmer temperature achieved using heating cables. The scientists compared three factors: carbon dioxide release in ambient conditions, carbon dioxide release in the warmer conditions, and carbon dioxide release during short-term exposure to the warmer temperature. The analysis showed that trees acclimated to warmer temperatures increased their carbon dioxide release by a significantly smaller amount than trees exposed to the same short-term temperature increase.

Two weeks after a fatal shooting in a Pittsburgh suburb, local news anchor Wendy Bell posted a Facebook update initially focusing on spreading kindness and hope. However, before moving on to the kindness aspect, she made racial comments that ultimately led to her termination. The shooting, which occurred on March 9 in Wilkinsburg, Pennsylvania, killed five people, including a pregnant woman, and remains unsolved. In her March 21 Facebook post, Bell described the suspects as "young black men, likely in their teens or early 20s" who had been in the system before and were familiar with the police. Bell also praised a hardworking young black man she saw working at a restaurant, but some saw her comments as condescending. Station officials removed her from the air and distanced themselves from her remarks, calling them an "egregious lack of judgment." Bell apologized, acknowledging that some of her words may have been hurtful and could be perceived as racist. A supporter defended her, saying she "spoke the truth." Bell has faced criticism for her comments before, including a 2010 incident where she apologized for remarks perceived as offensive to African-Americans.

A judge's ruling has injected the Hollywood debate on race into a legal framework. Music executive Gerald E. Heller has launched a lawsuit against the creators of "Straight Outta Compton", accusing defamation and rights infringement. Following Judge Michael W. Fitzgerald's decision, Heller can now present his case in court. Heller, a former business partner of N.W.A., claims that Paul Giamatti's depiction of him as a shady and exploitative music manager in the film has harmed his reputation and career.

Andrew Sullivan, a prominent political commentator, has regained prominence as a contributing editor at New York Magazine, where he will write in-depth features on politics and culture and provide commentary on upcoming national conventions. His focus will shift from regular blogging to long-form journalism. Sullivan's new role began on Friday. Prior to this, his personal blog, The Daily Dish, was published rapidly from 2000 onwards and was later hosted by Time magazine, The Atlantic, and The Daily Beast. Sullivan stopped blogging in 2015, citing exhaustion with digital life.

Exxon Mobil and the energy industry faced intense scrutiny on Wednesday following the release of decades-old documents revealing the industry's knowledge of climate change. The documents, published by the Center for International Environmental Law, suggest that the industry understood climate change as far back as 60 years ago. According to Carroll Muffett, the environmental law center's director, Exxon's predecessor, Humble Oil, was aware of rising CO2 levels and global warming potential as early as 1957. The American Petroleum Institute, energy companies, and organizations formed the Smoke and Fumes Committee to monitor pollution research and use science to undermine environmental regulations. Muffett believes the committee's actions would be echoed in later efforts to discredit climate science. The Center for International Environmental Law's work was first reported by Inside Climate News, which has previously published stories suggesting Exxon Mobil understood climate change risks from its own research and used that knowledge to plan activities. Exxon Mobil's own research funded climate denial groups until the mid-2000s. The investigations have led to a surge in activism against the company and energy industry, with the hashtag #exxonknew. Attorneys general, including Eric T. Schneiderman of New York, have demanded information from Exxon about its internal research and funding of climate denial. Inside Climate News announced its article is the first in a series based on the environmental law center's work and documents. Exxon Mobil spokesman Alan Jeffers dismissed the new allegations as absurd. Exxon Mobil is pushing back against an investigation into its knowledge of climate change, claiming the inquiry is not credible. The company is being investigated by four attorneys general, including Claude Earl Walker, the attorney general of the US Virgin Islands, who is working with a private law firm. Exxon Mobil filed a response in Texas, accusing Walker and his team of misusing their power and violating the company's constitutional rights. The company argues it has no physical presence in the Virgin Islands and therefore is not subject to the jurisdiction of the island's courts.

Michael Strahan is leaving "Live with Kelly and Michael" to join "Good Morning America" in September. As a co-anchor on "G.M.A.", he will bring his expertise to the network's flagship morning program. Strahan has been a steady presence on "Live" since 2012, contributing to the valuable ABC programming asset. He may now be tasked with maintaining "Good Morning America's" momentum, as the show leads "Today" in overall viewership but trails in the key 25-to-54-year-old demographic.

In the live music industry, promoters and venues are embroiled in a constant battle over ticketing agreements. Companies discreetly negotiate for ticket sales and valuable customer data. Pandora Media's $450 million acquisition of Ticketfly marked a significant turning point in the industry. Ticketfly competes with Ticketmaster to secure partnerships with clubs and theaters, boasting over 1,200 clients. The company has secured a deal to become the exclusive ticketing provider for the Bowery Ballroom and the Mercury Lounge. Both venues, previously partnered with Ticketmaster, will switch to Ticketfly on Sunday. This deal represents a major triumph for Ticketfly, expanding its presence in New York City. The Bowery Ballroom attracts around 130,000 attendees annually, while the Mercury Lounge draws around 80,000. The agreement also expands Ticketfly's presence in New York City, where it already works with popular venues such as Central Park SummerStage, Forest Hills Stadium, Brooklyn Bowl, Output, and Birdland. The deal will not affect Bowery Presents' talks to be acquired by AEG Live.

Rovio, the developer behind Angry Birds, is urging moviegoers to use their smartphones at the theater. To promote the US release of "The Angry Birds Movie" on Friday, Rovio is offering bonus content in its new mobile game, Angry Birds Action, to those who open the app during the movie's credits. This cross-platform marketing strategy is part of Rovio's efforts to revitalize its Angry Birds brand and become a global media powerhouse. The original Angry Birds game, released in 2009, was a massive hit, but sales have slowed in recent years, leading the company to diversify into consumer products and reduce its reliance on mobile games. Despite these efforts, Rovio reported a 13 million euro loss in 2015. The company's desire to evolve beyond apps led to the development of "The Angry Birds Movie", according to Tuomo Korpinen, president of Rovio Animation and former DreamWorks Animation executive. "We needed to compete with the best in the industry, like Disney, Pixar, and DreamWorks," Korpinen said.

The evolution of the Internet parallels that of the Weblog, Electronic Message, and World Wide Web. The New York Times has announced that it will adopt the same lowercase naming convention as The Associated Press for the global network that has become an integral part of our daily routines. The network, accessible through our pockets and screens, keeps us hooked on various feeds, much like lab rats pressing a lever to receive a reward. The changes will take effect at both news outlets on June 1, explaining why "internet" remains capitalized throughout this article. In a memo to the newsroom, Jill Taylor acknowledged that it may take some time to break the habit of capitalizing the word "internet". The Times' decision follows The A.P.'s announcement in April, made during the American Copy Editors Society conference, where grammar enthusiasts, punctuation aficionados, and syntax aficionados gather to discuss the latest guidelines for American journalism.

Shanghai's tumultuous week for Disney's CEO Robert A. Iger began with a tour of the soon-to-open Shanghai Disneyland. A mass shooting in Orlando, Florida, however, drastically altered his mood, prompting him to bolster security at Walt Disney World, issue a statement expressing his heartbreak, and pledge a $1 million donation to the victims. Despite the tragedy, the Shanghai Disneyland show proceeded as planned. On Tuesday, Iger attended a festive event to celebrate the launch of an all-Mandarin version of Disney's "Lion King" stage musical, surrounded by enthusiastic lieutenants. The next morning, Iger appeared relaxed at a news conference attended by around 800 journalists. However, by Wednesday, more devastating news from Florida reached China: an alligator had dragged a toddler into a lake at a Disney World hotel, and the child was later presumed dead. Iger issued a statement from Shanghai, expressing his condolences to the Graves family. The unveiling of the Shanghai Disneyland nightly fireworks show was ultimately canceled due to a rainstorm on Wednesday night.

Dweezil Zappa, a guitarist and son of rock legend Frank Zappa, has rebranded his project three times. Initially, he called it Zappa Plays Zappa, a tribute to his father's music, but later renamed it Dweezil Zappa Plays Frank Zappa to avoid legal issues with his brother Ahmet. After another dispute, Dweezil is rebranding the show once more. His upcoming tour, starting July 1 in El Prado, New Mexico, will be called "50 Years of Frank: Dweezil Zappa Plays Whatever the Heck He Wants -- The Cease and Desist Tour." The tour's name acknowledges the absurdity of the situation and the 50-year anniversary of his father's debut album "Freak Out!" by the Mothers of Invention. The Zappa brothers, once musical partners, have been estranged since their mother's passing last year. The Zappa Family Trust now has two trustees, Ahmet and Diva Zappa, with Dweezil and his sister Moon as beneficiaries. Frank Zappa passed away in 1993.

On March 3, two armed men stormed the home of Berta Caceres, a prominent Honduran environmental activist, and took her life. She had fiercely opposed the Agua Zarca Dam's construction on ancestral Lenca land for years. According to Global Witness, Caceres was one of 185 environmental activists brutally murdered in 16 countries over the past year, a 59% increase from 2014, the highest recorded rate since 2002. The environment has become a new battleground in the fight for human rights, says Billy Kyte, author of the report.

Fourteen pigs, fitted with lab-grown bone, surprisingly thrived. The unexpected outcome was a welcome surprise, given their unusual implants. According to Dr. Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic, a biomedical engineering professor at Columbia University, the pigs' recovery was remarkable. The pigs awoke and, within half an hour, were eating normally, a stark contrast to expectations. "We expected them to be in pain, but instead, they're doing extremely well," Dr. Vunjak-Novakovic explained. The researchers successfully created living bone from stem cells by crafting a "scaffold" from cow bone, immersing it in a nutrient solution with stem cells, and allowing the cells to attach and form a new bone identical to the original. The new bone was then implanted into each pig. Their findings were published in Science Translational Medicine.

In 2014, a significant milestone was reached when the US student body, spanning kindergarten to 12th grade, became predominantly minority. This demographic shift is already evident in colleges and universities nationwide, with the Census Bureau forecasting that the entire nation will follow suit by 2050. As I reflect on these changes, I am left pondering whether our college and university faculties are adequately equipped to teach a diverse student body. Unfortunately, I believe they are not. Faculty members often receive limited training on teaching and even less on diversity and inclusion issues, creating a concerning situation for future learning. For nearly two decades, I have been studying innovative strategies employed by minority-serving institutions to promote student success. In my latest book, "Educating a Diverse Nation" (Harvard University Press), co-authored with Clifton Conrad, we outline the lessons from MSIs that all faculty members can apply to their teaching practices. These institutions assume students' potential for success, rather than viewing students of color through a deficit lens. They also teach in a way that focuses on students' needs, rather than the professor's convenience. Furthermore, MSI faculty members collaborate to develop curricula, empower students, and provide culturally relevant assignments that connect to students' communities.

The campus rape issue is receiving long-overdue attention, yet efforts to address it are faltering due to widespread uncertainty about the university's response to sexual assault. Higher education institutions cannot replicate the criminal justice system or civil justice system, as they have distinct interests. Universities must prioritize creating a safe and inclusive learning environment, free from sex-based discrimination. This core mission should drive comprehensive institutional reform. Colleges have a responsibility to foster an environment where all students can learn, which involves preventing sexual assault and gender-based misconduct. The goal is not to burden women with prevention by teaching them how to behave, but rather to eradicate gender violence and the racism and sexism that perpetuate it.

For those who put teaching others first, the weight of college debt can be suffocating, hindering the pursuit of a well-educated and globally competitive workforce in America. To make higher education more accessible, we must address the staggering debt accumulated by millions of American students and their families. The American Federation of Teachers has launched student debt clinics to support its members, offering valuable insights on income-based student loan repayment programs and Public Service Loan Forgiveness. These 90-minute sessions have been transformative for some participants. The A.F.T. is at the forefront of the fight against predatory lending practices, warning students and their families about the risks associated with for-profit educational providers, servicers, and lenders, while educating them on repayment options and empowering a new generation of advocates to combat the national student debt crisis. A young adjunct professor from Miami attended an A.F.T. debt clinic, feeling overwhelmed by her $168,000 student loan debt and monthly payments exceeding $2,000. After applying for income-based repayment, she reduced her monthly payment to $700. By sharing her story, she discovered the courage to reveal that it was the first good night's sleep she'd had in three years. Today, she is a trainer herself, guiding others through the process of debt relief.

The Supreme Court's potential reversal of its 2003 Grutter v. Bollinger ruling would have far-reaching and devastating consequences. California's experience over the past two decades serves as a stark warning, with the ban on affirmative action in 1997 leading to a significant decline in African-American students at Berkeley and UCLA. Prior to the ban, the incoming classes at these institutions were roughly 8% African-American, compared to 4.3% at UCLA and 2.8% at Berkeley last year. Meanwhile, the percentage of black college-age residents in California remained unchanged. This stark reality underscores the impact of California's ban, which resulted from a ballot initiative. Despite ongoing debate, few dispute the importance of diversity in generating innovative ideas, and without a diverse student body and faculty, universities will struggle to achieve excellence. Without considering race in admissions, achieving diversity will become unattainable. Preserving consideration of race in admissions is crucial, but insufficient. The court and society must confront the broader question: whether our institutions of higher education will be enlisted in the pursuit of a racially integrated society that transcends our nation's legacy of slavery, Jim Crow, and segregation.

Researchers in the Netherlands have identified a special oil produced by swordfish, which they believe is responsible for the fish's remarkable speed. The oil is secreted by a gland at the base of the swordfish's sword and is distributed through a network of tiny blood vessels to pores on its head. This unique oil is only found on the fish's head, not its body. According to the study's lead author, this waterproof lubrication may provide a smooth, water-resistant coating for the fish's head, allowing it to achieve remarkable speeds.

A Delaware judge has ordered a trial on October 17 in a lawsuit over the replacement of five Viacom directors, with the possibility of an independent medical evaluation of 93-year-old Sumner M. Redstone, who is in poor health. The case's high stakes are due to Redstone's holding company, National Amusements, controlling 80% of Viacom and CBS's voting shares. A Massachusetts judge has scheduled an October trial to question Redstone's mental competence to make business decisions, while a California judge has set a tentative hearing for October 18 to address the future of his business estate. The prospect of multiple trials could increase the incentive for the parties to resolve their disputes outside of court. It is unclear whether settlement talks are underway.

Frank Palopoli, a celebrated chemist who led the team behind Clomid, the world's most widely prescribed fertility medication for women, has died at 94 in Montgomery, Ohio, due to heart failure, according to his son. For nearly five decades, millions of women have successfully conceived thanks to clomiphene citrate, a relatively affordable medication introduced by the William S. Merrell Company as Clomid in 1967. Under Mr. Palopoli's guidance and his team's expertise in organic chemistry, the researchers synthesized and patented the pill, now widely available in generic and branded forms, including Serophene. Notably, among women with ovulation failure as their sole infertility issue, approximately 80% of those who take Clomid typically ovulate and can conceive naturally or through assisted reproductive technologies.

A presidential forum on NBC, featuring Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump, drew nearly 15 million viewers on Wednesday, exceeding many primary debates in terms of viewership, according to Nielsen statistics. This significant audience is a welcome development for television executives, who expect record-breaking ratings for this fall's presidential debates. However, it may have had a negative impact on... 

The live broadcast from the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in Manhattan aired on MSNBC and NBC affiliate channels, featuring memorable moments, including Mr. Trump's praise for Russian President Vladimir V. Putin. Despite this, Mr. Lauer's perceived errors, including accusations of carelessness and unfairness, dominated headlines on Thursday. Mrs. Clinton's team sent out a fundraising email with the subject line "Matt Lauer," highlighting a moment during the forum when Mr. Lauer failed to correct a false claim made by Mr. Trump about his stance on the Iraq War.

As we revel in the excitement of a roller coaster ride, we often anticipate certain physical sensations: a jolt in the stomach, a surge in heart rate, and a tingling sensation in fingertips. For some, this may be accompanied by other symptoms: sudden back pain, a kick in the lower abdomen, or an urgent need to use the restroom. These sensations are reminiscent of those experienced by individuals who have passed a kidney stone. Researchers created a silicone cast of the inside of a kidney to study the effects of roller coasters on kidney stones. The study found that moderate-intensity, rattling roller coasters may dislodge small kidney stones in the outer ducts of the kidney and propel them towards the ureter. The study suggests that riding these roller coasters could be a potential treatment for patients with kidney stones five millimeters or less in diameter. A patient's passing of kidney stones after each of three consecutive rides on the Big Thunder Mountain Railroad roller coaster inspired the study. Dr. Wartinger and Dr. Mitchell created a 3D-printed silicone cast of a patient's kidney, filled it with kidney stones and urine, and rode the roller coaster 20 times, observing the movement of the kidney stones. The back of a roller coaster is a more effective spot to dislodge a small kidney stone, with a success rate of 64% compared to 17% at the front. Each year, over 300,000 Americans seek emergency care for kidney stones, often due to severe pain caused by a large stone lodged in their ureter. However, it's unlikely that a roller coaster ride would provide relief for those with larger stones. Dr. Borin notes that this study is specifically designed for individuals with small kidney stones. If you're aware of having a small kidney stone and are interested in trying the roller coaster method, it's recommended that you consult with your urologist. You might be able to eliminate your kidney stone while also having a thrilling experience – a true case of "killing two birds with one stone."

The audience for Tuesday's vice-presidential debate between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine was significantly smaller than the viewership for last week's presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. Nielsen reported that around 37 million Americans watched the debate, a decline from the 84 million viewers who tuned in to the previous debate. Despite being viewed as a relatively tame affair, the debate between Pence and Kaine proved to be more lively than anticipated. It is now expected to be the lowest-rated vice-presidential debate since 2000, when Dick Cheney and Joseph Lieberman faced off.

A study reveals that primates can decipher human intentions. Researchers from Kyoto University and Duke University conducted an experiment where chimpanzees, bonobos, and orangutans watched a video featuring an actor and a King Kong impersonator hiding an object. The actor left, and King Kong took the object. Upon the actor's return, the researchers tracked the apes' gaze to monitor their attention. The findings showed that the apes accurately predicted the actor's next move, anticipating him to approach the spot where he last saw the object. Despite knowing the object was gone, the apes appeared to understand the actor's mistaken assumption and recognized it as incorrect.

The New York Times Company is embracing the digital age by shifting its focus to lifestyle journalism, introducing online products such as Cooking, Watching, and Well. The company has made a strategic move into service journalism with the acquisition of The Wirecutter, a product recommendation website, and its sister site, The Sweethome, for over $30 million in cash. The acquisition, worth slightly more than $30 million, was completed on Monday. CEO Mark Thompson said, "The Wirecutter and The Sweethome's practical approach to product recommendations aligns with our newsroom's values and standards." Founded in 2011 by technology journalist Brian Lam, The Wirecutter provides in-depth reviews of gadgets and electronics, while The Sweethome focuses on home products. Initially published as part of The Awl network, The Wirecutter aimed to offer practical product reviews.

Jann S. Wenner, founder and owner of Rolling Stone, defended the magazine in a federal court libel trial in Charlottesville, Virginia, claiming the publication was incorrect to fully retract a 2014 article about a gang rape at the University of Virginia. Wenner contended that much of the article's material was accurate and that the magazine adhered to high journalistic standards in investigating the allegations. He argued that the magazine focused on verifying the accuser's account, known as Jackie, rather than confronting the accused rapists. Wenner attributed some blame to Jackie, whose story began to unravel after the article's publication. He said that journalists are powerless to stop individuals determined to commit fraud and disagreed with the decision to retract the entire article in response to a critical report by The Columbia Journalism Review in 2015. While acknowledging that the magazine retracted specific allegations made by Jackie, Wenner believed that the bulk of the article, detailing ways to improve the University of Virginia's handling of sexual assault cases, remained valid.

After graduating, Christopher Gray became the CEO of his first job. Growing up as the son of a single mother who lost her job during the recession, Gray knew he needed significant financial aid to fund his college education. After a seven-month search, Gray successfully raised $1.3 million by applying for and reusing essays on leadership and community service, while avoiding scams. At Drexel University in Philadelphia, Gray turned his experience into a social enterprise, developing an app called Scholly that matches students with personalized lists of scholarships. Scholly quickly rose to the top of the iOS App Store after Gray pitched it on "Shark Tank." In just three years, Scholly has been downloaded over a million times and has helped students secure more than $50 million in scholarships. Now 25, Gray has been recognized as one of Forbes's "30 Under 30" and Oprah Winfrey's "SuperSoul 100." Gray initially felt the need to leave his hometown to pursue a career in technology entrepreneurship, driven by his desire to break the cycle of poverty and create a better life for his younger brother and sister. Gray's success has been both surreal and emotional, as he has been able to achieve his goal of helping a large number of people. Initially, Gray's goal was not to become a billionaire, but rather to make a positive impact on his community. During his time at Drexel, Gray was surrounded by students from diverse backgrounds, including those from affluent families who still required financial assistance to pursue their academic goals.

The classic song "We Shall Overcome" is embroiled in a potential court dispute over its copyright validity. As a powerful symbol of the civil rights movement, the song has been reinvigorated at candlelight vigils across the US in response to gun violence. This case joins ongoing disputes over "Happy Birthday to You" and "This Land Is Your Land" in highlighting the ongoing struggle to strike a balance between intellectual property rights and public access to historic songs with unclear origins. The lawsuit, filed by the We Shall Overcome Foundation and joined by the producers of "Lee Daniels' The Butler," contends that the song, rooted in a 19th-century black spiritual, should be declared public domain property.

The New Jersey State government has issued a warning against consuming fish and shellfish from the Lower Passaic River and Newark Bay due to the presence of toxic pollutants in the water. The Diamond Alkali Superfund Site, a former chemical production facility, has contaminated the surrounding waterways, allowing toxic substances to seep into aquatic animals' bodies. Despite the toxic environment, some aquatic animals have miraculously survived, including the Atlantic killifish, a small, silver fish that has adapted to thrive in this polluted ecosystem. According to a recent study published in Science, the killifish's ability to survive in polluted waters is a remarkable example of evolutionary adaptation. Researchers first discovered the fish's tolerance to toxic waters in the late 1990s and have since found that distinct populations of killifish have independently developed similar genetic adaptations to survive in highly polluted areas along the Atlantic coastline. The new study reveals that evolution can occur independently in different populations and that similar genetic changes can emerge in response to extreme environments. According to biologist Diane Nacci at the Environmental Protection Agency, the study provides a valuable example of how animals can adapt to rapidly changing environments. Researchers led by evolutionary geneticist Noah Reid at the University of Connecticut analyzed the genomes of 384 killifish from polluted and less-polluted areas, finding that a single genetic pathway was responsible for the pollution tolerance in all regions, with slightly different patterns of genetic changes in each population.

As winter approaches, envision the thrill of diving with sardines in the Philippines. Book a trip with a local dive shop and prepare for an unforgettable adventure. The boat will transport you just offshore, and you'll dive in to witness the breathtaking spectacle of "fish clouds" above. For the best view, consider an early morning dive, as the sardines are present daily. Unlike the renowned sardines in South Africa, the Philippine sardines are a year-round attraction. The sardines' unique schooling behavior, known as a "bait ball," may confound predators and aid their survival. However, it's not foolproof, as a 2010 video showed a thresher shark using its tail to stun and devour the sardines. The sardines' presence near Cebu's beaches remains an enigma, as they were previously unknown in the area until recently. According to Dr. Oliver, the science on the populations of these fish is lacking, and it's unclear why they've emerged in such numbers. The sardines may not be permanent residents, but Dr. Oliver believes they've found a niche in the area. It's possible that a small number of eggs drifted into the waters and thrived due to the presence of few predators and ideal conditions. The sardines appear to migrate between locations, such as Pescador Island and Moalboal's shores. If this setup were to change, they may disappear forever.

Warner Bros. is defying the common pattern of leadership changes in Hollywood, which often occur when profits decline. Despite this, the studio is on track for one of its most lucrative years ever, according to financial reports. Warner has just released "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" to massive success, and its market share of 18% this year trails only Walt Disney Studios' 24%. Warner has had successes like "Fantastic Beasts," "Mad Max: Fury Road," and "The Lego Movie," but also critically panned films like "Pan," "Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice," and "Suicide Squad." CEO Kevin Tsujihara has been patient with the studio's struggles, but has recently reduced former president Toby Emmerich's role in superhero film production, giving oversight to Jon Berg and Geoff Johns instead. The pipeline of upcoming films left behind by Emmerich includes potential hits like "The Lego Batman Movie," "King Arthur: Legend of the Sword," and "Ready Player One." Emmerich's departure has been expected, as he has been looking to pursue new opportunities and wants to focus on his entrepreneurial ventures. Meanwhile, Emmerich's New Line division has had a string of successes, including "The Conjuring 2," "Lights Out," "Central Intelligence," and "Creed." Emmerich oversaw the production of Warner's high-profile "Hobbit" film series, which he is leaving behind to focus on his entrepreneurial ventures.

Dr. Tarduno's team published their research in Scientific Reports, which challenges the prevailing theory that the Earth's atmosphere was dominated by heat-trapping carbon dioxide during the Cretaceous period. The greenhouse effect would have drastically altered the polar ecosystem, allowing species like Tingmiatornis arctica and its prey to thrive. The Turonian age, a period of intense warming, occurred between 93.9 million and 89.8 million years ago, with the Arctic reaching temperatures of around 57 degrees Fahrenheit at its coldest. Dr. Tarduno discovered two wing bones belonging to Tingmiatornis arctica in Nunavut's snow-capped hills and glaciers. Initially, he found a small humerus in 1999, but it didn't spark much interest. However, the discovery of a larger humerus a few years later piqued his interest. Although the second humerus didn't initially capture his attention, Dr. Tarduno and his team were distracted by a large turtle shell found on the same rock. "We took it back to camp and realized, 'Wait a minute, there's another incredible fossil on the other side,' " Dr. Tarduno recalled.

The world of "Game of Thrones" is set to hit the big screen at a theater near you. Later this month, the show's beloved characters will take over 150 Imax theaters across the country, featuring an exclusive trailer for the upcoming season and the final two episodes of the previous season. This marks a groundbreaking moment, as "Game of Thrones" becomes the first television series to be shown on Imax screens. The event runs from January 23rd to 29th, with tickets going on sale soon. This move underscores the blurring of lines between media platforms, where content can be streamed seamlessly across a variety of devices. It also highlights the efforts of media companies to transform their hit shows into massive events, as drawing large audiences becomes increasingly difficult. For Imax, this is part of a broader strategy to expand its programming beyond traditional films, as the North American box office struggles with declining sales. The company has already explored showing other TV series and has tested technologies for screening live sports and music concerts.

A representative for Jay Z and his company, Panther, shared insights into his thought process, highlighting the potential for increased entertainment consumption and enhanced artist promotion through streaming. Panther's strategic objective is to expand globally and scale up Aspiro's platform, technology, and services to meet growing demand. Jay Z's interest in Aspiro may stem from his desire to tap into the niche market of high-fidelity digital music and capitalize on the growing trend. Aspiro's WiMP and Tidal services offer lossless audio formats significantly higher in quality than those of Spotify and most other streaming services. WiMP boasts 512,000 paying subscribers, according to Aspiro's latest quarterly report, while Tidal's customer numbers remain undisclosed, despite charging $20 per month, twice the average rate of most streaming services. The number of companies offering high-quality digital audio has increased recently, including Tidal, WiMP, Deezer's Elite version, PonoPlayer, and Sony's high-resolution Walkman, priced over $1,000. However, analysts note that consumers have shown little interest in these products, despite their high quality. For Jay Z, another potential motivation for acquiring a streaming service may be to expand the media portfolio of Roc Nation, which began as a music-focused joint venture with Live Nation Entertainment in 2008 and has since expanded to represent top athletes.

The Super Bowl XLIX advertising lesson is clear: ads featuring puppies are a hit, while ads tackling sensitive topics like a deceased child face backlash. Budweiser's heartwarming spot showcasing its iconic Clydesdale horses rescuing a lost puppy dominated Super Bowl advertising. The ad racked up over 4.2 million online views by Monday morning, accounting for 12% of online activity surrounding the Super Bowl ads. Budweiser's social media presence surged, with over 234,000 mentions, 45% of which were positive. In stark contrast, Nationwide's commercial featuring a young boy who dies in a preventable accident sparked widespread criticism. The ad generated over 238,000 social media mentions, with 64% of comments being negative. Nationwide defended the ad, stating it aimed to initiate a conversation about safety and well-being, not to sell insurance. Procter & Gamble's Always commercial explored what it means to "do something like a girl." The ad highlighted how girls often lose confidence after puberty and showed little girls answering the question with confidence and strength. The Always spot captured 8.6% of online activity and 1.6 million viewers. NBC aired 48 minutes of commercials during Sunday's game, with approximately seven minutes dedicated to promoting the network's own programming. The game featured ads from 15 first-time Super Bowl advertisers. Amobee awarded Skittles the "Rookie of the Year" title, as the brand generated over 85,000 social media mentions, more than triple the amount of some other newcomers. Skittles' humorous commercial received a boost when Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch was spotted eating the rainbow-colored candy just before the game started.

The New School is adopting a holistic approach to combat climate change, encompassing measures such as streamlining clothing production to reduce waste and transportation, and designing urban spaces to withstand extreme weather events. An internal audit will be conducted to identify ways to minimize its carbon footprint, energy expenses, and paper usage and waste. The institution plans to promote sustainable food services by partnering with local Hudson Valley suppliers, collaborating with environmental advocate Bill McKibben on this initiative. According to Tokumbo Shobowale, the New School's chief operating officer, addressing climate change requires a multifaceted strategy. By integrating climate change into the curriculum across all disciplines, the school aims to go beyond divestment, which initially faced skepticism from some faculty members. Divestment can serve as a teaching tool, as economics students analyze the practices of companies in the school's $340 million endowment to develop principles that add nuance to their investment decisions.

Richard Meryman, a former writer and editor at Life magazine, passed away on February 5 in Manhattan at the age of 88. His wife, Elizabeth, confirmed that pneumonia was the cause of death. Meryman's career was distinguished by numerous achievements, including his intimate portrait of reclusive artist Andrew Wyeth, his collaboration with Joan Rivers on a memoir about her quest for stardom, and his own emotional journey after the death of his first wife.

Meryman's entry into journalism was sparked by an adventure story he shared at his first job interview with Life magazine in 1949. He had just returned from a cross-country trip with two college friends, including future Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, which began in a 1935 Packard hearse and ended with the trio hopping freight trains back home.

Meryman went on to become Life magazine's first human affairs editor, writing profiles of extraordinary people in everyday life. His subjects included a struggling family on Chicago's South Side and a single mother giving up her baby for adoption. Meryman was one of the first writers to use a tape recorder, conducting interviews with notable figures such as Ingmar Bergman, Charlie Chaplin, Marilyn Horne, Paul McCartney, Laurence Olivier, and Elizabeth Taylor.

Meryman's most famous interview was with Marilyn Monroe, which appeared in Life magazine on August 3, 1962, just two days before her death at the age of 36. The eight-hour conversation, recorded on tape, later became the basis for the 1992 HBO program "Marilyn: The Last Interview."

E! has agreed to pay a substantial amount to continue airing "Keeping Up With the Kardashians" for three more years. The network has reportedly reached a deal with the Kardashian family to extend the show's run, although the exact terms remain confidential. The reported deal worth over $100 million over four years was denied by a NBCUniversal Cable spokesperson, who described the claim as "grossly inaccurate". Industry insiders expect a significant payment due to the family's widespread popularity and influence. Despite this, E!'s prime-time ratings for the 18-49 age demographic decreased by 10% in 2014, averaging 386,000 viewers per year.

When Mr. Pizzolo uploaded his comic series "Godkiller" to YouTube, he was surprised by the large and untapped audience that eagerly consumed the content. The series, which follows siblings in a post-apocalyptic world, garnered 100,000 views without any promotional efforts. Following its release on Netflix, Hulu, and PlayStation, it attracted tens of thousands more viewers. According to Mr. Pizzolo, it's essential to cater to both core comic book fans and new audiences. The inaugural series on the YouTube channel will feature a mix of comics from Black Mask and other independent publishers, including "Liberator," which focuses on animal welfare activists, and "Five Ghosts," which follows an adventurer possessed by literary characters. The channel will include links to purchase the comics and related merchandise.

Black Mask Studios was founded in 2012 by Mr. Pizzolo, a filmmaker, Steve Niles, a writer of horror novels and comics, and Brett Gurewitz, a musician and founder of Epitaph Records. The company was born out of "Occupy Comics," a project aimed at raising funds for the Occupy Wall Street movement. This experience highlighted the challenges of publishing comics with a message. With the upcoming release of the animated version of "Godkiller" and "Liberator," Black Mask will have a broader platform to share its message. Before the International Comic Con in July, the company will release the first part of the animated "Godkiller." Kirkus Reviews has praised the comic's first volume, describing it as "wickedly delectable" and "an experience rather than a story." Black Mask is also developing three comic-based TV series: "Sinatoro," "The Disciples," and "Ballistic." Despite its small size, with only a handful of employees and freelancers, the company remains committed to its mission. Black Mask operates like a startup, with a scrappy and entrepreneurial spirit. As executive producers, we ensure that the creators of the comics are involved throughout the process. Historically, film and TV executives would often use comic books as a starting point and then depart from the original material, but now we're seeing a trend towards more faithful adaptations, which is a direct result of our hands-on approach.

Jay Z's investment vehicle, Project Panther Bidco, has acquired Swedish tech company Aspiro for $56 million. Aspiro operates subscription streaming services under WiMP and Tidal brands, which debuted in the US last fall. Jay Z made the offer through Project Panther Bidco in late January. The acquisition is now unconditional, with Project Panther set to complete the purchase of tendered shares. As a result, Aspiro will be removed from the Nasdaq Stockholm stock exchange. Jay Z has not disclosed further plans for Aspiro, but his interest in the company may be linked to its high-definition audio capabilities.

Five decades have elapsed since Dustin Hoffman's character received the iconic "one word" advice about the future in "The Graduate". It's overdue to revisit the script and adapt it for the contemporary era. Metamaterials have the capacity to transform entire industries, just as "The Graduate" could be updated for modern audiences. Over the past 15 years, scientists have made substantial progress in creating materials that can manipulate light, radar, radio, sound, and seismic waves in ways that contravene natural laws. The concept of metamaterials was first proposed by Russian physicist Victor Veselago in 1967 and later developed by physicist David R. Smith and his team in 1999. Initially, it was viewed as a curiosity with potential applications in science fiction, such as invisibility cloaks. However, researchers have since gained a deeper understanding of the science and are now driving innovation in various fields, including radio antennas, radar, cosmetics, soundproofing, and earthquake-resistant construction. Most recently, Airbus collaborated with Lamda Guard to test a metamaterial-based coating for cockpit windows, designed to protect pilots from laser pointer attacks.

HarperCollins has unveiled the cover for Harper Lee's highly anticipated new novel, "Go Set a Watchman", giving a glimpse into the book's themes and story. The cover art depicts a dark tree with sparse yellow leaves against a dusky blue sky, with a train approaching from the distance, mirroring the novel's opening scene. The novel, set for release on July 14 with a first printing of two million copies, has generated significant buzz, with preorders selling briskly since its announcement in early February. The book's release has sparked controversy among literary scholars and those close to the reclusive author. Set in the 1950s, 20 years after the events of "To Kill a Mockingbird", "Go Set a Watchman" follows Scout as she travels to Maycomb to visit her aging father, Atticus Finch. The characters and setting may be familiar to fans of "To Kill a Mockingbird", but the two novels have little overlap, according to Lee's publisher and literary agent. The cover, designed by Jarrod Taylor, reflects Scout's journey home, according to Michael Morrison, president and publisher of HarperCollins.

Jeremy Clarkson's tenure with the BBC has reached its conclusion. The renowned presenter of the automotive-themed programme "Top Gear" will not have his contract extended when it expires at the end of March, according to the BBC. This decision follows an alleged incident in which Clarkson, 54, purportedly verbally and physically assaulted a BBC producer, Oisin Tymon, after a late-night drinking session at a Yorkshire hotel. Tymon received medical treatment but has declined to pursue legal action. Clarkson was suspended on March 10, leading to the postponement of the final three episodes of the current season of "Top Gear".

I stared at the card, confused by the unexpected turn of events. Hadn't I agreed to a different plan? I must have signed up for a lower rate. At 24, earning under $30,000 a year in 2000, the American Airlines Citibank Card was my first credit card, and I was thrilled. Its sleek, silver design with the vintage airline logo seemed to foretell the financial journey ahead. The marketing slogans echoed in my mind: "Earn miles!" "Live like others in New York!" "Welcome, young one." I couldn't recall the credit limit, only what I'd bought. I'd splurged on a stunning gold, strapless Nicole Miller dress, gold sandals, and a filmy wrap for a glamorous friend's sister's wedding. I'd also gotten a haircut inspired by Meg Ryan's character in "You've Got Mail." The total cost was around $1,000, far exceeding the budget my stepfather had helped me create, which I promptly ignored. Instead, I learned a valuable lesson about debt, confidence, and identity that still resonates with me today. Growing up, I was privileged, attending Sidwell Friends, a prestigious private Quaker school in Washington, and later Williams College in Massachusetts, where my family covered the tuition. As a result, I was financially sheltered, and my parents allowed me to focus on academics and personal growth, for which I was grateful.

HBO, a leading premium entertainment network, is enhancing its partnership with Vice, a trailblazing media company and news organization. The company has unveiled a daily half-hour Vice news program, airing five days a week for 48 weeks annually, commencing this year. According to Richard Plepler, HBO's CEO, the newscast is scheduled to premiere this year. For Vice, this agreement represents a substantial upgrade of its collaboration with a respected and successful media brand, which earned Vice an Emmy award last year. In return, HBO will acquire a substantial amount of fresh content as it prepares to launch its standalone streaming service, HBO Now. "This is one of our largest investments in terms of airtime," said Michael Lombardo, HBO's president of programming. "I've been with HBO for a long time, and I can't think of another producer we've worked with who will have this much visibility on our network."

A study suggests that Little Foot, an ancient hominid, may have coexisted with Lucy, a renowned human ancestor, during the same era. Research in Nature reveals that early hominids were more diverse than previously thought. Initially estimated to be 4 million years old, Little Foot's age was later revised to around 2.2 million years through mineral analysis. Scientists initially disagreed on Little Foot's age, but an international team has now used a dating method to determine the fossil is approximately 3.67 million years old, roughly half a million years older than Lucy.

Davidson College students have enjoyed a unique perk for 95 years - their dirty laundry is washed, folded, and pressed for free. Introduced in 1920, the benefit was a response to the all-male student body's formal dress code. According to Jan Blodgett, the college archivist, the laundry service has been a beloved tradition ever since. However, this perk will end next month. While freshmen appreciate the convenience, only about a third of seniors use the service. The decline is attributed to the abundance of free laundry machines on campus. By discontinuing the service, the college expects to save $400,000 per year, which it will redirect towards educational initiatives.

James Oseland, former editor-in-chief of Saveur, shared a memorable dinner with Maria Rodale, CEO of Rodale, at ABC Kitchen near Union Square, where they coincidentally met celebrated chef Alice Waters, a pioneer of sustainable food. Oseland described the encounter as a remarkable sign, while Rodale recalled him exclaiming it was like receiving a blessing from the pope. Almost eight months after Oseland's unexpected departure from Saveur to join Rodale, the publisher is launching a new magazine, Organic Life, which rebrands Rodale's Organic Gardening. This revamped publication will focus on the organic lifestyle, encompassing food, wellness, and home living. Over the past five to 10 years, a significant shift has taken place, yet there was no single, comprehensive media brand catering to the growing demand for this type of content. Organic Gardening was a beloved brand, and our goal is to build upon its success and make it even more comprehensive.

Celebrity talk show host Dr. Mehmet Oz is expected to vigorously respond to criticism from doctors who have questioned his medical expertise and faculty position at Columbia University, according to a show spokesperson. Ten physicians recently sent an email to the university, accusing Dr. Oz of lacking integrity by promoting unproven treatments and cures for personal gain. The doctors specifically targeted Dr. Oz's opposition to genetically modified food crops, which they deemed baseless and relentless. Dr. Oz will address the criticism on his syndicated daytime talk show, "The Dr. Oz Show," on Thursday, questioning the credibility of the letter's authors, some of whom have ties to a pro-industry advocacy group that supports genetically modified foods. He will also reiterate his stance that genetically modified foods should be labeled, a position he has repeatedly expressed on his show. The segment is expected to be longer than usual, taking up a significant portion of the 60-minute program.

Richard Corliss, a renowned film critic who wrote for Time magazine for 35 years, died on Thursday in Manhattan at the age of 71. His wife, Mary, attributed his death to complications from a stroke, which he had been receiving hospice care for. Corliss was a prolific contributor to Time, writing profiles, essays on popular culture, and reviews of television and theater productions. A self-proclaimed movie enthusiast who believed every film was worth watching, Corliss often said, "Everything is worth seeing." However, he wasn't afraid to take a contrarian view as a critic, and his reviews weren't always glowing. He was particularly critical of films like Robert Altman's "M*A*S*H," James Cameron's "Titanic," Richard Attenborough's "A Chorus Line," and the British comedy "The Full Monty," which he deemed formulaic and emotionally manipulative. In his "Titanic" review, Corliss praised the film's special effects but panned its storytelling, predicting the film would be a commercial failure, calling it "dead in the water."

Thomas R. Shepard Jr., the last publisher of Look magazine, has died at 96 in Sarasota, Florida, on April 29, due to pneumonia, according to his son Rocky. As publisher from 1965, Shepard witnessed the magazine's decline from its peak to its demise. A salesman with unwavering enthusiasm, Shepard was appointed publisher during the heyday of mass-circulation magazines. However, the rise of television and postal rate increases soon took their toll, eroding profit margins and contributing to the magazine's downfall. By the late 1960s, Look, Life, and The Saturday Evening Post struggled to remain relevant, with Look and The Post publishing biweekly issues. Despite being considered an also-ran to Life, Look briefly topped the charts with a circulation of 8.5 million copies before Life's dominance lasted nearly four decades under Henry Luce's ownership.

A newly found horned dinosaur, distinguished by its unique ornaments, has been found to be closely related to Triceratops. Its nasal horn was longer than Triceratops', and it featured two small horns above its eyes. A striking feature was a radiating frill, comprising large, pentagonal plates resembling a crown, situated atop its head. Researchers at the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology in Canada have named their discovery Regaliceratops peterhewsi. The team initially stumbled upon the fossilized remains protruding from a cliff along the Oldman River in southeastern Alberta about a decade ago. Like other horned dinosaurs, Regaliceratops likely evolved during the late Cretaceous period, spanning from 65 million to 100 million years ago. The nearly complete skull of Regaliceratops has been described in the latest issue of the journal Current Biology.

The United States Fish and Wildlife Service declared on Friday that all chimpanzees will be classified as endangered under the Endangered Species Act. This decision follows a 2010 petition by Jane Goodall, The Humane Society of the United States, and other organizations to eliminate the distinction between captive and wild chimpanzees. Captive chimpanzees in the US will now receive the same protections as their wild counterparts under the new classification. The new regulations necessitate permits for biomedical research, interstate trade, and the export and import of captive chimpanzees, issued by the Fish and Wildlife Service. The changes will take effect on September 14, following a 90-day grace period that begins on June 16. However, the regulations do not require permits for private ownership or use of chimpanzees in the entertainment industry, according to Dan Ashe, director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service. Ashe explained that the previous distinction conveyed a mixed message to the public, implying that chimpanzees were not in urgent need of conservation efforts.

To optimize their travel budget, older Americans should follow these expert recommendations:

Identify your top travel destinations and estimate your annual travel budget. Prioritize the most expensive trip first, advises Anne Scully, president of McCabe World Travel. Calculate the total trip cost before departure, including all expenses, such as hotel fees and departure taxes. Verify you're getting the best deal by reviewing the final price, Scully suggests. Cruises and all-inclusive trips simplify the process with a transparent, upfront cost. Leverage loyalty programs, two-for-one offers, and last-minute discounts, which may be more accessible to retirees. Consider home exchanges, a cost-effective option that allows you to swap homes without exchanging money. John Adams, a retired publisher, and his wife, Martha, have been utilizing home exchanges since 2013. With no money changing hands, they'll care for each other's homes. Popular home exchange websites include www.myplaceforyours.com, www.homeexchange.com, and www.homeforexchange.com.

Campus-affiliated accounts can conceal hidden fees that rapidly accumulate if students are not diligent about their usage. Some campus debit cards impose additional fees when students use their PINs to make purchases, unlike traditional checking accounts. Furthermore, some accounts charge substantial overdraft fees for debit transactions, as reported by the Center for Responsible Lending. To avoid these fees, students must thoroughly review their account terms and utilize their accounts in a manner that minimizes expenses. Always scrutinize the fine print, advises Meredith Turner, chief governmental officer with the California State Student Association. While adjusting to campus life can be overwhelming, students should take a few minutes to acquaint themselves with their bank accounts' rules. To set themselves up for financial success, Turner suggests taking the time to review account terms and manage personal funds. Students should consider their financial aid options and manage their personal funds before arriving on campus. If they already have a bank account, they should have their financial aid directly deposited into it, she recommends. According to estimates from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, more than half of new college students already possess a bank account.

The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science has been awarded to numerous laureates.

In 2004, Finn E. Kydland and Edward C. Prescott received the prize for their groundbreaking research in dynamic macroeconomics, focusing on time consistency in economic policy and business cycles.

In 2002, Daniel Kahneman was recognized for integrating psychological research into economic science, exploring human judgment and decision-making under uncertainty. Vernon L. Smith was also honored for establishing laboratory experiments as a valuable tool in empirical economic analysis.

The 2001 prize was awarded to George A. Akerlof, A. Michael Spence, and Joseph E. Stiglitz for their influential analyses of markets with asymmetric information.

In 2000, James J. Heckman was awarded the prize for developing theory and methods for analyzing selective samples, while Daniel L. McFadden was recognized for his work on developing theory and methods for analyzing discrete choice.

In 1975, Leonid V. Kantorovich and Tjalling C. Koopmans jointly received the prize for their significant contributions to the theory of optimum resource allocation.

The 1974 prize was awarded to Gunnar Myrdal and Friedrich August von Hayek for their pioneering work in the theory of money and economic fluctuations, as well as their insightful analysis of economic, social, and institutional phenomena.

Wassily Leontief was awarded the 1972 prize for developing the input-output method and applying it to important economic problems.

John R. Hicks and Kenneth J. Arrow jointly received the 1971 prize for their pioneering contributions to general economic equilibrium theory and welfare theory.

Simon Kuznets was awarded the 1970 prize for his empirically founded interpretation of economic growth, which has led to new and deepened insights into economic and social structure and process.

Paul A. Samuelson was awarded the 1969 prize for his scientific work, which has developed static and dynamic economic theory and raised the level of analysis in economic science.

Ragnar Frisch and Jan Tinbergen jointly received the 1969 prize for developing and applying dynamic models for the analysis of economic processes.

Taxpayers can now start filing their 2013 federal income tax returns, despite the delayed start due to the recent government shutdown. This year, those seeking IRS assistance may face distinctive challenges. The National Taxpayer Advocate's report indicates that the IRS's reduced budget and staff will likely lead to reduced service, making it harder to provide top-quality assistance. As a result, customers can expect longer wait times for answers to their questions. In 2013, the IRS received 109 million phone calls, with only 61% of callers reaching a representative, resulting in an average wait time of nearly 18 minutes.

Mutual of Omaha declined to comment on ongoing legal matters, and John Hancock did not respond to a request for comment. According to Jesse Slome, women account for approximately two-thirds of long-term-care insurance claims paid annually. Last year, insurance companies paid out $7.5 billion in claims. As a result, women will now pay significantly more in long-term-care premiums compared to men. Women will pay an average of $1,225 per year for a policy providing $164,000 in current benefits without inflation protection, while men will pay $925. The difference is even greater with 3% annual inflation protection. The association found that a typical single woman will pay an average of 12% more than in 2013. Couples who buy a policy together may experience varying premium increases depending on the insurer. Genworth noted that its gender-specific pricing only applies to single policies. Insurers typically offer significant couples discounts, and the average premium for couples with inflation protection has risen by about 3% from last year. When considering long-term care insurance, it's crucial to explore ways to secure the lowest premium possible. Consumers should shop around as premiums for similar coverage can differ significantly among insurance providers. Insurance broker Rose Clayton advises women to keep the additional premium cost in perspective. While clients may initially be disappointed to learn that women pay a higher premium, it's not a deal-breaker. Instead, it serves as a reminder to plan for their golden years. A visit to a nursing home or assisted living facility can starkly illustrate the impact of women's longer lifespan.

A federal appeals court has ruled in favor of banks and the Federal Reserve, overturning a lower court's decision. As a result, the amount banks can collect from retailers when consumers use debit cards will remain unchanged. For consumers, this means no significant changes are expected for now. According to Adam Levitin, a professor of financial regulation and consumer protection, consumers should not expect their fees to increase or their rewards to decrease. The Federal Reserve was tasked with writing rules as part of the financial regulatory overhaul following the economic crisis, and ultimately reduced the fees to 21 cents per transaction, starting October 1, 2011, down from an average of 44 cents. On Friday, the US Appeals Court for the District of Columbia overturned a district court judge's July ruling, which had favored retailers. The original rule had been challenged by retailers, who argued that the Fed had been too generous to banks. If the July ruling had stood, experts said, it was possible that swipe fees could have been reduced further.

As July approaches, many people eagerly anticipate warm weather activities like swimming, hiking, and savoring watermelon. Yet, for couples with school-age children who both work, summer can be a challenging time of balancing schedules and securing affordable childcare until the school year resumes. Sixty percent of two-parent households with children under 18 feature both parents in the workforce, according to Pew Research Center. For these families, the traditional 10-week summer break is no relaxing vacation. As Ellen Galinsky notes, "Summer is particularly demanding because we often have unrealistic expectations of summer as it's supposed to be: indulging in ice cream, watching sunsets, and spending quality time at home. But it's not always that way." Not everyone has access to nearby family members who can provide childcare or the budget for a full-time nanny. Consequently, many families rely on summer day camps. In fact, the number of summer day camps has increased by 40% over the past four years, according to the American Camp Association, which accredits both overnight and day camps.

US Secretary of Education Arne Duncan has announced that states can delay incorporating test results into teacher-performance ratings for another year, acknowledging the immense pressure on teachers due to new academic standards and rigorous standardized testing. In a blog post, Duncan emphasized the need for teachers to adapt to new standards and tests that focus on more than just multiple-choice answers, as testing issues are draining the life out of many schools. Over the past four years, nearly 40 states have passed laws linking teacher evaluations to student performance on standardized tests, with many districts planning to use these evaluations to determine tenure, promotions, and firings. These laws were a condition of Education Department waivers from the No Child Left Behind law, governing how states receive federal education funding. The test-based teacher evaluations were also a requirement for Race to the Top grants awarded by the Obama administration. Many teachers and parents argue that these laws force educators to narrow their curricula and spend too much time on test preparation, while schools scramble to adjust their curricula to align with the Common Core, new academic guidelines for math and reading from kindergarten to high school graduation. Adopted by over 40 states, the Common Core standards have become increasingly controversial.

2. The University of Tulsa, University of Miami, and Iowa State University all honor Native American heritage through their mascots.
3. Texas A&M, New Mexico State, and Utah State celebrate their agricultural roots through their mascots.
4. Central Michigan University and the University of Illinois have adapted their mascots while preserving their tribal names.
5. Florida State University and the University of Utah have maintained both their names and mascots with the endorsement of their respective Native American tribes.
6. Georgia Tech fans proposed the team's name, the Yellow Jackets, and its mascot, Buzz, as well as its secondary mascot, a 1930 Ford Model A Sport coupe.
7. The Ramblin' Wreck tradition originated from a yearly auto race that began in 1929 and evolved into a parade of makeshift mechanical contraptions.
8. In 1927, the University of Akron held a contest to find a team name and awarded $10 to the winner, who submitted the name "Zippers".
9. The team name was later changed to the Zips in 1950, and three years later, the mascot, Zippy the kangaroo, was chosen for its speed, agility, and strength.
10. Zippy is a distinctive mascot, being a female.

The US Department of Education is investigating claims that plans to close or restructure public schools in Philadelphia, Detroit, and Newark unfairly impact African American and Hispanic students, as well as those with disabilities. Advocates from these cities, along with 15 others, will meet with Education Secretary Arne Duncan to request a temporary halt on school-closing plans until alternative solutions can be developed. The group will demand swift action on civil rights complaints and urge officials to stop school closings, privatize public schools, and combine public and charter schools. The department's civil rights office has never substantiated a complaint related to school closings, according to an Education Department spokesperson.

In Tokyo, Japan's central banker Masaaki Shirakawa defended the country's monetary policy decisions, dismissing allegations of currency manipulation and emphasizing the need to combat deflation. After releasing new economic data showing an unexpected fourth-quarter contraction, Shirakawa reiterated that the Bank of Japan's top priority is stabilizing the economy, not influencing currency values. The bank decided to keep its benchmark interest rate at 0-0.1% and delay expanding its asset-buying program. Japan's economy contracted at an annualized rate of 0.4% in the October-to-December quarter, marking the third consecutive quarter of decline. Despite this, economists predict Japan's economy will recover later this year, driven by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plans for fresh fiscal stimulus and continued low interest rates.

When Diana Natalicio became the University of Texas at El Paso's first female president in 1988, a local newspaper compared her to Wonder Woman. As she enters her 26th year at the helm, her tenure remains the longest among current Texas public university presidents. Under her leadership, the university's budget has expanded substantially, from approximately $65 million to around $400 million, and research expenditures have increased from $6 million to about $76 million. The number of graduate programs offered has risen from one to 19, with more in development. Total enrollment has grown from fewer than 15,000 students to around 23,000. "I believe the biggest difference between then and now is our self-confidence as an institution," said Natalicio, now 73. "We used to underestimate ourselves, thinking no one would notice us because we were located in the Chihuahuan Desert." This month, the TIAA-CREF Institute honored Natalicio with the Theodore M. Hesburgh Award for Leadership Excellence, named after the former University of Notre Dame president.

Every city council member who takes their job seriously is searching for solutions to their financial struggles, but no one wants to discuss the issue or take the risk, said Mr. Sweet. Mr. Sweet and other public finance lawyers believe the outcome in Stockton could serve as a guide for Detroit, which is not currently in bankruptcy but has been placed under emergency management by the state of Michigan. Calpers, a $252 billion pension fund, administers pensions for California state employees and many municipal workers, calculating annual contribution amounts, billing cities, collecting payments, investing funds, and distributing benefits to retirees. In 2011, Stockton paid Calpers $20 million, roughly double the amount it spent on public libraries, and the city's payments to Calpers are expected to nearly double over the next decade, making Calpers Stockton's largest creditor. Stockton claims it has no choice but to continue making payments, even as it cuts costs elsewhere, including payments to bondholders, and argues that reducing the rate at which its workers build up their pensions would lead to a mass exodus, particularly among police officers who were recruited with promises of large, early pensions. Last year, Stockton requested a "hardship exemption" from Calpers, allowing it to slow down its contributions, but Calpers denied the request, fearing that if Stockton fell behind, it might never catch up. Calpers claims that if they give Stockton a haircut, the entire system will collapse, said Mr. Sweet. They're terrified. The phrase suggests that financial troubles tend to spread throughout the region. San Bernardino, however, did not follow the same path as Stockton, instead stopping its pension contributions after filing for Chapter 9 bankruptcy, a decision that was put on hold by the judge handling the case. In contrast, Stockton continued to make its pension contributions during its bankruptcy, a decision praised by Calpers' spokesperson, Amy Norris, who described it as a right business decision.

China has secured a free-trade agreement with Iceland, its first with a European country, as Beijing seeks to expand its economic reach amid growing concerns from its trading partners. The accord, aimed at eliminating most tariffs over the next few years, was signed in Beijing during a state visit by Icelandic Prime Minister Johanna Sigurdardottir. The two economies, vastly mismatched, with trade between the countries being relatively small, totaling $402 million in 2011. Iceland cannot offer significant new market growth, but it could help China gain more influence in the Arctic region. China is seeking to join the Arctic Council as a permanent observer. Iceland will not grant China backdoor access to the European market through this trade deal. The country had been negotiating EU membership but suspended talks in January due to domestic opposition. If Iceland were to join the EU, it would have to terminate its bilateral trade deals. The two governments issued a joint statement calling for cooperation on human rights, gender equality, labor issues, Arctic affairs, geothermal development, culture, education, and tourism. With the Doha Round of talks under the World Trade Organization stalled, some nations are seeking partnerships at a lower level. The Trans-Pacific Partnership is being negotiated between Washington and several Asia-Pacific nations, while a comprehensive trade and investment agreement is being considered with the European Union. China is not a party to either of these agreements, leading some officials and trade experts to speculate that the proposals are intended to counterbalance China's growing influence in global commerce. This development comes at a time when China's intentions towards its North Atlantic ally are under scrutiny.

Finance ministers from the world's leading economies sidestepped a public disagreement with Japan over its currency policies, instead urging Germany to boost economic growth in Europe. After two days of talks outside London, the Group of 7 finance ministers appeared to accept Japan's explanation that its new monetary measures aimed to stimulate its domestic economy, rather than manipulating the yen's value on global currency markets. The UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, stated that the G-7 ministers reaffirmed their earlier commitments on exchange rates and agreed to ensure their policies align with domestic objectives. The talks were described as in-depth and positive by other officials. The US dollar broke the 100-yen mark for the first time in over four years. The two-day meeting in Buckinghamshire also focused on combating tax evasion and banking reform, with Osborne emphasizing the importance of completing work to prevent banks from becoming too big to fail. The officials also discussed the stalled efforts to create a European banking union.

Mr. Gee's base salary of $830,439 in the most recent year stood out as the highest among the 212 chief executives, with his total compensation exceeding $1 million. He is celebrated for his remarkable fundraising skills, which have generated over $1.6 billion for the university since he took office, and his lavish lifestyle, which includes a rent-free mansion and private jet travel. According to Mr. Stripling, a significant shift has occurred in recent years, with the wealthy becoming even wealthier, and some compensation packages exceeding $1 million, even $2 million. Deferred compensation agreements can significantly boost pay, as seen in the case of Mr. Gogue, whose pay surged from $720,000 to $2.5 million in a single year. However, Mr. Stripling noted that the biggest growth last year was in the $600,000 to $700,000 range, which included 28 chief executives, up from 13 the previous year. The Chronicle report revealed that the median total compensation for public research university presidents was $441,392, a 4.7% increase from the previous year's $421,395. The median base salary was $373,800, a 2% increase from $366,519 the previous year.

Air traffic controllers in France are staging a three-day strike, starting on Tuesday, to protest the European Commission's proposal to accelerate air traffic management system integration across the continent. French counterparts in several other European countries will take limited labor action this week. France's civil aviation authority has prepared contingency plans, asking airlines serving Paris, Lyon, Nice, Marseille, Toulouse, and Bordeaux airports to reduce their flight schedules by 50% from Tuesday morning to late Thursday to minimize the strike's impact. Unions in over a dozen countries, including Belgium, Hungary, Italy, and Portugal, are likely to participate in work-to-rule and other symbolic actions on Wednesday, which may cause limited delays. The strikes coincide with a speech by European Union Transportation Commissioner Siim Kallas on Tuesday, in which he is expected to announce planned changes to European legislation transferring air traffic management responsibilities from member states to a central body in Brussels.

The great American mortgage sale, driven by extremely low borrowing costs, appears to be coming to a close. Home loan rates are unlikely to return to traditional levels but will likely remain moderate, having prompted millions of homeowners to refinance and contributed to the housing market's recovery. As 10-year government bond yields rise in response to signs of economic improvement and the Federal Reserve's plan to reduce bond purchases, mortgage rates have quickly followed suit. On Thursday, 30-year fixed mortgage rates reached 4.25 percent, up from 4.12 percent the day before, after Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke hinted at easing stimulus efforts later this year. Just a few months ago, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate was 3.5 percent, near a historic low. In contrast, credit card borrowing costs are already at relatively high levels, and rates on short-term loans, such as car loans and home equity loans, are tied to short-term interest rates, which the Fed has indicated will not rise before 2015. The rate on a five-year car loan is currently around 4 percent, similar to its level in mid-May. A fixed-rate home equity loan carries a rate of 6.1 percent, not far from where it was a month ago. The Fed's decision to keep the short-term bank lending rate at close to zero means savers will not see any improvement in the low interest rates paid on savings accounts, money market accounts, and short-term certificates of deposit, which are also tied to short-term rates.

HONG KONG - The Chinese central bank has taken measures to alleviate investor anxiety about a prolonged credit crunch by providing targeted support to bank liquidity. Chinese stock markets experienced extreme fluctuations for the second consecutive day on Tuesday, following several days of turmoil. Initially, the People's Bank of China refrained from intervening as interbank interest rates skyrocketed last week, but it has since injected more funds into the market. The uncertainty surrounding the central bank's stance led to significant trading swings on Tuesday, with the main Chinese stock indexes plummeting to their lowest levels since 2009 before largely recovering by the end of the trading day. The Shanghai composite index, which plummeted 5.3% on Monday, fell over 5% in the early afternoon on Tuesday before recovering most of its losses to close down 0.2%. The index has declined nearly 20% since reaching a peak in early February.
