After the markets closed, the People's Bank of China issued a statement aimed at calming investors' nerves and maintaining pressure on banks deemed to be taking on excessive risk.

Global stock markets plummeted and oil prices surged above $100 a barrel on Wednesday as concerns about the political crises in Egypt and Portugal intensified. The Egyptian situation dominated geopolitics after President Mohamed Morsi refused to step down, heightening the risk of violence and turmoil. Uncertainty surrounding Egypt's situation is driving up oil prices, despite the country not being a significant oil producer. Egypt produced an average of 728,000 barrels of oil per day last year, compared to Libya's 1.5 million barrels, according to BP figures. Consequently, American crude oil for August delivery was trading at $100.72 a barrel, a 1.12% increase and its first time above $100 in nine months.

The Bank of England has chosen to keep its benchmark interest rate at 0.5%, a historic low, and has not modified its economic stimulus program, which remains set at 375 billion pounds, equivalent to approximately $570 billion. This decision comes as Britain's economic recovery appears to be gaining pace, with the government reporting a 0.6% growth in the second quarter and all major industries experiencing faster growth for the first time in three years. According to James Knightley, an economist at ING, "We're starting to see genuine signs of momentum building. People feel more secure in their jobs, households feel wealthier as house prices rise, and there's a real improvement in sentiment." Following a close call with a triple-dip recession at the beginning of the year, Britain's economy has shown signs of improvement, with increasing home values, recovering consumer sentiment, and slightly increased lending to small- and medium-sized businesses. However, some economists warn that the recovery faces challenges, including inflation above the Bank of England's 2% target and concerns about slowing growth in Asia and uncertainty in the euro zone economies.

The International Monetary Fund has issued a warning in a report, indicating that Greece may face a financial shortfall of 11 billion euros over the next two years due to a persistent recession and slow reform progress. Greece received a 4 billion-euro aid package from its creditors on Wednesday, which may require debt relief and additional funding to meet the current 172 billion-euro bailout program requirements. The IMF warns that Greece's investment and growth are unlikely to recover unless investors are convinced of a credible plan to address the debt crisis. This warning has sparked concern among some IMF officials, including Paulo Nogueira Batista, who abstained from voting on additional aid to Greece, citing growing awareness of the program's risks. Batista also noted a sense of desperation among IMF staff, who urge Greek and euro-area authorities to uphold their commitments.

Hong Kong has been selected by Sotheby's as the location for the auction of a rare multimillion-dollar diamond in October, despite China's economic slowdown and a less promising outlook for Asia. "The Premier Blue", a 7.59-carat diamond, will be put up for auction on October 7 as part of Sotheby's regular bi-annual sale series. Measuring roughly the size of a shirt button, the stone boasts a vibrant blue colour and a round cut, making it exceptionally rare. Sotheby's expects the stone to sell for around $19 million, a record price per carat for any diamond, according to Quek Chin Yeow, deputy chairman of Sotheby's in Asia.

The Chinese Communist Party's anti-corruption drive has expanded into the oil sector, a highly influential and sensitive area. Authorities have launched an investigation into four executives of state-owned China National Petroleum Corporation, including three suspected of serious disciplinary violations. PetroChina confirmed that the three executives had resigned due to personal reasons. A day earlier, Wang Yongchun, a deputy general manager of China National Petroleum, was also placed under investigation for suspected disciplinary violations. The probes indicate that the Communist Party's efforts to combat corruption extend beyond the government to powerful state-dominated industries. Party leader Xi Jinping, who took power in November, had pledged to tackle official corruption and self-enrichment, a major source of public discontent.

Kazakhstan's Kashagan oil field has begun producing crude oil, a significant new source of energy to meet the world's growing demand. Initially, the field yielded a limited amount of crude, but a consortium of oil companies aims to significantly boost production over the next few years. Claudio Descalzi hailed the project as "one of the most complex in the world," describing the milestone as "historic" due to the high-quality oil and its proximity to rapidly growing markets. The field was first discovered in 2000, when it was the largest new oil deposit since the Prudhoe Bay field was discovered in Alaska in 1968. Despite being one of the largest oil fields ever discovered, Kashagan remains a testament to the challenges of finding new oil sources.

Madrid, Spain - The country is poised to meet its 2013 budget deficit target agreed upon with the European Union and is expected to emerge from recession by year's end, according to the economy minister. The government will not need supplementary austerity measures in the 2014 budget, which will be presented this month. The budget will be based on a revised forecast for 2014, with projected growth and unemployment rates that are more optimistic than previously anticipated. Spain's economy has been in recession since the construction bubble burst in 2008, but 2014 is expected to mark the beginning of a turnaround. The European Commission granted Spain extra time to meet its budgetary targets in May, given the severity of the recession. Spain's deficit is expected to drop to 6.5% of gross domestic product in 2014, down from 7% in 2013 and the initial target of 4.5%.

The Social Security Administration's website indicates that it is currently processing some spousal retirement claims and paying them according to schedule. For same-sex couples residing in states that recognize same-sex marriage, the application process is likely straightforward. However, a lingering question remains for couples who were married in one state but relocated to another that does not recognize gay marriage. The Social Security Administration uses a "place of residence" standard to determine spousal benefits, instructing staff to accept and hold applications pending further legal clarification. Mary Bonauto expressed optimism regarding the case of 83-year-old Herb Burtis, who successfully challenged the Defense of Marriage Act and is now receiving survivor benefits. Bonauto believes there is every reason to expect the agency will eventually process and pay survivor benefits to other eligible same-sex applicants. To qualify for spousal retirement benefits, you typically need to be at least 62 years old and have been married for at least 12 months. For survivor's benefits, you must be at least 60 years old and have been married for at least nine months. Bonauto recommends applying for benefits despite any uncertainties. You can apply for spousal retirement benefits online at www.ssa.gov, but must visit a local Social Security office to apply for survivor's benefits, scheduling an appointment in advance. It's recommended to bring a copy of your marriage license, civil union certificate, or domestic partnership certificate, as well as a copy of your spouse's death certificate, to your office visit. If you have questions, contact your state's regional communications director, whose contact information is listed on the Social Security website.

The 1% income bracket is not a fixed entity, as millions of individuals and households shift up or down the income scale annually based on their earnings, investments, and age. The fortunes of new tech graduates and retiring lawyers fluctuate, but those with considerable capital have fared well during the economic recovery. The 1% tends to be resilient, particularly during bad times, according to economists. A study found that a quarter to a third of individuals in the 1% in a given year remained in that bracket for the following five years. As a result, the profile of wealth in the United States has remained relatively unchanged before and after the recession. The typical high-net-worth individual is coastal, educated, older, white, and male. Warren E. Buffett exemplifies this profile, with his net worth increasing by approximately $10 billion over the past year. The tech industry has created hundreds of new top earners, mostly men. David Duffield of Workday and Elon Musk of Tesla, among others, have benefited from the tech boom. Meanwhile, fields like finance, medicine, and energy continue to generate significant wealth. Three interconnected economic phenomena have driven the boomerang effect among the country's top earners. The rich suffered significant losses when the markets plummeted, but those who held on or invested after then have been rewarded. The recent market gains have boosted the earnings and net worth of Americans who own stocks. The wealthy have benefited significantly more. The top 10% of households hold more than 80% of the value of stocks. In addition to capital gains, shareholders have also benefited from the surge in dividend payments. Many companies paid out large dividends before taxes on unearned income increased. Wealthier Americans tend to have a smaller portion of their net worth tied up in their homes. After prices dropped and credit markets relaxed, many of them were able to purchase homes as investments.

Lael Brainard, the US chief financial diplomat, is expected to depart her post by the end of the week, according to a Treasury official. Rumors swirl that the White House may appoint her to the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors. As Under Secretary for International Affairs since the Obama administration's inception, Ms. Brainard has played a pivotal role in negotiations over China's economic rebalancing and Europe's sovereign debt crisis. In her capacity as a diplomatic shuttle, she has attended numerous meetings with foreign finance ministers and central bankers, expertise that could be valuable at the Fed. Global concerns persist that the tapering of the current asset-buying program could lead to rising interest rates and the bursting of "Bernanke bubbles" abroad. Ms. Brainard is also well acquainted with the White House's nominee for Fed Chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, with whom she has worked closely in recent years to address the fallout from the deepest downturn since the Great Depression.

The German economy led all Group of 7 nations in growth last year, official data showed on Wednesday. Despite its initial success, the euro crisis and global economic slowdown are already impacting output. Germany's economy expanded by 3 percent in 2011 compared to 2010, according to the Federal Statistical Office in Wiesbaden. Most of this growth occurred in the first half of 2011, with the office forecasting a 0.25 percent decline in the fourth quarter compared to the previous three months. Some economists now predict Germany's economy will contract in the first quarter of 2012, meeting the typical definition of a recession. Despite this, Germany's 2011 growth rate of 3 percent outpaced Canada's growth rate of around 2 percent and the United States' growth rate of 1.7 percent, according to Ralph Solveen, an economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt.

In Europe, stocks suffered a minor setback on Monday after Spain's National Statistics Institute confirmed a recession in the first quarter of 2012. The institute reported a 0.3% economic contraction from January to March, echoing the same decline seen in the preceding quarter. A recession typically involves two consecutive quarters of economic decline. By the end of trading, the Euro Stoxx 50 index had fallen 1.6%, while the FTSE 100 index in London dropped 0.7%. Contrary to a Reuters poll predicting a 0.4% quarterly contraction, Spain's economy actually shrank by 0.4% compared to the same period a year earlier.

L. Rafael Reif, a seasoned electrical engineer, has been appointed as MIT's next president, succeeding Susan Hockfield. At 61, Mr. Reif will take office on July 2, having served as provost for the past seven years. As provost, he led the development of MITx and edX, expanded the institute's global presence, and nurtured the emergence of an innovation hub in Kendall Square. During the 2008 financial downturn, he oversaw a process that eliminated a $50 million structural deficit. A native of Venezuela, Mr. Reif has been part of the MIT community since 1980, serving as head of the department of electrical engineering and computer science before becoming provost. He is recognized for his research on semiconductors and has driven MIT's innovation and growth.

Mexican tomato growers have agreed to absorb significant price hikes and implement a system to boost compliance and enforcement to avoid a potential trade war, coinciding with the US Commerce Department's review of a 16-year-old agreement. The proposed price increase ranges from 18% to 25% per pound, depending on the tomato type, and growers have committed to extending the agreement to all exporting farmers, currently around 85%, to improve compliance and enforcement.

A recent survey shows that almost one-third of college students face academic struggles due to financial constraints, and a similar proportion often skip buying essential academic materials due to cost. The burden of college expenses on families and former students is well-documented in an era of stagnant incomes and rising tuition and student debt. Financial concerns are a significant source of anxiety for undergraduates, with nearly three-fifths frequently worrying about having sufficient funds for daily expenses. Students who work the most hours at part-time jobs tend to feel the most financial pressure, with about three-fifths of those working over 20 hours a week reporting that their jobs conflicted with schoolwork. For many students, financial struggles are a major obstacle to achieving their academic goals, according to Alexander C. McCormick, director of the survey. The survey polled 285,000 students at 577 four-year colleges and universities in the United States and Canada.

Recent surveys of consumer and business confidence have fallen to unprecedented lows, sparking widespread unease. In response, businesses have drastically reduced capital expenditures, including computers, delivery trucks, and equipment, largely due to concerns over higher tax rates and government austerity measures. However, some economists believe that businesses will increase spending if Congress provides clarity on fiscal policy, significantly reducing the risk of severe contraction. Businesses need a list of projects they'd like to pursue, but have been delaying due to uncertainty. Once they have a clearer understanding of the future, including tax rates, they'll be able to revive those plans and implement them. Enhanced access to credit can make capital expenditures more appealing and accessible. Commercial and industrial loans have been increasing in recent months, and the share of small business owners struggling to meet their credit needs has been declining. Corporate profits reached a record high in the third quarter, adjusted for inflation, and companies have accumulated significant cash reserves that can be used to invest in equipment or hire staff if they feel confident about the recovery. In contrast, consumers are still not financially stable, particularly since their disposable income has been stagnant or declining in recent months. However, consumers have made significant progress in reducing their debt, either by paying it down or having it written off through default, and they are also feeling more affluent due to the stabilization of the housing market. The country has finally cleared the excess housing inventory from the bubble years, and housing prices and construction are now on the rise. The pace of household formation is increasing, as young adults are finally moving into their own homes, as well as other Americans who had previously lived with family or friends. Eventually, young people can only live with their parents for so long. There are strong forces driving them to leave, both from the parents' perspective and the young adults', and as soon as they have the opportunity, many will take it.

Secretary of Education Arne Duncan emphasized the crucial role teachers' unions can play in addressing public school challenges at a Denver labor-management conference. However, this viewpoint was met with resistance in several state capitals as the conference began. Republicans in various states have proposed legislation limiting teachers' unions to negotiating compensation, excluding them from policy discussions. In Tennessee and Wisconsin, Republicans have proposed stripping teachers' unions of collective bargaining rights entirely. According to education historians, this is the most hostile political climate teachers' unions have faced since gaining legal bargaining rights. The Department of Education's conference brought together 150 districts to discuss collaborative work, with each district's superintendent, school board president, and teachers' union leader signing a pledge to work together to improve student achievement.

German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schauble warned in Frankfurt on Thursday that a Greek debt default could have severe and unpredictable consequences, but left room for a less drastic outcome. He noted that there is no precedent for a country in a currency union becoming insolvent. European leaders are now openly discussing extending the repayment period for Greek debt, despite opposition from the European Central Bank. Schauble's comments suggest he has moved closer to the central bank's stance.

The US trade deficit unexpectedly shrank in April, with the country exporting a record-breaking $175.6 billion worth of goods and services abroad. According to the Commerce Department's report, released on Thursday, exports of goods reached $126.4 billion and services $49.1 billion, while imports totalled $219.2 billion, resulting in a trade deficit of $43.7 billion - the lowest since December. The revised March deficit was $46.8 billion, down from the initial estimate of $48.2 billion. Economists had forecast the deficit would swell to $48.8 billion. A weaker US dollar has made American goods more competitive globally, while growing demand in developing nations has driven up export prices. The Commerce Department attributed the April surge in exports to increased sales of industrial supplies, capital goods, and consumer goods. The decline in imports was partly due to a decrease in automotive parts, vehicles, and industrial supplies, the department said.

European finance ministers made significant headway towards a comprehensive debt crisis solution at a G20 meeting, despite ongoing hurdles. Officials concurred on implementing necessary measures to stabilize the financial system and mitigate the crisis. A comprehensive plan is slated for introduction at a Brussels meeting on October 23. US Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner voiced optimism regarding the European efforts' pace and direction, citing commitments from France and Germany. Nevertheless, Geithner emphasized that the plan's true impact will hinge on the details, which remain difficult to gauge until it takes concrete form.

The University of Chicago's Joe and Rika Mansueto Library is a futuristic building with a unique design, featuring no traditional bookshelves. Despite offering nearly one million items online, the library has also invested in advanced technology. Unlike other academic libraries, the Mansueto Library is one of the largest and latest to incorporate automated storage and retrieval systems, housing its volumes in solid steel cases 50 feet underground. Books can be retrieved through a complex system of cranes and elevators, reminiscent of the door-sorting machine from Pixar's "Monsters Inc." The $81 million Mansueto Library has a capacity for 3.5 million volumes, freeing up space in the main library's cramped stacks. The Mansueto Library also features a lab that serves dual purposes: digitization and conservation. The lab not only repairs and rebinds the university's books, including ancient papyrus volumes, but also cleans and prepares materials for scanning, which are then shared with partner Google Books.

Despite a significant $30 million budget reduction, the Brownsville Independent School District is placing a high priority on its chess program, allocating a substantial $400,000 this year. This notable investment sets the district apart from others across the country. According to Jay Harris, who oversees the program, Brownsville's commitment to chess is unparalleled. As a city grappling with poverty and situated on the US-Mexico border, the district views chess as a valuable asset for student achievement and a source of community pride. This year, around 4,000 students have enrolled in the district's chess programs, which include regular tournaments. Harris notes that typically, 500 to 800 students attend these events.

James Anthony, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, often discovers that many iPhone and iPod Touch developers share his programming background. He and others learned Apple's hit mobile devices through Stanford's popular iPhone applications course, which debuted in 2008. Anthony took the class as a senior, while many others learned through free video recordings on iTunes U, which consistently ranks as one of the most downloaded courses. Stanford's online class remains the primary way to learn about iPhone development, but online students miss out on in-person benefits. This term's classes are not available online, although past sessions are typically uploaded to iTunes U within two to three days. Stanford is unable to discuss the new iPad due to rights issues, but a lecture from last winter provided valuable tips for iPad programming. Despite limitations, past classes offer iPhone developers a rare opportunity to gain insight from Apple, notoriously secretive about its technology.

Ken Meyer and Carmine Fiore clasped hands in the kitchen, while their daughters, Sabina Meyer and Stephanie Fiore, tackled logistical challenges at opposite ends of Room 227 on moving-in day at Queens College's sole dormitory. Stephanie Fiore was stumped by her extensive shoe collection, scrambling to find space in her compact closet. Meanwhile, above, roommates Letticia Camacho and Juliet Dolan chuckled at the serendipitous coincidence of matching color schemes: turquoise-and-purple hangers, storage boxes, and sheets. On the fifth floor, Mohamed Sako left his door ajar, his stereo playing Nicki Minaj's "Your Love" lyrics: "You got spark, you, you got spunk." Living on campus is a rare privilege for 500 of Queens College's 20,000 students, a commuter college accessible by car and bus, but not subway. The Summit, officially known as the dorm, offers rooms with full kitchens, cable TV, wireless internet, and private bathrooms. The dorm boasts a hotel-like atmosphere, with carpeted hallways, a glass-encased gym, and a lobby featuring flat-screen TVs. For residents, it's a convenient and coveted living arrangement. For the college, it serves as a valuable recruitment tool, offering a unique selling point to prospective students.

Researchers have enlisted 3,000 educators from seven US school districts, including Dallas, Denver, Charlotte, North Carolina, Hillsborough County, Florida, Memphis, New York, and Pittsburgh. Participating teachers consented to classroom video recordings, with access restricted to researchers alone. The project features teachers from grades four to nine in regular public schools. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation requested additional recordings from Charlotte and Memphis teachers, with the understanding that these would not be subject to confidentiality agreements. Rachael Maher, a seventh-grade math teacher at Alexander Graham Middle School in Charlotte, volunteered to record her classes. For an hour, Ms. Maher taught her students the Pythagorean theorem while digital video equipment captured a panoramic view of the classroom. Two scorers from the Educational Testing Service reviewed the video footage to critique Ms. Maher's performance. The scorers, Edith Aurora Graf and Leslie Thornley, watched the video multiple times, analyzing Ms. Maher's rapport with her students, pacing, and transitions.
